My Cries and Your Whispers

by Holy_dyke

Summary

On a random, depressing day. In a bar the brokenhearted professor Rio Vidal knows all too well, she sees a woman. Or as she describes her in her head, an ethereal being, the painter Agatha Harkness—a woman whose mere presence sobered Rio up, then made her drunk again for an entirely different reason.

Can Rio—a woman who doubts her self-worth, who believes she's undeserving of love—handle holding the door open for someone as delicate and willing as Agatha?
And if she does, can she handle letting her in afterward?

Chapter One

Rain heavily poured down on her as she sat in her garden, surrounded by the plants she put so much effort into growing so they could soothe her. To reconnect with her own self. To be held by nature's embrace.

As the rain continued to fall down on her head and soaking her wet. Feeling the water cleansing her whole being, her mind wouldn't rest. Her thoughts were consumed by the woman who left her broken and completely out of control of herself.

Tears steamed her face and mixed with the raindrops. Her head was filled with only her—that woman. Her ex–girlfriend.

Four months ago, Rio Vidal's world completely shattered after that breakup. It weakened her.

The last words her ex–girlfriend said still felt like daggers in Rio's body. They made her bleed and weep. 

“I look at you and I see nothing, Rio. I see nobody but a stranger I once knew. I don't even know how I loved you in the first place, you're a monster Rio Vidal.” 

“I'm the monster? You really want to have this conversation with me right now, Jane? I fucking caught you cheating on me with a dude for fuck's sake! On our goddamn bed! While I was gone, planning a vacation for your majesty so we could celebrate our fourth anniversary! But you obviously had better plans in your head.” Rio said as she looked at her girlfriend who refused to meet her eyes. 

“I don't love you Rio, I'm sorry but I just don't.”

“Yeah don't worry. I figured that out when I saw a dick deep inside you.” Rio's voice dropped lower as she walked toward the couch. Throwing all of her weight as she sat down with a heavy sigh. Feeling herself getting consumed by the piece of furniture. 

Rio stretched her arm toward the coffee table and grabbed the bottle of vodka.

“I'm leaving.” Her girlfriend said once Rio took the first gulp.

“You better do.” Rio whispered as she stared at the black screen of the turned-off TV as she clenched the bottle tighter. She didn't want to look at her girlfriend's defrauding green eyes.

As Jane walked toward the door with force, the sound of her heels clicking on the floor with every step she took. “I had no regrets 'til I met you, Rio.” she said and stepped out. Slamming the door shut behind her.

Rio never understood how her ex girlfriend managed to play the victim's role in a situation like that. Or how she manipulated her into believing that she was the bad person. The monster who never deserved love or happiness.

How did she manag to get into her head and fuck with her life over and over again? And why did she allow it? How was she so naïve, standing in the corner and looking at herself from an outsid instead of stepping in to rescue herself? 

Until it was too late.

Her life felt hollow. Empty of any meaning or purpose. Rio felt like nothing could save her anymore. She should just rot and everything could burn in hell.

She had experienced breakups before, but none came close to this miserable one.

Her depression wasn't merely a result of her ex's constant manipulation. How she cheated on her and lied to her for years.

It stemmed from how disgusted Rio was with herself. 

The sunlight woke her up instead of the alarm.

Rio had left the windows open last night while she was gazing at the clouded moon. Thinking about taking her own life while drinking like a maniac.

But for some reason, she couldn't do it. 

The night breeze was cold and it brushed with her hair tenderly. The moon looked alluring. Its light escaped through the grey clouds and illuminated the night. The clouds sailed in the sky and there were a few shining stars, blinking constantly. The neighborhood looked different at night, it was peaceful. She observed and noticed it all, even with her blurry vision. She saw the cats moving, heard the wind whispering and the night humming.

And that gave Rio something else other than how miserable she was to think about.

Maybe another night, when the sky wouldn't be so beautiful. 

Her headache was unbearable. Rio was able to feel every goddamn nerve pulsating in her head. It felt like a warning, that her head would explode at any second.

Rio cursed herself as she removed the duvet away from her body and forced herself to sit down. The moment she put her feet on the floor, the alarm went off and it was so loud. She felt it in her stomach instead of her ears, and it was nauseating.

She walked toward the bathroom with heavy, languid. Dragging her legs forward that she felt they were moving on their own.

Rio grabbed the bathroom's door for dear life when she felt the nauseous sensations burning in her stomach.

She put her hand on her mouth as she hurried her steps until her head was leaning down to the toilet seat and her body fell down on the cold floor of the dark bathroom, she didn't even bother turning the lights on.

Rio immediately started vomited her soul out. Her mouth and stomach were burning. The taste was making her sicker than she already was. Her head stayed leaning down as she felt the tension in her neck and shoulders because she couldn't sleep well last night. Her hair was falling down by her sides and its length was annoying, adding to all the shit she was experiencing. Rio needed to cut it from its roots.

She felt disgusted with herself. It was unbearable.

But the coldness of the bathroom's floor offered a sense of... safety and belonging. As if she belonged there, sitting on the floor while vomiting her feelings out of her body with her eyes closed shut.

After a few minutes, Rio spat down then she managed to stand on her feet again while wiping her mouth with her sleeve.

She washed her face multiple times then she lifted her water-dripping head and stared at her reflection—she looked like hell.

Rio had been looking like hell for months now. She had lost so much weight, and whatever she was feeling, it appeared on the outside, whether she wanted or not.

The darkness that circled her eyes had become a part of her face. The pale, damaged skin and the chapped, dry lips. The messy, split hair. Misery was written all over her face.

She stared for a few more seconds, then Rio turned her face away, unable to handle her own reflection any longer. Who was she staring at? Who the hell was that?

She hopped into the shower after taking every piece of fabric off her body. The warm water cascaded down her whole being, feeling her body getting cleaned while her mind drowned in thoughts Rio couldn't contain. She didn't know how to do that. She didn't have the right container.

Rio stepped out and wrapped a towel around her body without actually drying. She walked the hallway to her bedroom as her body and hair dropped down on the floor.

She approached the wardrobe and pulled out the first thing her eyes landed on—some black trousers a white button–up shirt and she grabbed her usual jacket from the chair, that black jacket that she didn't wash in a week and a few days.

Rio got into her car and drove to the nearest café to the university as she listened to her thoughts during the ride. Blending with the annoying sounds of the streets, people and the morning.

After grabbing her black coffee she made her way to the office, she wasn't ready for any of this.

“Hey, nice seeing you here, stranger. Where have you been?”

“I was literally here yesterday, Alice.”

“No, I mean where have you been, Rio? You either at home or here. You don't even go out anymore. It has been months.”

“Yeah, I've been busy.” Rio said as she unlocked the door, pushed it open and stepped inside.

“Busy mourning an asshole?” Alice asked as she followed Rio inside.

Rio turned around and looked at her with sharp eyes.

She knew her ex was an asshole but she didn't want to hear it, she couldn't bear hearing such a fact. She didn't want a reminder. 

The only asshole Rio was mourning every morning was herself.

“Sorry. But seriously, Rio, you should go out. You'd get yourself killed like that.”

“Out where, Alice? Bars? Clubs? Drinking all night as I try to pour my sadness and suffering into any girl's mouth that would be willing to swallow?” Her voice rose as she heavily placed her things on the desk.

“I didn't mean that.” Alice sat on the green velvet couch, looking at Rio.

Rio ran a hand through her hair then she opened a bottle of water and started watering her plant. She needed to do something with her hands otherwise she'd explode. 

She looked back at Alice and her heart tightened in her chest as she firmly closed the bottle. She didn't like the sympathetic look in her best friend's eyes. It weakened her.

“Don't you have lectures to attend, professor?” Rio said as she sat down on the chair. Trying to change the subject so she wouldn't be the center of it.

“No, I'm staying here.”

“Well, I have lectures to attend. So I have to go.”

“Do you want to grab a drink later? Just talking, catching up. You know?”

Rio looked at her, holding back.

She wanted to go out—see people, and talk. But she also didn't want to. What good would that do to her? To talk and force someone to hear her problems? People have enough pain already. They're dealing with their own struggles everyday, then why bother them with more?

“Just the drink without the talking part.” Rio said after a while. Breaking the uncomfortable silence that was about to stretch.

“You'll talk eventually.” Alice softly smiled as she stood up. 

She exited and closed the door behind her after telling Rio to take care of herself.

Rio let out a deep, heavy sigh as she leaned back on her chair. Feeling the tension in her muscles and her headache was worsening with every passing second. She leaned forward and grabbed her coffee that she knew won't help her in any way. But she needed it so she wouldn't crash out.

She managed to survive the day and herself. Aside from how hard her work could be. How challenging it was at times, Rio found some kind of comfort in teaching. It distracted her from herself. Looking at the faces of the youth as she explained to them, it made her feel good even if it was temporary and it faded the moment the lecture reached its end.

Rio stepped out of her office, exited campus and headed to the parking lot while fisting the car key in her hand. 

“Hey, Vidal!” Alice called her from behind.

Rio inhaled deeply before she turned around to face her. “Hey, what's up?”

“Still up for the drinks, right?”

“You say that like I have a say in this.” Rio chuckled.

“Exactly, you don't.” Alice said, her voice was laced with amusement.

“God Alice, you're insufferable.”

“I know. Anyway, going somewhere?”

“Yeah, home.”

“Great, so I'll meet you there or should I come and pick you up?”

“No, just text me the address and I'll be there.”

“Alright. Don't you dare bail on me though.”

“I wish I could do that, Alice.” 

Alice chuckled as she put her hands in her pockets. “By the way,” She paused to search Rio's face. “Jen will be there, if that's okay.”

Rio met Alice's uncertain eyes as she took a few seconds to think. Then she smiled, an honest smile that reached all the way up to her tired eyes.

“Yes, of course. It's about time I meet her properly.”

Once Rio got into her car, she took a deep breath, started the engine and headed to her depressing home.

She opened the front door and stepped inside. Rio took her shoes off by the door and walked to nestle into the couch, letting the heavy silence of her house consum.

She closed her eyes for a while, as her head visually replayed many unpleasant memories. Heavy, awful things that happened right in this living room. Tears threatened to fall down but Rio refused to listen to them, she didn't want to obey. So she opened her eyes and her eyelids were heavier than a rock.

Rio laggardly dragged her feet toward the kitchen. She grabbed a bottle of beer and drank it as she got upstairs, heading to the mess that was called her bedroom. 

She took her clothes off and put on an oversized t–shirt.

She gluped her beer down until the bottle was empty. Rio set it on the nightstand and crashed onto her bed. 

A couple of hours later, Rio woke up sweating and her breaths were heavy. She couldn't do anything other than stare at the ceiling, tracing its patterns while listening to the buzzing of her phone blending with her heavy gasps.

Rio closed her eyes as she put one of her hand on her chest, right above her heart and the other rested on her stomach.

She tried calming her alerted body down. Trying and failing to remind herself that there was no reason to panic.

She started counting inside her head as she desperately tried organizing her breaths. 

Rio weakly bent her legs up as she listened to her heartbeats ringing inside her ears. She closed her eyes as she slid her hand underneath her shirt and started palming her chest to calm her heart down, until she was finally able to feel herself getting back inside.

“Hello?”

“Dude are you sleeping?”

“Not anymore.”

“Good. Okay, can you meet us in an hour?”

Rio sighed. “Sorry, I crashed out. I didn't sleep...” She pressed two fingers on her eyes, desperately trying to ease the headache away only for a few seconds. “Anyway, meet you an hour, yeah?”

Rio hung up as she threw her phone on the bed and her body slid down to lay on her back again. 

She stared at the ceiling while regretting her entire life. “Death is not coming to me anytime soon,”

She sighed as she set it back on its place.

She washed her face as she ignored her own reflection in the mirror. She wasn't in the mood to deal with herself.

Rio looked at her wardrobe, considering the options. But she wasn't really looking, her head was blank in a terrifying way and her eyes were only drifting left and right.

She settled on black trousers and a navy-blue button–up shirt, not wanting to over think any of it. She was going to drink all night until she black out, which was what she had been doing for a long time lately, but the difference was she'd do it with someone else.

Rio forced herself to look at her reflection just so she could apply her eyeliner and lipstick and didn't glance any longer. Although she caught that empty look in her eyes.

She grabbed her bag and keys then stepped out. The night breeze embraced her, causing a shiver to run down her spine.

Rio took a deep breath as she closed her eyes. She felt utterly present in that moment as the strange sensation took over her. Creeping inside.

She parked her car and got out of it, heading to the usual bar—the one that she knew all too well.

“Here we are.” Rio muttered to herself while stepping inside, searching for Alice with her eyes in the booth she knew Alice would be sitting in.

“Here, Rio!” Alice shouted from the back of the bar, waving with her hand so Rio could notice her.

“Rio this is Jennifer. Jen this is Rio.”

The two women looked at each other at the same time, exchanging polite smiles.

“Nice to finally meet you.” Jen said as she offered her hand for Rio to shake.

“Nice to meet you, Jennifer.” Rio gladly took her hand.

“I can't believe this is the first time you guys meet each other.” Alice said as she clapped her hands together. “Why is that?” She looked at Rio, knowing the exact answer to her question.

“Wrap it up, Alice.” Rio chuckled.

“Not famous as a celebrity but she's one of the greatest painters I've ever met. Seriously. I went to her gallery last year in Paris and I was stunned by her and her work.”

A woman with dark hair falling behind her back and piercing blue eyes that anyone could drown deep into even from a distance. She had the perfect nose, lips and jaw. Her face was so beautiful. So comforting to look at.

“W-which one?” Rio swallowed. Her mouth was dry all of the sudden.

“Above the couch.” Alice gestured with her hand into the air above Rio's head.

“Oh, yeah. Yeah, what about it?”

“It's hers. I bought it years ago.”

“Really?” Rio felt her heart pounding in her chest for no reason. It was that annoying beating that made her stomach twist and burn. “I love that painting.” she said as she senselessly turned her head around to look at that painter's captivating face again, but she was met with her back instead.

“Black: My True Love's Heart.”

And she left, heading to the restroom.

She ran a wet hand through her hair as she sighed then that woman—that ethereal being stepped inside and Rio's heart tightened in her chest.

She inhaled deeply and a soothing scent filled her senses, sending a shiver to run down her spine.

“Gosh you're gorgeous.” Rio spoke inaudibly, yet, the sentence echoed somehow in the empty space.

And her heart pounded as her words lingered.

Agatha looked at Rio's reflection with a raised eyebrow and her lips were curled up in a hint of a faint smirk.

Then she turned around the moment Rio did.

Their eyes locked.

“Excuse me?”

Rio swallowed as she constantly blinked. Feeling her body tremble because of Agatha's deep voice.

“Sorry, I'm drunk,” Rio whispered and she immediately started walking away with beating heart. Leaving Agatha behind her who she certainly heard her chuckilng seductively.

Nothing was working, the universe made it as clear as crystal that nothing was on her side, not even her mind

That raised eyebrow...

She stayed in her place for a few more, silent minutes. Lying horizontally with a throbbing head. Then got up, even though sleeping for a few more hours sounded tempting, she needed to get up.

Rio washed her face and brushed her teeth then headed back to that dump of a room.

She tried her best to clean up. Hours and hours of trying to make the room suitable for living again.

And she was satisfied with the final result. Better than nothing, she told herself.

After taking a cold shower, she went to the kitchen, opened the fridge, and found that basically, nothing was edible in there. She huffed and opened the wall cabinets—Rio was grateful for any and every divine power out there for the cereal she found, that she didn't even remember when she had bought.

She opened the empty fridge again, took out the milk, and had the breakfast of a five–year–old kid.

Hours passed by doing nothing. Everything was boring and the idea of getting out of the house tired her, let alone actually doing it.

She was watching some dull documentary on some channel about paintings. Though she wasn't really paying any attention, until the name Agatha Harkness was mentioned and that made her open her eyes widely and focus them on the screen in disbelief as memories of last night flooded her.

That documentary was old because the woman looked younger—she was discussing one of her paintings and Rio had never looked more focused on something in her entire life. 

She didn't even know who that woman was three days ago, what were the chances of watching her on a documentary only a few days later? Had Rio seen Agatha before that and she didn't recognize her because she didn't know her?—not that she actually knew her.

But, would Rio have watched an old documentary about artists and paintings, her eyes glued to the screen, if she hadn't seen Agatha on that bar?

She wouldn't have. Not even in a million years.

The deep voice of the woman was soothing in many ways. It made her melt on the couch. Rio felt relaxed, safe even. It was oddly satisfying. And Rio wasn't even sure what she was listening to, she just knew that woman—Agatha—was looking beautiful and talking about one of her artworks.

Then Agatha looked directly into the camera, and Rio felt it, as if she were looking at her. Pulling her forward. As if they were staring at each other knowingly.

But they weren't.

A couple of minutes passed and Agatha disappeared. Paintings filled the screen and the reporter voice was ringing, became boring again, unbearable.

Rio kept her eyes glued on the screen in front of her. Just in case. Hoping Agatha would return at any second, but she didn't.

Rio's mind replayed the image of her in the bar. 

Over and over again. She traced her features through her mind's eye, memorzing them

“Gosh, you're gorgeous.”

“Excuse me?”

“Sorry, I'm drunk.”

Rio covered her face in embarrassment as she remembered how stupid she acted. How her heart pounded.

“You couldn't be more stupid, could you? ‘Sorry, I'm drunk’ who the hell wants to hear that? Oh my God.”

Her scolding of herself didn't last much longer because she was interrupted by the sound of her phone buzzing by her side. And of course it was Alice.

“Hey, where are you?”

“Home.”

“Are you kidding? Why haven't you responded to my messages then?”

“What messages? I didn't see anything.”

“Jesus Christ, Rio. I asked you yesterday if you could make it to the party tonight.”

“Hold on, hold on, what party? What messages? What's the occasion? And the answer is no.”

“Can you please just shut up? It's a par...”

“No I won't shut up, I'll hang up now, bye”

“I'll come to your house and drag you from there, and you know I would.”

“Alright, alright, stay right where you are. What's the party for? Who is getting married?”

“Just shut up and let me talk.” Alice said. Then continued when she didn't hear a response from Rio. “Alright, so Jen and I were planning to have a party for a long time now, my friends, her friends, our friends’ friends and others. There's no particular occasion; we just wanted to have some fun. But to be honest, I want to propose to her tonight. I've been thinking about it for a month now, and I think tonight is the night. And I really, really want you to be there, Rio. So please say you'll come.”

“You're abusing me Alice, because that's a lot, and you know socializing tortures me. But sure, I'll be there.”

“Oh my God, really?”

“Yeah dude, and I'm really happy for you, I think I'm gonna cry.”

“Don't,” Alice said with a chuckle. “Be there at 9. Love you. Take care of yourself, yeah?”

“Love you too, Alice. And you too. Take care of yourself.” She said and hung up.

She let out a breath she didn't know she was holding.

Well, party.

After feeling bad for herself this morning, she decided to at least buy the groceries that she needed the most.

She put on a green hoodie and her good to go trousers and stepped out of the house.

The weather was great, and the cold breeze was welcoming, brushing her hair to the side and making her nose red. The coldness sent an electric wave to travel through her entire body, and that made her smile. A sudden attack of delight made her feel better.

She walked from section to section, picking up only what she felt was necessary, as if her fridge wasn't crying to be filled for months.

She steeped outside, lit a cigarette and took the first puff. The smoke filled her lungs and senses. The burning sensation rested in her throat, and the sudden rush of nicotine in her body made her relax as her muscles loosened. She walked to her car, put the bags in the back and headed home. She was feeling good.

Around 7 PM, she sat on the couch looking through photos, trying to waste some time.

And there it was, a photo she had forgotten to delete.

Her ex–girlfriend kissing her cheek as Rio looked directly at the camera with a silly grin on her face. Her eyes were full of love and appreciation.

Rio looked at herself in the photo for minutes before she deleted it and threw her phone away.

One of her sudden panic attacks took control of her entire body. Anxiety coursed through her veins, Rio felt like her heart would break through her rib cage and escape her chest.

She started sweating so she got up from the couch, and tried to breathe, once, twice. Again and again. Her legs lost the ability to stand, so she lowered her head looking at the ground, trying to put her weight on her knees.

Dizziness began to take control of her head, making her feel numb and acutely aware of everything at the same time. She remembered how her mother used to hold her during her panic attacks as a kid, and how her whole body would relax and regain its normal state, but not at that moment—no one was there to hold her. No one was ever there to hold her.

So, she fell beside the couch onto the floor with a loud thud and tried to hold herself as tightly as she could, embracing her body while trying to steady her breaths.

“It will be fine, Rio. It will be fine, Rio. It will be fine, Rio.”

She kept repeating that sentence over and over again, until she was able to breathe normally again. Her head was still dizzy and her vision was blurry from the tears that fell from her eyes unconsciously. She sat onthe cold floor for several minutes, trying to get herself back.

Then she got up, wiped the tears with the back of her hand while walking toward the bottle of vodka that was setting on the table.

She poured the first glass and drank it in one swig. The burning in her mouth led her to pour the second. During the third one she realized that she—unfortunately—had somewhere to go in an hour and a half. She abandoned the bottle and went upstairs. Washing her face five times with cold water without looking at her reflection, because she knew what she would see there.

By 8:30 PM she was ready—a navy-blue blazer, a dress shirt in the same color and a black trousers. Having opened the first three buttons of her shirt to leave a space to show her cleavage and that necklace that she refused to take off.

Red lipstick, black eyeliner, and letting her hair fall down to her shoulders.

She drove to Alice's place, took a few minutes to prepare herself while leaning on her seat, then she got out. Before knocking on the door, it swung open, revealing Alice.

“Rio! You're here!”

“I guess I am.” Rio said with a soft smile as she handed Alice the bottle of wine she brought with her.

“God, I'm so happy you're here! come on in.”

Alice moved aside so Rio could step in. Many people were there—people she either didn't know or didn't recognize.

“You look gorgeous.”

Alice said with a smile on her lips as she looked at Rio

“Thanks Alice. You look really beautiful too, this color really suits you.”

“Oh, thank you.” Alice blushed. “You won't believe who is here, but now come with me, I need to show you something.”

Rio followed Alice to one of the empty rooms. Alice took out a small box from her pocket, opened it, and waited for Rio's reaction. Rio looked at the radiant ring inside, then looked at Alice while smiling.

“Alice, this is so beautiful! Without exaggerating. I think it's one of the prettiest rings I've ever seen.”

“Really? Do you think she'd like it?”

“She would love it. Trust me.”

They both smiled at each other and then left the room to engage with the party's vibes.

Rio was laughing at something Alice had said when she looked up to see that dark-haired woman with her piercing, hypnotizing blue eyes.

Rio couldn't believe her eyes, so she glanced at Alice who was already looking at Agatha.

“This is who I wanted to tell you is here.” Alice said as she met Rio's gaze.

“What is she doing here?” Rio whispere.

“I don't know. I seriously don't know. She came here with a friend of a friend. Lilia. I still cannot believe it. I haven't even talked to her yet cause I'm afraid I'll look like an obsessed fangirl.”

Rio looked once more at the woman.

Agatha met her gaze from across the room and time stopped for a few seconds.

Rio tried to look relaxed but she couldn't, so she immediately looked away with a pounding heart and embarrassing memories of last night flooded her head.

She grabbed one of the champagne glasses from a passing tray and gluped it down in an attempt to busy herself with it. She couldn't look at the woman.

Why would she be here? Why now?

“Come, I want you to meet some of my friends.” Alice broke the silence and brought Rio back—she was grateful for that.

Alice walked and Rio followed by her side. She introduced her to some of her friends whom Rio knew she'd forget about by tomorrow morning or once she'd step out of this house.

“Look who is here, Rio Vidal!” A voice filled with amusement came from behind her. Rio turned her face toward the source as she put her glass down.

Her eyes were gleaming and an honest, warm smile formed on her lips the moment she saw Lilia.

“God, Lilia!”

They embraced each other warmly. Wrapping their arms around one another.

“I missed you, kid.” Lilia said as she pulled back and held Rio's hand tightly in hers.

“So did I,” Rio said sincerely, she had always loved Lilia.

“How are you doing?” Lilia asked with that mothery, concerned voice of hers.

“Fine. Good, doing good.” 

Lilia knew she was lying and Rio knew she knew. The older woman always had a way of seeing right through her, but she never pushed her.

“How is your new project?” Rio asked in an attempt to change the topic and spot the light on something other than herself.

“Great. So far, I'm really proud of what we have achieved. I've been working with this amazing artist, Rio. You should meet her.”

Lilia looked at Rio with a bright smile. “Come, I'll introduce you to her. You'd love her.” she took Rio's hand in hers and walked her through the room.

Rio's heart raced inside her chest as they started walking closer to the woman Lilia was talking about and Rio realized who she was. Rio couldn't even breathe the moment they stood in front of her.

“Agatha darling, this is Rio.”

Agatha's eyes sparked upon hearing Rio's name for the first time. As if she was waiting to hear it.

Agatha extended her hand with a smirk and a delighted look in her gleaming eyes.

Rio hesitated for a brief second before shaking it. Rio's hand trembled after the unexpected connection that she, in fact, had anticipated.

She felt Agatha's hand in hers. It was soft. It made her heart pound. It felt right in hers. And Rio wanted to run away because it was overwhelming.

“I was telling Rio about our project,” Lilia said as her eyes drifted between the two women.

Agatha's eyes never left Rio's face even though Rio refused to meet her gaze. She couldn't do that. 

What if Agatha recognized her?

They talked for a few minutes. Mostly, it was Agatha and Lilia exchanging topics, because for some reason, Rio couldn't find her own voice. She couldn't talk or engage, not when she was that close to the woman and she could smell her with every inhale.

“I'll leave you girls to know each other, I have dozens of people to see.” Lilia patted Rio on the shoulder and left. Leaving her alone.

Rio froze in her place, if she wanted to move her legs she wouldn't be able to do so. It was as if someone had poured cement on her feet and glued her to the floor.

She felt Agatha's eyes on her, looking at every feature, as if she was observing her.

So Rio lifted her head, and met her blue eyes for the third time.

Their eyes locked.

Her heart raced.

And she knew she was blushing from the alcohol in her system and because of who was standing in front of her.

“Rio.” Agatha said her name for the second time, as if she was tasting how it sounded. Finding delight and pleasure in saying it out loud. Victory in knowing it.

“Where have we met?”

If Rio was frozen before, then she became a statue the moment the question landed on her ears.

“I–I don't really know.” Rio said. “Have we? Met, I mean?” she was such a bad liar and she knew it. She was sweating for fuck's sake.

“I think it was 3 days ago,” Agatha said with a smirk, refusing to change the subject. She was clearly enjoying herself.

Rio looked at her again. Taking her in the same way she did at the bar.

Looking at her clothes—adark blue suit, a black high–necked top and a golden necklace. Rio realized they were wearing similar shades of blue.

Rio looked back at Agatha who was already looking at her with lips curled up in a knowing smile.

“Where?” Rio finally said. Still denying it, because the memory was too embarrassing to handle or even to talk about. 

“At the bar?” Agatha said with a raised eyebrow and an amused smirk. “And I quote...” she licked her lips. “‘Gosh, you're gorgeous.’” Agatha said Rio's words as she looked straight into her eyes.

Rio's face turned red and her body trembled. Hearing Agatha say it like that, out loud, did something to her—it made her heart tighten in her chest.

Embarrassment flooded her whole being but there was something... else.

Something about Agatha's anticipated look and delighted smirk. Something about Agatha's whole presence. Something about Agatha...

“I told you I was drunk.” Rio whispered as she clenched her glass in her hold and briefly looked down at the floor.

Agatha laughed. The rich sound came out of her throat in a low, deep tone. Seductively. Laughter had never sounded that intoxicating.

Her laughter made Rio look up at her and smiled in return as she saw the jaw in her face.

“I know sweetheart, but I have to tell you, you looked adorable.”

Rio was not doing well after that sentence.

“What do you do, Rio?” It felt as if Agatha loved how Rio's name sounded in her mouth—the taste of it.

“I'm an English professor,” Rio said while nodding with her head without a reason. Spinning from her glass and drifting her eyes up and down. She was nervous.

“And you? No wait, I actually know. My friend Alice told me about you.”

“Yeah? I'm an artist, I mostly paint.” Agatha smiled. Her smile was bright, reaching all the way up to her eyes.

She looked beautiful.

“It suits you,” her tongue slipped.

“How?” Agatha asked with an amused tone as she took a step toward Rio. And Rio's heart fell down to her stomach as she inhaled her in. She was too close.

“I—” 

“Hi, I'm Alice.” Alice interrupted the moment by awkwardly introducing herself. And Agatha immediately took a step back, putting a space between them.

And Rio kept looking at her as her mouth watered and her stomach tensed and burned.

“Nice to meet you, Alice. Agatha Harkness.” she said as they shook hands.

“I don't really know if you remember me, but... we met last year in Paris.” Alice said with a nervous smile on her face.“I just wanted to tell you it's actually an honor for me to have you here ms. Harkness.”

“Thank you. The honor is truly mine. It's a really great party you have in here.” Agatha said as she looked at Alice, then at Rio—her eyes lingered there for a few long seconds before they drifted back to Alice. “And forgive me for not remembering you.”

“No, no, I completely understand.” Alice grinned.

Rio couldn't help but to stare at the woman in front of her as she talked with her friend. Noticing everything about her. She was... Intoxicating.

And Agatha seemed to notice every time Rio's eyes landed on her. Because every time her lips would curl up and she'd glance at Rio only for a second.

“Excuse me but I have to steal Rio for a moment.” Alice said and then dragged Rio with her.

“What?” Rio asked.

“Dude, I'm nervous.”

“Why?”

“There's too many people here, I should've thought about that.”

“Hey, don't worry. Look it's just for a few moments, you know? Once you propose you'd be lost in the bubble that contains only the both of you and you'll forget about everybody else. But if you're not comfortable with it then just do it in a private place where you'd feel completely comfortable.”

“I want to do it now.”

“Then go get it, tiger!” Rio grinned.

Alice looked at her for a few seconds then nodded. “Alright, wish me luck.” 

“Good luck!”

And with that Alice walked toward Jen who was standing among people. Alice looked Jen in the eyes, then took the small black box out of her pocket, knelt on one knee and opened the box while asking Jen to marry her.

Jen said yes with a blush, then they kissed. Passionately. Warmly. With love. Their smiles visible on their features even with their mouths deeply connected.

Rio was watching them with a big smile and a tear hanging on the edge of her eye. Admiring the sight of the lovebirds and how happy they were.

How happy she was for them.

“They're beautiful together.”

A voice from beside her said, and it was Agatha.

Their shoulders were almost touching because of how close they were.

Rio looked at her, smiling. “They are.”

Chapter Three

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Rio arrived at work on time. It was the first day in months. She woke up feeling great, nothing bothered her all morning, not even herself.

She was sitting in her office, sipping her coffee with a little humming sound coming out of her as she did the work she should've completed months ago.

Rio took a rest as she cracked her fingers and leaned back on the chair. She closed her eyes and let out a soft sigh and her mind drifted to Agatha.

She inhaled deeply as she remembered her—as if Rio forgot her in the first place.

That woman was possessing Rio's whole being since that party.

The way they felt so close yet too far away.

Rio couldn't really understand the strange connection she felt that linked her to Agatha in some way, or why it even existed.

Two days ago, at the party, after they had a few conversations here and there. Shared some laughed and toasts, Rio momentarily had thought Agatha would give her her number at some point in the night, or mention something close to that, or even ask Rio for hers.

But Agatha disappeared after a while and Rio couldn't find her after that. She searched for her with her eyes all evening, but it seemed like Agatha had gone home.

And Rio didn't realize that the last time she looked into Agatha's blue eyes was actually the last time she looked into them.

She sighed again as her fingers hovered over the keyboard. She hesitated as she typed the first letter and looked at the screen. Then as if her fingers started working on their own, she typed Agatha Harkness' name absentmindedly.

Results appeared once Rio clicked enter—photos of Agatha. Very limited information about her. And her artworks. 

Rio looked at Agatha with focused eyes. Admiring her sharp features and how beautiful she looked in every photo. Every pose. And every quality. 

Rio Read the information that the internet allowed her the access to, but there wasn't much—just some articles that barely contained anything. But nonetheless, Rio read every line at least two times.

She scrolled down, viewing the few artworks attached to the article she was reading. She observed them carefully. Each one looked like it possessed a piece of Agatha. They looked like her in many ways.

Rio wasn't practically invested in paintings even though art was a huge part of her childhood, but she could see and feel how every painting screamed Agatha's name one way or another—her art style. The colors she used. The themes. The details every painting held and offered. Even the subjects.

Rio examined each one of them closely. Tying to figure out how and why each one of them was Agatha. Trying to interrupt them.

She noticed the number of portraits of women and the naked bodies. Some paintings felt intimate, flooding with emotions—the angles, the poses, the women themselves. And Rio found herself wondering if those women were Agatha's partners or her muses. Wondering what they meant to her and what she meant to them.

The artist and their muse relationship.

Then she looked at the last painting the article offered a glimpse of. A reproduction of the one Alice had the original copy of in her office. The one that offered a sense of terrifying belonging.

Rio had always loved that painting and felt a kind of connection to it—something she couldn't quite name but still felt. She always took a deep look at it whenever she stepped into her best friend's office.

The painting contained only three dark-shaded colors colors. Black, red and a dark shade of gray.

It wasn't obvious what the picture truly represented, what it was about, or why it filled Rio's heart with a sense of remorse every time she looked at it. That  one, in a way, didn't resemble any painting of Agatha's, it was strangely different. It held something within its strictly limited details, and Rio was curious to discover what was so special—so overwhelming—about that piece. Why it felt personal and even its title was pulling?

Black: My True Love's Heart.

Rio tried to collect the information she had found, but it was merely useless. All she found about it was its title and the date it was displayed. There wasn't anything about Agatha talking about the artwork or some critical article about it. It was like a deep piece and Rio wanted to dig in to feed her curiosity.

The workday had come to an end, Rio gathered her things and stepped outside the office, meeting Alice in the hallway.

“Hey, you,” Alice greeted her with a smile.

“Hey,” Rio replied, mirroring Alice's smile.

They walked in silence for a few minutes until Rio broke it.

“Um, so, I wanted to ask you about something,”

Alice looked at her, offering a look to continue.

“About that painting in your office—Agatha's.”

“What about it?”

“What do you know about it?”

“Not much really. I bought it years ago, because when I looked at it for the first time, I felt like I should have it. The only thing I know is that it's one of Agatha's earliest works, from when she was in college, I believe. She hadn't painted much at the time, yet she refused to show her work to the public eye—epecially this one. But years after her graduation she started publishing her work. I don't really know what it's about—like, the topic of it. I don't think that I actually understand the true meaning behind the painting, but it kept growing in me. It's that kind of piece, you know?

“Oh,” was the only response Rio offered in return. “Yeah, I know.” She said in a low tone, barely audible.

“Yeah, you should ask Lilia, she definitely knows something—if not everything.”

As they continued walking, silence stretched and began enveloping them.

“What were you two talking about, anyway?” Alice asked as she walked beside Rio.

“Who?”

“You and Agatha.”

“Oh, nothing really,” Rio paused. “Lilia introduced me to her.”

“Yeah? Because, I think that woman was looking at you—like really looking at you.” Alice said, enjoyment filled her tone.

Rio stared into space, thinking about what Alice was aiming at.

Agatha wasn't looking at her in any way. Why would she do that?

Moments of silence followed her friend's words as they reached the parking lot. 

“How do you mean?” Rio spoke after a while.

“I don't know, but I felt something was there.” 

“Alice, you're delusional.” Rio replied and got into her car without looking back at Alice.

“We'll see about that! See you!” Alice was practically screaming at that point.

Rio only laughed and started the engine, pretending that Alice's conclusions did not matter.

Because they didn't.

Rio didn't go home, instead she stayed outside the walls of her empty, depressing house. 

She gifted herself a proper meal at a restaurant, considering it a self–date, because she needed that and she had already begun forgetting what real food actually tasted like.

Once at home, she collapsed onto the couch after taking off her shoes and jacket. The dimly lit living room was forcing Rio to close her eyes but after a brief second she forced them open. “No, not today, Rio.”

Then she stood on her feet and headed to the bathroom to take the peaceful, warm bath she deserved.

She wrapped herself in a towel, went back to her bedroom and grabbed the same oversized t–shirt that she always found comfort in wearing.

She sat on the bed. Nothing was in her head to waste the remaining time of the day. She thought about calling Alice so they could go out for some drinks but it was too early for that, instead she called Lilia.

“Hello?” There was some noise in Lilia's side.

“Hey, kid. Nice hearing your voice.”

Rio laughed. “Are you busy?”

“Not really, do you want something?”

“Well, I thought, do you want to go out?”

“Yeah sure why not. Are you hungry?”

“No, not really”

“Okay then, just give me an hour.”

“Alright.”

So she got up, put on some clothes—a t–shirt, a jacket, and trousers, did her hair, applied her makeup on, and went out.

She drove to the café where she was supposed to meet Lilia, and she was already there.

They hugged once Rio approached her, then she sat facing her. 

“How are you doing?” Lilia asked.

“Fine, good. What about you?”

“Great. Here, I got you your coffee.”

“Thanks. And yours?”

“Nope, no caffeine for me darling.”

They talked for a while. About their lives recently though there wasn't much to talk about really in Rio's side. It was a routine. She had been living a routine for a quite sometime.

“I wanted to ask you something.”

Lilia looked at her, “Go on.”

“About that painting of Agatha Harkness, Black: My True Love's Heart. Do you it?”

“What about it?”

“I don't know. I just feel something when I look at it, something strange. I asked Alice about it today, because she has it, you know? But—um, she didn't really know much about it.” Rio paused to take a sip from her drink while looking at Lilia. “She said you might know something.”

“I maybe do.” Lilia said as she searched Rio's face with her eyes.

“What do you know? I'm just curious about it.”

“What makes it curious to you?”

“I—I don't know. It's pulling in a way. Not something specific about the piece—but the painting as a whole.”

“Mhmm. Why I'm not surprised you find that specific piece pulling? Of all Agatha's artwork.”

“Yeah, well, I looked up her artwork... And yeah, that one was different in many ways.”

“You looked Agatha up?” Lilia said with a brow raised in obvious delight.

“Yes—I actually did. For no reason really, I just did.” Rio stammered. She was blushing, caught off guard.

“Well, darling, that painting is really personal to Agatha.” Lilia spoke as she looked outside the window then back to meet Rio's eyes.

“I also felt that pulling toward that painting, it was the reason why I wanted to meet Agatha in the first place. When I asked her about it when we first met years ago, her expressions completely changed upon me mentioning it. She said the painting was never meant to be left exposed to the public's eyes and people' opinions, but she was in deep need of money at the time and a friend of hers offered to display it in their exhibition, that friend was her ex-wife.”

Rio nodded as she sharply listened to what Lilia was saying. Completely absorbed in what she had to offer.

“Agatha didn't talk about the process of painting it or what it meant to her—but she said it's her most spiritual work, and it defines her the most.” 

Rio blinked several times until she realized Lilia has stopped talking.

“Is—is she always that mysterious?”

“Yes, always. She doesn't let anybody in. And her intensity makes her the great artist that she is. Honestly, she's one of the greatest artists I've ever met and worked with.”

Rio felt like she was left with no answers but more questions, and she needed something to quell her curiosity.

They talked for a while about nothing and everything all at once. Every topic led to another until they were out of things to talk about and found themselves asking each other how are they again.

“Now, kid, you should take me home.”

“You didn't come in your car?”

“No, I took a cab, but since you're here, I'm depending on you.”

“So, you're taking advantage of me?”

“Exactly, but I'll cook you dinner.”

“Well, that's tempting, I like it. I'm your chauffeur this evening.”

Rio chuckled as she got up from her chair and Lilia followed her movements.

Once Rio parked the car in front of Lilia's house and was about to step out, Lilia spoke, “Agatha is staying with me for a few days until she finds the place that she wants, she...”

“Jesus, Lilia, why are you telling me this now?” Rio was stunned.

“What? I didn't think it would be a problem,”

Rio sighed, “It's not. It's—it's not a problem, but you could've told me before.”

“I forgot,”

“No, you didn't. You want me to meet her, again.”

“Shut up, Sherlock.” Lilia said as she unfastened her seatbelt. “Anyway, Agatha doesn't live in LA, she settles in Paris, so she's staying with me for now,” Lilia said and got out of the car, slamming the door in Rio's face.

Rio was absolutely shocked because, damn. She wasn't ready for that. 

Lilia knocked on the window telling Rio to get out, and so she did.

Lilia opened the door and motioned for Rio to step inside. She was nervous, an anxiety rush traveled through her entire body and settled in her stomach. Her heart was pounding and her face was red because of the blood that was rushing to it.

They got in and Rio walked ans sat on the couch. There were no signs of Agatha, which was good—because Rio really needed to breathe.

“Do you want something to drink, dear?” Lilia called from the kitchen.

Rio got up and followed her there.

“Oh God, yes please!”

“Here,” Lilia handed her a glass of red wine.

They returned to the living room and sat opposite each other. They were talking about something but Rio's mind couldn't really focus on the conversation, she was thinking about Agatha who still hadn't shown any sign of showing up.

“Are you alright?” Lilia asked with a concerned tone.

“Yeah. Yeah, totally—I just zoned out.”

Then the door swung open. Agatha.

Rio's eyes immediately found hers once she turned around, and Agatha did the same thing.

Because seeing Rio here... a stunned expression overtook Agatha's face for a brief second, but she quickly replaced it with a smile, and Rio noticed that, how could she not?

“I just went out to buy something,” Agatha said as she sat a plastic bag on the table. Speaking with Lilia while looking at Rio.

“Well, Rio's here and she's staying for dinner. You know her.” Lilia said as she also looked at Rio, there was too much gazing on her direction.

“Yes, I do know her.” Agatha smirked. Her voice was laced with delight.

Rio realized that she was also staring, so she sprang to her feet, took a few steps toward Agatha and extended her hand for Agatha to shake.

And Agatha gladly did.

“Nice seeing you again, Rio.” Agatha said. This time she wasn't tasting the sound of Rio's name, she was devouring it with great pleasure.

“Likewise,” Rio replied, then she withdraw her hand from Agatha's hold and sat back down on the couch with a deep exhale that she prayed nobody heard the depth of.

“Excuse me for a few minutes ladies. I'll be right back.” Agatha glanced at Lilia and then back at Rio—her eyes lingered on Rio's face for a few long seconds.

“Take your time darling,” Lilia replied.

Then Agatha walked away toward what Rio assumed was the room she was staying in.

And six minutes later, she returned. Rio counted the seconds of those six minutes—of course she did.

Agatha was wearing an oversized earthy green button–up shirt and black sweatpants. Rio found herself looking at her and Agatha seemed to notice that too.

She looked like she was considering the options, whether to sit beside Rio or Lilia and she ended up choosing Lilia's side.

Rio didn't even know if she should be relieved by her choice or disappointed. She was a mess.

“What do we want for dinner?” Lilia asked, her eyes drifting between them both.

“Anything really,” Rio replied.

“The Chicken Florentine Pasta that you made the other day? I can still taste it, so I'd very much love to eat it again.” Agatha said enthusiastically while looking at Lilia.

“Great, easy and delicious.” Lilia approved.

Rio looked at Lilia then her gaze drifted to Agatha and the open buttons of her shirt. Rio absentmindedly licked her lips at the sight and of course Agatha noticed and threw an unreadable smirk and look to Rio's side.

Rio blushed, feeling her body getting hotter and she tried her best to busy herself with the last few drops of wine that were left in the bottom of her glass.

A minute later, Agatha got up with grace. She went to the kitchen, and came back with two glasses filled with wine.

Agatha walked toward Rio and Rio felt her heart racing with every step Agatha took in her direction until she approached her and was standing in front of her. Agatha looked down at Rio as offered her a glass of wine. And Rio's heart stopped for a heartbeat or two.

Once Rio took the glass and whispered a barely audible “Thank you.” Agatha leaned in front of her, way too close. Rio felt as if time had stopped in that second. She could smell Agatha's intoxicating scent and feel her presence. But Rio didn't dare look down at Agatha's cleavage, instead she closed her eyes, overwhelmed, until Agatha was up again holding Rio's empty glass then she set it on the coffee table with a smirk.

Rio was dumbstruck. Agatha clinked her glass to hers, the moment Rio heard the sound she felt herself being pulled back to earth.

“Cheers.” Agatha said then she took a sip.

Rio swallowed hard as she looked at Agatha's amused eyes.

“Cheers.” she whispered with a pounding heart.

They both looked at each other for a few long, intense seconds as they sipped their drinks.

Brown met blue and assorted with it for a fleeting moment, then Agatha broke the moment by looking away. She walked and sat back down in her spot beside Lilia.

Lilia broke the silence that stretched and embraced the three of them, “Alright girls, I'm gonnr make us dinner, you rest here. Get to know each other.” and with that she left, leaving Rio alone with Agatha.

The silence that embraced them seconds ago started to firmly choke Rio, but Agatha loosened its grip on Rio's throat with that sweet voice of hers, rich with depth.

A one–word question.

“How?”

Rio looked at her, confused. 

“What?”

“You said at the party that what I do suits me. I asked you how? but I didn't get the chance to hear your answer.” Agatha said with a smirk, then she took a sip from her drink. Looking at Rio from behind the glass.

Why did this woman always start her conversations with such intensity?

Because you left. Rio thought to herself, but of course she didn't say that, that was a forbidden territory.

“You've got an incredible memory.” Rio chuckled.

“One of my blessings.”

Rio's mind paused longer than necessary, she couldn't think of anything to start with.

“So, how?”

“It's just, you know, it suits you. I can't really imagine you being in a normal job or anything else.” a pause. “Being an artist, I mean, it suits you. You, you look artistic. I mean, yeah, like a painting.” The words slipped from her tongue and it was tot late. That should have stayed in her head.

Rio realized the words that came out of her mouth and drank what was left in her drink—which was the whole goddamn glass.

“Easy there.” Agatha said, looking at Rio with intensity and something more—so much more.

The empty glass was resting in Rio's hand. She was clenching it firmly as she looked at Agatha.

Their eyes locked and neither of them was ready to look away. As if both of them were daring each other, testing the waters.

Rio felt herself stuck in that moment. In that place. With that woman. Part of her wanted to stay because it felt so good to be stuck with Agatha. But she also wasn't able to handle it—to handle all those unexplainable things she was feeling—the floating emotions, the creeping sensations, the way her heart was tightening, and the charged atmosphere.

The way Agatha was looking at her, the woman's eyes were seductive—an ocean of blue that Rio was willing to be drowned in.

She needed to go somewhere else.

“I'm—” she cleared her throat. “I'm gonna see if Lilia needs anything.”

An escape.

With that, Rio left her spot on the couch and walked toward the kitchen. With every step she took, she felt Agatha's eyes on her.

“Do you need anything?” Rio awkwardly approached. 

Lilia looked at her, “No darling, I told you to rest.”

“I don't really need to.” Rio paused, “I'm gonna be outside for a minute.”

“Are you alright?”

“Yeah, no, I'm fine, I just... need a smoke.”

“Rio Vidal, when did you start smoking again?”

“Five days ago, Lilia Calderu.”

“Kid, don't do that to yourself!” Lilia said, pointing a spoon at her.

“Okay,” Rio chuckled as she left the kitchen and heard Lilia's heavy sigh.

She was heading to the front door when a voice made her stop mid-step.

“Going somewhere?” Agatha asked and she was already on her feet. She finished her glass and set it on the coffee table. Then she wiped the edges of her mouth with her thumb. And Rio—poor Rio—she looked at every motion Agatha did.

“Um, no—” She swallowed. “I just need a cigarette.” Rio said as she took the package out of her pocket.

“Do you mind if I join you?”

“Of course not.”

Rio lit the cigarettes for them and they smoked in silence. The sound of the burning paper filled their ears and the atmosphere between them. The cold breeze added a layer of intensity.

Words were resting on the tips of their tongues. They both desperately wanted to say something to break the silence, to hear each other's voices, but none of them did.

They only looked at each other. Their eyes traced their features as they searched one another's face. Their eyes were filled with intensity, unspoken words, and a hanging promise somewhere.

When they went back inside, Lilia saw them, like if she had caught some kids sneaking in.

“I just want to know why people don't care about their health.”

Agatha looked at Rio and they both laughed without responding.

They were all chatting in the kitchen. Helping Lilia and talking about different things.

Rio found it easy to talk with Agatha if someone else was there with them. Things felt less awkward, and Rio was able to find her own voice.

But every time their eyes met, Rio remained silent, no matter what the topic was or what they were talking about, and it also didn't matter if she was in the middle of a sentence.

Rio was saying something about some college students when her eyes met Agatha's. Rio's heart rapidly pounded and she became quiet all of a sudden. It felt as if Agatha's eyes were a maze and she was lost in them, unable to find the entrance or the exit. She didn't even know which one she wanted to find.

“Rio, are you alright?” Lilia's voice brought her back.

“Yeah, absolutely.” She paused as she took the plates from the counter. “I'm gonna take these.”

She placed them on the dining table. Rio took a deep breathe then turned around to go back to the kitchen and bring the other stuff.

“Are you okay?” This time it was Agatha.

Agatha's soft voice. Agatha's presence. 

“Yeah, just a...” Rio paused as she looked at Agatha's face. She didn't know how to response. Was she okay? “Just a headache.”

“Yeah?”

“Yeah.”

Lilia came to join them with a bottle of wine in her hand.

They sat, and of course Agatha would sit facing her. Of course she would.

“This is so good, Lilia,” Rio said as she took the first bite.

“Exactly! It's so good.” Agatha said in affirmation.

They ate while talking about things here and there, Rio felt good here, between these two.

By the third glass of wine, Rio was drunk.

Lilia left to do something—Rio didn't really know what it was. She wasn't paying attention.

“Why are you staring at me?” Rio asked, it was barley above a whisper. 

“I'm not staring at you.” Agatha said in her normal tone that was laced with delight.

“No, you are. You're staring at me.” Rio insisted, still whispering. 

“And what If I'm really staring at you? Is it a problem?” Agatha replied, matching Rio's whispering tone. She waited for Rio's response with her lips curled up in a smirk.

“Yes,” Rio spoke after a few seconds.

Agatha raised an eyebrow at that and that smirk never left her face. “Yeah? And what is it?”

“It makes me drunk, the way you stare at me... I mean, yeah, this is, um, this is my what? Fifth glass? But—but it's different. It's not the alcohol. I don't think so.” Rio struggled to speak what she was feeling. She leaned back in her chair as she locked eyes with Agatha.

“You're adorable, do you know that?” 

Oh, Agatha was also drunk.

“Yes, I know.” Rio grinned and Agatha laughed at that.

She really was adorable.

“I like your painting.”

“Yeah? Which one?”

“The one that makes me feel guilty and sad.”

“Guilty and sad at the same time? Which one is that?”

“I don't know, Agatha,”

Agatha's eyes widened upon hearing her name coming out of Rio's throat for the first time.

“Tell me which one is it when we're both sober.” She said after a second of silence.

“Will do, ma'am.”

Agatha smiled.

By the time Lilia came back they were wasted. She tried to make Rio stay the night but Rio refused, so Lilia called a cab for her.

Rio grabbed her jacket and stepped outside. It was a cold, dark night. The moon was clouded as its light illuminated through the dark clouds sailing in front of it in the sky.

Rio took a deep cold breath as she closed her eyes and clenched her jacket. The inhale almost sobered her up.

“Hey,” A soft voice from behind made her open her eyes.

Rio turned around and faced Agatha.

Their eyes locked.

Their smiles mirrored 

“Give me your phone.”

Without saying a word, Rio took her phone out and handed it Agatha. 

Their fingers brushed momentarily. 

Agatha wrote her number down, then she gave Rio's phone back. “There, just in case.”

Rio's smile widened as she kept staring at Agatha's gleaming eyes with her half-lidded ones. Taking in her beautiful face and flushed skin.

Then Rio got into the cab and went home.

In case of what?

Was the question she kept asking herself.

Chapter End Notes

I think I'm mischaracterizing everyone

Chapter Four

Chapter Notes

Hey guys!
English isn't my first language so I'd appreciate it if you ignored the mistakes and the flows and stuff, bear with me.

Also, I don't really know where this is exactly going, but I'm going with it. Because I really need to get this idea out of my system or else I'd combust. But don't worry, we're definitely going somewhere (somewhere nice, I hope.)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio stared at the ringing phone. She had called five times already, and it was midnight. The noisy sound disappeared for a few seconds as her phone remained set on the table. She took a deep breath and exhaled through her nose. Rio was furious.

Only seconds later, her phone rang again, illuminating the dark room and disturbing the peace. Because she always disturbed Rio's peace.

6 Missed Calls, 3 New Messages

Rio picked her phone up with gritted teeth. “What the fuck do you want?” She said. Her voice was loud. Echoing in the room.

“Woah, someone's in a bad mood, I see.”

Rio's blood boiled at the audacity of her ex. How dare she?

“What are you? A child? Do you know what time it is?”

“Oh, I know. I'm also aware that you've never been a good sleeper, so I figured you'd be awake.”

Rio's tongue poked the inside of her cheek in an attempt to not say what had came to her mind. She didn't want to argue with her and waste her time and energy.

Her left hand clenched into a fist by her side, her knuckles turned white. Rio was sure as hell ready to kill someone with her bare hands.

“And you didn't take the hint when I didn't respond? What the fuck do you want, anyway?”

“I need to talk to you.”

“About what? What is there between you and me that we need to talk about? Nothing, Jane. Absolutely fucking nothing.”

“Oh come on, Rio. Don't you miss me?”

“I don't. To the point that If I saw your corpse lying on the street, I'd fucking dance on it.”

“Come on baby, don't be like that...”

“I'm not your fucking baby! Don't you ever dare call me that. Ever!”

“Okay, okay, calm down. Just let me talk to you this once,”

“I told you, there's nothing between us to talk about.”

“I know. Just meet me this once—just this time, I want to talk to you.”

“Say it now, I don't have time for you. What do you want?”

“I want to see you.”

“Oh, fuck you.” Rio said and hung up.

She ran a furious hand through her dark hair. Fustration ran through her entire body with her boiling blood.

She wetted her lips and stood in her place for a few long seconds, feeling her head throbbing.

Then Rio drank a glass of water in one swig and went to sit on the couch. Throwing all of her weight on it with a heavy sigh.

“That fucking bitch.” Rio muttered as her head rested in her hands.

She always disturbed her peace. Always dragged her and threw her in the mud. Always found a goddamn way to twist a knife in Rio's back. Always.

And Rio? Rio was a fool because she always let her affect her.

Rio looked at the time, it was just a few hours until the sun would rise. The evening had gone to waste and she hadn't gotten a single minute of sleep. It felt like she was trapped in a box—one that fit her perfectly, so tightly that she couldn't even stretch her body. And that box would close and open from time to time, but now, it was shut rigidly.

No light. No oxygen. Nothing.

She couldn't get out. Something—or rather, someone—was choking her for their own pleasure, releasing her throat whenever they pleased. And Rio just couldn't escape, trapped and suffocated.

Morning came, and the sun rose. The sound of birds singing—or maybe cursing this damn morning. The cold breeze filled the house, the chatter of people could be heard outside. The world was filled with life and it irritated Rio.

Her eyes were burning and the headache was tearing her apart. She had tried to sleep on the couch, but her mind hadn't rested for even a second. At that moment, her only wish was to sleep and sleep and fucking sleep. Maybe sleep and never wake up again. She was feeling like shit, and why? For what reason?

Rio got up from the couch with a sigh—an exhausted and a heavy one—and wearily dragged her feet upstairs.

She stood in the doorway of her bedroom, looking at the bed. God, it looked so comfortable. She couldn't resist it, so she crashed onto the mattress, burying her face in the pillows with a sigh.

Another day, another canceled classes.

She didn't know how many hours had passed when she woke up, confused. She thought she heard a loud knocking at the door so she got up, more irritated than before.

Rio quickly washed her face, then went downstairs, approaching the front door, she opened it. 

And there she was. Who else would disturb and ruin her night and morning but her? No one. Not a single human being had the audacity to do that other than her.

“What the fuck are you doing at my door? Are you fucking kidding me? Seriously?”

“Hello.”

“Oh fuck off.”

“Just let me in.”

“Are you insane? Seriously, what the fuck is wrong with you? Do you want me to call the police?”

“No, Rio, what’s wrong with you?”

Rio laughed, hard and loud as she shook her head in mock disbelief. 

“What’s wrong with me? What’s wrong with me? Are you joking?” She said, unable to believe the irony of the situation. The nauseating impudence of her.

“Let me in. I'm freezing.”

“No, say what you want right here because this is the only chance you get. The only chance that I'm not even willingly giving it to you.”

“Fine.” Jane paused as she looked at Rio's eyes, then her eyes drifted to look behind Rio. “I'm pregnant.” She said as she clutched her jacket tighter.

“Yeah? I'm sure it's not mine.” Rio said with a tired, mocking smile. 

“I wish it was.”

“No, you don't. Cut the crap, Jane, I'm not an idiot.”

“I do.” Jane stepped forward, closer to Rio. “I want to raise...”

“Stay right where you are,” Rio said as she lifted her finger up and pointed at her ex–girlfriend. “Don't you dare playing this shit with me, Jane. You want sympathy? Find it elsewhere. I don't have any for you.”

“Rio. Please. Don't be like this.” Her ex–girlfriend begged as she stepped closer and closer. And with every step she took, Rio felt herself being suffocated.

Rio only looked at her, gritting her teeth inside her closed mouth.

Jane leaned closer as she lifted her hand up in an attempt to touch Rio's face.

“Go fuck yourself.” Rio slammed her hand to the side. “I don't want to see your face in my life ever again. And I mean it.”

“Your really won't give me another chance?”

“To do what? Act like a bitch all over again?”

Her ex–girlfriend didn't say a thing. She just narrowed her eyes and searched Rio's face.

Rio pointed at her, “You...” she paused as she looked at her with disgust. “Leave me alone.” Then Rio stepped inside the house and slammed the door shut in her ex's face.

She leaned her back against the door as she felt her heart tightening inside her chest and stomach was twisting. Rio was desperately trying to steady her breaths. She felt as if she was being chocked. A tight hold wrapped around her throat and denying her to breathe.

“You did well, Rio. You had to do it.” Rio reassured herself through deep inhales and shaking exhales. Counting inside her head to relax her chaotic state.

Rio didn't glance back at the door to see if her ex–girlfriend was gone or not.

It didn't matter. 

She went to the kitchen and made herself a cup of black coffee. A mixture of feelings was running through her, creeping inside. Messing with her head. Just yesterday, she was fine—she was great, even—and as if her ex had sensed it so she came like a storm to ruin Rio's day.

“Pregnant.” Rio muttered, the thought alone made her feel sick. What was her ex expecting? Did she really think Rio was that stupid to the point she thought doing that would work on her?

Rio took a sip of her coffee. The bitter taste stung her tongue as it ran down her throat—but it did wonders to wake her up and calm her head, even if just for a little while. Even if it was temporary, because everything in her life lately was temporary.

Most of the day had passed. The sun began to set, and it was getting darker outside while Rio lazily lay on the couch and wrapping herself in a blanket as she stared at the TV. She wasn't even watching, she just looked.

She went from one panic attack to another during the day, and in between, she regretted her entire life—every decision she had ever made. But worst of them all, falling in love with that woman and letting her ruin her as if she had been blindfolded the entire time. And willingly, she decided to stay like that.

Rio forced herself up from the couch after a battle with herself inside her own head—on whether she should get up or rot on that spot. Because even the thought of putting her feet on the floor and walking seemed exhausting. And she wondered, how the hell she was walking without any trouble most of her life if only thinking about it was that draining?

But she had to get up and get out from here. This house was holding her captive, making her even more miserable than she already was. She had once lived in feigned love, surrounded by these exact same walls. But lately, they've been mocking her—laughing at how stupid she was. Even the walls knew it and witnessed it.

Rio wore some clothes without putting much thought into it, she was in her casual state now. She couldn't waste her energy on something as simple as dressing up. 

Heading downstairs, she caught sight of the wine bottle resting on the kitchen island. So Rio grabbed it and poured herself a glass, then she stared at it for a few long seconds as she slowly swirled the liquid inside. Staring at its state and its color.

A glass filled with wine.

Her mind drifted to Agatha handing her a glass filled with wine as she mysteriously looked at Rio with her hypnotizing blue eyes—with mischief and more. So much more.

And Rio found herself drifting, she closed her eyes as she took a sip of her glass and let out a deep sigh at the taste. Rio licked her lips and inhaled deeply as the dark-haired woman appeared behind her closed eyelids and graced her.

In many ways and for several reasons, red wine reminded Rio of Agatha. Red wine was Agatha. Agatha's eyes. Agatha's smirk. Agatha's mysteriousness, intensity and creativity. It was Agatha, because in a way, that woman was intoxicating. And Rio—poor Rio—she didn't know what else to do other than to drift and daydream with every sip of wine she took. Swriling the drops inside the warmth of her mouth and rolling her tongue around them. As if she was, for the first time, truly tasting it. But that bottle was empty, and it barley filled the glass she was holding in the first place.

She was drifting.

Rio inhaled deeply and the acidic taste of the wine lingered on her tongue as she stared at the glass for a few more seconds. Agatha.

Why was Agatha in her head?

Since when did wine remind Rio of someone? Since when did she think about someone she knew absolutely nothing about? Since when did she yearned the way someone looked at her? Or the way someone's presence made her feel? And the strangest thing of them all—why did she think about Agatha to begin with? Why did Rio think about Agatha almost everyday since she first saw her? 

Rio licked her lips as she studied the glass in her hold. Looking at it closely. Observing what it contained as if she had something personal with it.

Then she poured the rest of her drink into her mouth. Letting the burning sensations take over her senses for a while. To feel something even if it was bitter.

Rio drove in silence, humming along to the song that was playing from the car stereo. A cigarette rested between her fingers and the smoke was swirling in the atmosphere of the car.

She had no idea where she was going. Rio was just driving without any plan in her head. She was just trying to reach and any destination that would distract her from herself even if temporarily. 

Fifteen minutes later, she found herself parked outside a nightclub. Rio wasn't a party person not even a night person in general—at least that was the case for the past decade of her life—so to be there, it felt out of place.

She remembered what she had told Alice days ago: “Out where, Alice? Bars? Clubs? Drinking all night as I try to pour my sadness and suffering into any girl's mouth that would be willing to swallow?”

And she was there.

The Irony of it all.

But at that moment.... At that moment, it felt right.

It felt right to pour her sadness and suffering into someone's mouth—someone who would be willing to swallow. It was the right time to forget herself for a few hours. To lose it all and regain something in return.

Maybe it wasn't the best decision. Maybe it was wrong. But it also felt right—it felt right to make someone else swallow her misery. Even for just a few minutes. To empty herself.

Rio stepped inside and the neon lights welcomed her sight. They were eye-blinding.

The loud music. The heavy smell of alcohol, sweat, and strong perfumes. There were many people. Swaying and dancing bodies. They were chatting and yelling or doing whatever they were doing.

Normally, Rio would turn around and go rot in her house like everyday, but in a way, it was already too late for that.

Half an hour passed, and she was two cocktails in. She was swirling the ice in her glass as she stared at as if she was observing something, that was when a dark–haired woman sat beside her at the bar and her perfume filled Rio's senses. It was admirable.

“Hey.” The woman greeted. Her voice was soft, yet it was laced with heavy delight. Confidence maybe.

Rio turned her face to the side at looked at the woman. “Hi,” she said, then she lifted her glass up to her mouth and drank what was left in it.

“On me,” the woman said with a smile and gleaming eyes as she pushed the cocktail closer to Rio. 

“Thanks.” Rio chuckled awkwardly as she slightly frowned her brow in confusion.

“What a pretty thing like you is doing her?” The woman said with a low tone laced with anticipation as she moved her hair to the side and let it fall behind her back. She lifted her chin up slightly, showing her neck and giving some spotlight to her cleavage where two of her shirt buttons were undone. “All alone...” she said locked eyes with Rio and started deliberately brushing Rio's wrist with her fingers.

Rio poked the inside of her cheek with the tip of her tongue as she met the woman's eyes. She didn't respond, but her lips were curled up by the side with a smile.

“Are you enjoying your time here?” The woman said as she moved her hand up and tucked a strand of Rio's hair behind her ear.

Rio narrowed her eyes at the woman as she finished her drink with one swig.

“Not much,” Rio said as she grabbed the woman's wrist and removed her hand off her face. “Not a fan of unnecessary touching.” She got up from her seat. “Excuse me,” then she left.

As Rio walked away, she thought about going home. This wasn't for her. She knew it was a bad idea. What she thinking? She knew she couldn't do such a thing.

But she found herself on the dance floor, her hips were swaying and her eyes were wandering around. Searching for nothing. Rio just wanted to feel something, and even that something, she didn't know what it was.

Rio closed her eyes briefly as she turned her body to the side. She inhaled deeply then she exhaled sharply as her eyes snapped open and looked forward.

At that moment, with her vision a little blurry, Rio saw her—Agatha—at the back of the crowd with a woman younger than her by her side, they were standing too close to each other. There wasn't any space between their bodies. And Rio saw how Agatha's thumb was stroking the exposed back of the woman as they smiled and looked adoringly at each other with gleaming eyes.

The sight was agonizing and it made her heart clench inside her chest for no specific reason.

Rio stood still in the middle of the dancing crowd, looking at Agatha. Watching her.

The way Agatha's lips curled up in a knowing smirk when that woman whispered something in her ear gave Rio goosebumps. The creeping kind.

The way Agatha's body swayed with the music as she swirled the drink in her hold while her other hand kept touching the blonde's back and pulled her closer to her... Rio couldn't do anything other than stare. Feeling like an observing creep.

She hadn't thought of Agatha as someone who went to clubs with a woman by her side or the kind who enjoyed loud music and blinding neon lights.  But then again, what did she even know about Agatha in the first place? Nothing.

They were strangers to one another, and the way her heart was pounding? That was ridiculous and unasked for.

“You know nothing about her Rio.” She muttered, scolding herself.

As she kept looking at Agatha with wide eyes and a dry mouth, Rio imagined Agatha instead of that dark–haired woman at the bar, or... herself by Agatha's side instead of that blonde woman.

Rio sighed heavily as she dragged her legs. She should've gone home. 

But her eyes lingered. Now that her eyes found Agatha, Rio was unable to look away or to look at anything or anyone. 

Then, as if she sensed the intensity of Rio's gaze, Agatha found her eyes from the distance. And Rio noticed how her eyes widened.

The lights went out for a brief second, then they came back on. Agatha's eyes were still on her. The smirk on her face disappeared and was replaced by a shocked expression. She was stunned by seeing Rio just as much as Rio was stunned by seeing her.

When the music stopped, Rio felt Agatha coming closer to her through the crowd. Almost in a hurry, as if she was being pushed from behind or pulled by something in front of her.

Agatha approached her.

“Rio,” She said Rio's name with a smile as she leaned closer.

“Agatha.” Rio swallowed as she put her hands in her pockets. She had no idea what to do with them.

They looked at each other with gleaming eyes. Searching each other's faces with uncertainty, hoping to find something in each other's features.
