Agatha leaned in to Rio's ear and Rio felt herself melt down. “Let's get away from here?” Agatha whispered the suggestion, her words were warm on Rio's ear and she couldn't help but close her eyes as a shiver ran down her spine.

Rio nodded and they walked away from the noise. She was surprised when the blonde woman didn't follow Agatha, but she was relieved at the same time. That was better.

They sat at the bar and neither of them looked away, as if they were searching each other's eyes for answers. For something to be spoken.

“What are you doing here?” Rio broke the silence. Her tone was sharper than she intended.

“You gotta try LA clubs while you're here, right?” Agatha smiled.

“Yeah, you're right.” Rio said as she reflected Agatha's smile on her face.

Seconds passed between them. And the silence had began to stretch.

“What are you doing here...” Agathapaused as she took a sip from her drink. “By your own?”

“Blowing off some steam.” Rio's eyes drifted from Agatha's eyes, down to her nose, then lower to her lips. She lingered there for a few seconds, until she realized and lifted her drink up to her face to hide the blush of her skin behind the glass.

“Mmm.” Agatha hummed as she looked at Rio.  Sensing that she was more tired than any other time she had seen her. As if it all was visible on her features—and Rio knew everything was visible on her features.

“Are you alright?” Agatha asked, trying to sound as casual as she could to avoid scaring Rio off, but there was real concern behind her words. Rio could hear it.

Agatha licked her lips and Rio looked at them again, then she met her blue eyes and Rio's heart pounded.

She didn't answer. She didn't even know what to say. Was she alright?

“You don't have to answer that.” Agatha said, breaking the uncomfortable silence before it had the chance to stretch.

“No, it's okay. It's just some personal issues.... um, relationship issues.” Rio's eyes kept roaming over Agatha's face. Looking at every possible spot on her face. She was beautiful, her features were striking.

“So... you're not single?” Agatha's tone sounded a bit disappointed as she moved in her seat.

“No, no, I am single.” Rio said as she looked at Agatha. Slowly lowering her gaze to take her in—the glittery mini black dress just above her thigh that she was wearing. The black high heels. Her pale skin. The dark red lipstick that made her lips look delicious. Her silver earrings and necklace. Her dark, wild, wavy hair. And her piercing blue eyes.

Rio stared for a long time. She almost lost herself in Agatha's face and body. She was being pulled into her.

Rio cleared her throat as she looked to the side for a few seconds, when she looked back at Agatha— Agatha's smirk was even wider. Something wicked was behind it.

“What about you?” Rio asked.

“What about me?”

“Your blonde partner back there.”

“Oh, she's not my partner.” A sip. “I'm not into blondes.” She said as she leaned closer and licked her lips.

Rio inhaled deeply and Agatha's scent filled her senses. It made her head spin.

She, helplessly tried to stay still and act cool, but Rio could feel her heart pounding inside her chest and ringing in her ears.

The way Agatha was sitting and facing her so casually while she looked devastatingly gorgeous. It was too much to handle.

The alcohol had finally gotten into Rio's head—and lord, she wanted to kiss those full, covetable lips.

“I—I noticed that in the women in your paintings. They were all... dark–haired.”

“Hmm, you noticed?” Agatha said with a low chuckle.

“Yes I did. I—I've seen your work. Some of your work.”

Agatha didn't say anything she just looked at Rio with that smirk. And it was driving Rio insane.

They stayed like that for a few minutes. Just looking at each other, letting silence embrace them as if all the noise that was surrounding them didn't exist.

“Do you want to get out of here?” Agatha asked as she looked straight into Rio's eyes.

“To where?”

“To my studio.”

Rio looked at her for a few seconds with a smirk, a flushed cheeks and eye gleaming from the alcohol in her system. She leaned in and lowered her voice. “What's in there?” then she pulled back slightly and sipped her drink. Looking at Agatha with a smile visible from behind the glass.

Agatha tilted her head slightly to the side as she narrowed her eyes.

“Well, wine, a few paintings and.... me” Agatha finished her sentence with her lips curled from the side with a smirk.

Rio's eyes were shining in anticipation.

“Okay.” 

“Yeah?”

“Yeah.”

They drove separately to their destination, and Agatha arrived there first. 

Rio pushed the door open and stepped inside. It was a large, open space, filled with both finished and unfinished paintings, art supplies scattered everywhere, large windows, wooden floors, and white walls. The dim lighting added the perfect touch to the studio's ambience.

“This is beautiful.”

“Oh, thank you, it's nothing really but I'm trying to get used to it for now.”

Rio looked around the place and her eyes landed on the pillows and blanket thrown on the floor.

“Do you stay here?”

Agatha seemed to hesitate before answering the question. 

“Not exactly, but I'm trying to not intrude on Lilia, so I stay here some nights. I—I still didn't find the place that I'm looking for.” She said after a few seconds of silence.

Rio took in the space, looked around and a painting caught her attention—the one Agatha was standing in front of.

“Let me get the wine.” Agatha said.

Rio stood in front of it, the painting was only half covered and what she was able to look at made her curious, so without thinking, Rio removed the white sheet and she gasped the moment she saw what she was looking at.

It was her, her face, her features.

Rio was in that painting and she couldn't believe her eyes, so she turned around to look at Agatha who was pouring them two glasses of wine.

“Is...” Rio swallowed. “Is that me?” Rio said as she pointed her finger at the piece.

Agatha looked at her then at was behind her. She walked forward as she kept her eyes locked on Rio's until she handed her the glass and stood beside her.

“Yes.” Agatha nodded as she sipped.

Rio kept looking at her with a pounding heart. Urging Agatha to continue.

Agatha sighed “I just... I couldn't get your face out of my head that night, Rio.” she paused as her eyes drifted behind Rio briefly. “That night at the bar. I tried to paint your face out of my memory.” she licked her lips, hesitation obvious in her features as she looked at Rio—who was still looking at Agatha with a flushed face without even blinking, seeking the truth behind why Agatha was painting her.

“I tried to paint what I remembered. Your face... It just stuck in my head.” 

Rio blinked then she turned her face to look at the painting. “Your memory is really incredible, because this...” she pointed with her finger as she met Agatha's eyes again. “this looks exactly like me,” Rio was stunned as she tried to fathom the situation.

She steeped closer to the painting. Touching it and brushing it gently. She was feeling it on her fingertips.

“I'm sorry about it though.”

“Why? No, Agatha. I like it, a lot.”

“You do?”

“Absolutely. It's perfect. But see,” Rio said, pointing at her face then at the painting, “I think my nose is a bit different than that.”

Agatha chuckled. The sound was low and sweet. “You're adorable.” she whispered as she took a step closer to Rio. “Well, I could paint you much better than that if I could... look at you. See you in front of me.”

Rio exhaled deeply through her nose as she grinned.

She took a sip from her drink.

“I'd love to pose for you.” Rio whispered.

“And I'd love to paint you.” Agatha stepped even closer.

Their eyes connected. A connection that felt eternal—nothing could disturb or ruin it. It felt sacred.

Rio was the one who stepped closer to Agatha and closed the inch of space that was remaining between them.

Their faces were only a few breaths apart. Agatha's scent filled Rio's senses and flooded her with every inhale she took.

Their eyes were searching each other's faces with longing and yearning.

Agatha reached for Rio's cheek, stroking it gently with her thumb, as if she couldn't believe the woman that was standing in front of her.

Rio's eyes kept drifting between Agatha's delicious lips and her hypnotizing eyes—those piercing blue eyes.

Rio leaned into the touch and closed her eyes briefly. A shiver ran down her spine at the sensations. She felt herself floating.

She opened her eyes again to see Agatha's face closer to hers. Noticing how Agatha was leaning slightly every second. 

Their faces were flushed and their eyes were half-lidded and looking with anticipation. Their chests were heavily rising and falling and their breaths were unsteady. Their hearts were rapidly pounding as they leaned even closer—sharing the same air.

“Kiss me,” Rio whispered. She was intoxicated and her voice was barely audible.

Agatha was heavily breathing as she took Rio's glass from her hold and put the glasses on the nearest, available surface.

Without wasting another second, Agatha's lips crashed into Rio's and kissed her with intensity, as if she had been waiting for Rio for decades.

Rio closed her eyes as she felt Agatha's mouth consume her entirely. Devouring her. She allowed herself to lost in the sensations as her thumb kept stroking Agatha's cheekbone. Tender but urgent.

The taste of Agatha was arousing as Rio tasted it. It was sweet and sent shivers down Rio's spine and made her body quiver.

She could feel the heat radiating from Agatha's body, and her own. It was only increasing.

She felt Agatha's tongue moving on her lips so Rio parted her lips to let Agatha's tongue slide in.

Agatha's hand abandoned Rio's face and rested on the back of her neck, urging her closer—as if it was possible to consume her even more. Their tongues tangled inside Rio's mouth, Agatha tilted her head slightly and took Rio's tongue in her mouth entirely, sucking it with hunger and lust. The taste of wine and something elseb it was making Rio's head dizzy. Her body numbed and had begun to lose control, her hand found Agatha's hip and rested there—depending on it to keep her in place.

Agatha was devouring Rio at that point. Eating her mouth out of her face. The intensity of it all—the way Agatha was pouring herself entirely into Rio's mouth, it was overwhelming in the most delicious way ever.

Rio's body was burning, soon to turn into ashes. Desire was scorching as it run through every part of her. Rio tightened her hold on Agatha's hips and pulled her closer. With the force of how she did so, Agatha took a few steps forward causing Rio to take few backward. Her back hit something with a thud and she moaned heavily into Agatha's mouth. The sound vibrated between them and Agatha whimpered as she slid her leg between Rio's. 

Rio felt herself melting in Agatha's hold, and in the middle of it all Agatha immediately pulled backas she removed her hand from Rio's neck and took a step backward causing Rio to take her hands off her hips.

They were panting. Their chest heavily rose and fell as they tried getting air inside their lungs.

Rio looked at Agatha as she put her hands behind her in an attempt to hold on something to keep her standing on her feet.

“God, I'm sorry.” Agatha breathlessly said as she ran a hand through her hair and locked eyes with Rio.

Rio frowned her brow in confusion as she took a step toward Agatha while she was still trying to breathe.

“For what?” Rio met Agatha's half-lidded eyes.

“I'm sorry, for... this.” She moved her hand fingers slowly on her bottom lip. “I lost myself, Rio.” Agatha swallowed.

“Why are you apologizing?” Rio's voice rose. Frustration and bewilderment flickering across her face.

Agatha inhaled deeply as she ran both of her hands in her hair.

“We're both drunk, Rio.”

Their eyes locked.

“I'm sorry, you... God, you should leave. We will—we'll talk about this. I'll see you later.”

Rio's jaw stiffened as she stood straight and looked at Agatha's face.

She stayed silent for a few long, awkward seconds.

“Oh. Okay, cool.”

With that, Rio headed out with hurried steps and left.

Hot, fast tears fell down her face the moment the door was shut behind her. Her vision was blurry and her heart was pounding against her ribcage.

Chapter End Notes

Sorry i guess

Chapter Five

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Rio left Agatha's studio in a hurry and got into her car as tears fell down her face. Fast, scorching and scolding.

She was driving as fast as she could despite her drunken state and blurred vision.

She almost got into an accident because of her reckless driving—or maybe, Rio wanted to get into an accident, because no physical pain could overpower what she was feeling. She was feeling sick in her skin, rotten. The weight of everything had finally caught up to her and it was so heavy to lift. It was nauseating, the way nothing had ever worked out for her. Even what she wanted.

Rio just wanted to reach home. That depressing place was where she wanted to be at that moment, it was her only destination. At least there, she could rot and hate her existence in peace, without being seen.

She lost her way. Her mind was too occupied to think about the right route home. She looked around, reading the signs with narrowed eyes and blurred vision, but she wasn't even able to focus properly. Words were floating in front of her without making any sense.

Her phone lit up several times beside her as time passed without knowing how she could reach her destination.

Her breaths were heavy and uneven. Her heart was racing. Her head was throbbing. Rio felt weak.

She parked in the closest parking lot she could find. She gasped for air as she wiped her face with her hands and grabbed her phone. Her fingers were shaking as they hovered over the screen, trying to enter the password correctly but she failed to do so three times.

Until Lilia called her again and Rio swiped to respond.

“Rio, dear, where are you? Are you alright?”

Rio sucked in a sob.

“Yeah, yeah I'm—I'm fine. I'm out, on my way home. Do you... Did you want anything?”

She said as she ran a shaking hand through her hair. She sounded drunk.

“Honey, look... Agatha told me you're drunk and driving. Tell me where you are, I'll come and get you.”

Rio cried at the mention of Agatha. She covered the phone's speaker as she desperately tried to collect herself. She shouldn't cry at the mention of the woman.

“Rio? Hello? Where are you?”

“I'm here. Look... I'm fine Lilia, I really am. Don't worry.”

She gasped for air with every word she said. Her tears were falling down, her sobs were escaping her throat, she couldn't hold them inside any longer even if she wanted to.

“Just tell me where you are, I'll come and get you, Rio. Just tell me. I'm on my way to Agatha's studio, are you close to there?”

“I don't know where I am.” Rio closed her eyes as she placed her hand above her heart and pushed on her chest with her palm.

“Look around you dear. Turn on your GPS. Tell me anything you can see.”

“I can't, Lilia. I can't. I swear, I just can't do this. I can't see anything. Everything is blurry.”

And there, she lost it all. 

Rio was suffocating. She wanted to scream. To rip her heart off her chest. To black out. She just wanted everything to stop, she couldn't handle what she was feeling. It was too much.

“Rio...”

That wasn't Lilia. It was Agatha.

And the hold on Rio's throat tightened.

“Rio? Hey, do you hear me? Talk to me, yeah? I'm here, just tell me where you are.”

Rio cried. Her eyes were burning and she leaned her head on the steering wheel as she clutched the phone closer to her ear. Listening to Agatha's soft voice that was laced with concern and it made everything worse on Rio. 

“Agatha... Agatha... Agatha...”

Rio finally opened her mouth to say something, but she ended up with whispering the woman's name with a shaking breath. 

“I'm here.” Agatha whispered and Rio felt her tears running faster than before.

She inhaled a deep breath that got stuck in her throat. “I'm not mad at you, you know? Really. So... excuse me, m’lady—I'm gonna hang up.”

And that Rio did.

Truth be told, she wasn't mad at Agatha. How could she be? But the fact that her life had been so awful lately. The way nothing seemed to work out no matter what it was. It all was heavy on Rio's shoulders to hold.

She couldn't even pour her goddamn misery into somebody else's glass. 

Her phone rang several times in her hand as she clutched it tightly in her sweating hold. Her tears were burning on her skin.

It was midnight. Rio looked around one more time, trying to figure out where the hell she was.

Then called Alice, the phone rang for a few seconds before her friend picked up.

“Hello?” She sounded half–asleep.

“Sorry, Alice, did I wake you?”

“Rio? No, no. What's up?”

“Can you come and get me?”

“Why? Where are you?”

“Please, just come and get me.”

Rio stayed inside the car. The parking lot was empty. She leaned her head against the steering wheel, feeling her heart pounding faster than ever. A throbbing sensation grew in her head, a second heartbeat pulsing in her skull and she couldn't do anything about it.

She had to get out twice to vomit her soul out, the nausea in her stomach faded for a few seconds, only to return stronger and more acidic than before.

Half an hour later, Alice arrived there with Jen. Rio was aware that she had disturbed their peace and she made a mental note to apologize about it later.

“Hey, hey, I've got you.” Alice said as she gently helped Rio get into the passenger seat of her own car so she could drive them both home.

Jen followed behind in Alice's car.

Before they got to Alice's house, Rio recognized it.

“No, take me home.”

“I know, I know. I'll take you there in the morning. You need to rest, Rio.”

Rio didn't have the energy to argue, so she just accepted it.

Alice took her to the guest room and Rio immediately crashed onto the bed. Her friend helped her out of her jacket and shoes while Rio mumbled an exhausted Thank you.

“Rest now.”

That was the last thing Rio heard before her heavy, burning eyes closed.

She slept most of the day and only woke up when she heard Alice softly calling her name.

Thank God it was Saturday. 

Rio opened her eyes as she gradually started realizing where she was, and who was standing next to her and feeling her forehead with her hand.

“Hey,” Alice said with that sweet smile of hers—the one that sparked and brightened everything around her.

Rio looked at her for a few seconds, trying to piece together last night's events and why she was here.

“God...” Rio sighed heavily before she sat and leaned her back against the headboard. Her body ached, and her head was throbbing. The headache was the worst kind—the kind where she could feel it from her shoulder blades up to her skull and every nerve in her head pulsed. “Alice, I'm really sorry.”

“Don't apologize Rio. Go wash up and come eat with us.”

And she did. Rio washed her face and went to the dining room, where Alice and Jen were already seated.

She looked at them with guilt in her eyes.

“Guys, I'm really sorry about last night, I didn't mean to—”

“Rio, just get your ass in here. We'll talk about this later.”

She couldn't eat. Her mind was crowded with thoughts and memories, which turned into a nauseating sensation that settled in her stomach.

“Why aren't you eating?” Alice asked.

Rio looked up at her. “I'm not really hungry.”

“Rio..”

“I'm not hungry, Alice,” She said, trying to keep her voice low.

“Okay. How are you feeling?”

“Good, I guess. I just need some coffee.”

Rio noticed the way Alice and Jen exchanged a concerned glance. And she hated it.

“Okay, I'll make you some coffee.”

“No, it's okay Alice. Seriously, I'm fine, I can make my own coffee.”

“Alright, Rio.”

She got up as she took her full plate with her.

Rio just wanted to go home.

 

“Do you want to talk about last night?” Alice asked, sitting on the couch, facing Rio.

“Yes,” Rio said, clapping her hands against her thighs. “I'm sorry about last night.”

“God, Rio, not this. Don't apologize.”

“I have to.” Rio looked at Alice. “Where is Jen?”

“She's working upstairs.”

“Oh. Okay.”

“Rio... I don't want to push you. You know I don't want to put pressure on you. I don't want you to get hurt, Rio. You know that I love you and I'd do anything to you. But... God, Rio. When I saw you last night? I almost didn't recognize you. What happened?”

Rio looked at her friend, unsure how to respond. She always hated looking vulnerable—it embarrassed her. For a long time she had balanced everything, allowing herself to be vulnerable only when she was alone. Moments like these always caught her off guard, and she knew she had to answer at some point. Because it was Alice, it wasn't some stranger who knew nothing about her. Alice was the only person who really knew Rio.

“I don't know Alice. I just lost myself, that's all.”

“Do you know you were saying Agatha's name the whole time on the way home? And you told me you wanted to see her.”

Rio looked at Alice and her heart tightened in her chest. Did she really do that?

“Did she do something to you? Did she hurt you?”

“No, no. She... I was just stupid, Alice. I drank too much last night. I lost my mind and acted like a fucking teenager, that's all. She has nothing to do with this. It was me.”

“Are you sure? I'll talk to Lilia if she did something to you.”

“No. No, Alice. I can handle myself.”

“Rio,”

“What?”

“You don't have to...”

“Please don't say the rest of that.”

“Okay. Okay, I won't. Just take care of yourself. Please.”

“I will. Don't worry about me.”

“Call me, if you need anything.”

“I will. And... I'm sorry about last night, Alice. Tell Jen that I'm really sorry.”

Rii got home. The moment she stepped inside, the familiar atmosphere wrapped around her.

She crashed onto the couch immediately. Letting the piece of furniture take her heavy weight.

Rio looked at her phone, reading that same message over and over again.

An unknown number, but she knew who it was.

Hi, Rio, did you arrive home yesterday? Are you alright?

Agatha had sent it hours ago ans Rio stared at it for a long time. Thinking of a response, then the three dots appeared—then disappeared. Twice. 

Yes, I'm home now. Thank you for your concern.

Formal, but it will do.

How was she supposed talk to Agatha anyway? As a friend? A stranger? Or as someone who had kissed her senseless the night before, only to send her away because she lost herself?

Can I call you?

Rio stared at the message longer than necessary.

Can Agatha call her? Yes or no?

Was it really that simple? Yes or no?

What would they even talk about?

But oh god, Rio wanted to hear her voice—that sweet, soft voice. She wanted to hear what Agatha had to say. 

She needed to listen to her.

Yes. It's okay, I don't mind.

Only seconds later, her phone rang.

“Hi, Rio.” Agatha greeted.

Rio sensed something in her voice. It was lower, almost a whisper, like she was afraid of revealing what her voice really sounded like.

But her voice was enough to make Rio sit up straight.

“Hi.”

An uncomfortable silence stretched between them. Rio could hear Agatha breathing—her breaths uneven. She waited for Agatha to say something. Anything. The silence was killing her.

“Are you okay, Agatha?” Rio found herself asking. She was worried about Agatha—a woman she knew nothing about—yet, she could feel her. She could feel her hesitation. Could picture the look in Agatha's eyes at that moment. She could feel Agatha running through her veins and it was a strange, unreasonable sensation. Or maybe it was just the hangover.

“I'm fine, are you?” Agatha's voice was deeper now.

Rio thought about the question. Something inside  urged her to tell Agatha everything. To talk to her for hours and hours, but she couldn't, she just couldn't do that.

“I'm better now. I mean... yes, I'm good. Don't worry.”

“Oh, Rio...” 

Agatha sighed her name, and a shiver ran down Rio's spine as the hairs on her body stood to their end. She found herself unable to coherent words. Hearing her name laced with exhaustion, wrapped in a sigh, and out of Agatha's mouth did something to her—it sent her heart racing. 

She placed a hand on her chest. She had felt this kind of heartbeat before—during panic attacks—but she wasn't panicking. Rio was melting, becoming one with the couch beneath her.

“What is it? Goddamn it” Rio muttered to herself, pressing her hand harder against her chest.

She wanted to say something to Agatha. Anything.

“I like the way you say my name.”

No. Goddamn it. That wasn't it.

Rio smacked her forehead. It was too late.

“I like how it sounds in my mouth. I like your name, Rio.” Agatha said, breathing through every word.

Her mouth...

Rio had tasted her mouth yesterday. How sweet it was—the way Agatha's lips had taken hers on a journey she wouldn't forget no matter what. The way Agatha kissed her with heat and hunger. She devoured her, left her breathless and speechless.

Rio desperately wanted that mouth on hers again.

The memory of the kiss flooded her and made her mouth water.

“Rio, I'm sorry. I shouldn't have let you leave like that yesterday.” Agatha broke the silence.

“It's—it's okay, Agatha.”

“No it's not. Please, just let me finish.” Agatha's tone was firm but it was still soft and concerned. 

She sighed heavily. “I'm sorry for being such a dick. You didn't deserve that. I hope I can make it up to you.”

“Agatha, it's really okay. I appreciate it, but look—it wasn't your fault. I kinda of rushed into it.” Rio paused for a moment, “I just haven't been myself lately, so... it has nothing to do with you.” She said as she ran a hand through her hair.

Neither of them spoke for a while, just listening to each other breathing. As if they were afraid of saying something. Of stepping inside. Of trespassing on each other's space.

Sitting in silence, knowing Agatha was on the other end of the line gave Rio a strange sense of safety—of presence. Just the thought that Agatha was actually there, made her heartbeat slow in a way she hadn't experienced before.

“I'd like to see you. I want to see you,” Agatha finally said, after what felt like an eternity.

“I'd like to see you too,” Rio responded immediately, without thinking much about it. Her heart pounded faster, sending a delightful sensation through her—one she hadn't felt in ages.

Rio was nervous. She shouldn't have agreed to see Agatha.

Seeing her after last night, after that kiss...

And God, her memory had never been kind to her, because now she remembered the nonsense she had mumbled in the car—whispering Agatha's name like a mantra through the phone.

Was she that teenager in Call Me By Your Name?

Why was she acting like a lovesick girl with a forbidden crush that will lead to a doomed, known fate?

She needed to pull herself together. She was a grown woman for god's sake.

Rio has kissed women before, plenty of them— whether she was drunk or sober, mourning or rejoicing.

But none of them had felt like Agatha. No pair of lips had tasted like hers—that heated, drunken kiss that lasted for... God, she didn't even know how long it even lasted. But it felt like eternity. It made her feel alive in a way she couldn't comprehend.

Everytime her mind drifted back to the memory of last night, an electric wave swept through her entire body. 

She stared at her wardrobe for a long time, trying to pick something that felt right—something that wasn't too much, but not too little.

She settled on a white button–down blouse with a slightly open neckline, a gray jacket, and a high–waisted gray trousers with a black belt that had a golden buckle. Gold hoop earrings. And that necklace.

She stared at her reflection in the full length mirror that will do, she told herself.

Rio drove to the place where she was supposed to meet Agatha. She parked her car and stayed in it for a while, preparing herself to see Agatha again—to meet her eyes.

Once she got inside, she couldn't see Agatha anywhere, thinking she must have arrived early. 

She looked around, searching for the woman.

“Do you have a reservation, ma'am?” 

Rio looked at the man, she was about to answer with a no and leave,

“Yes, Agatha Harkness,” a voice from behind her said. “Sorry for making you wait.”

Rio turned to look at her, and there was a smile on Agatha's face—one she hadn't seen before. It was stripped of all the usual teasing and intensity. It was... beautiful to look at. To feel.

Rio kept looking at Agatha as she smiled in return. Mirroring her.

An oversized beige suit, a high–necked top, golden necklace and earrings—she looked gorgeous. Ethereal.

They held each other's gaze for a moment before Agatha led them toward their table. As they walked, Agatha's hand briefly rested on Rio's waist before she pulled it away. Rio noticed the rush in the way Agatha had pulled her hand, she looked at her, but Agatha didn't look back.

They sat, facing each other. Their eyes spoke volumes while their tongues remained tied. 

 

“You look beautiful,” Agatha said before taking a sip of wine.

“Thank you.” Rio felt herself blusing, something that did not go unnoticed by Agatha.

“You look beautiful. Like, really beautiful.” Rio said as their eyes locked.

“Thank you, Rio.”

They spent the evening talking about themselves. Sharing fragments of their lives but nothing too personal. Nothing deep.

Rio felt safe in Agatha's presence, as if she were embraced—even though Agatha hadn't touched her at all.

“Okay, now I'll ask you a question that you have to answer and you'll ask me something in return,” Rio said, grinning widely. “Deal?”

Agatha hesitated for a brief second. “Deal.”

“What's that painting about?” Rio asked, watching Agatha's face, her features were so calming to look at. “Black: My True Love's Heart.”

Agatha stopped in the middle of taking a sip from her glass as soon as she heard the title of the painting Rio was asking about. And just as Lilia had said, her expressions changed into something unreadable—something Rio hadn't seen before. Something she couldn't read.

Agatha set her glass down as she looked at Rio's face, searching for something there. She remained silent for a while, and Rio waited eagerly.

“That painting is... personal,” Agatha said, pausing to drink what was left in her glass. “I painted it in college. I was a mess back then. Didn't know what I was doing or why.” She was looking at Rio then her eyes drifted away, staring at the empty glass in front of her. “I had issues back then—all kinds—but mostly with my... ah, my mother. I stayed the worst version of myself for years because of her. I never knew what I should do. I always aimed to please her because I thought I'd be worth something if I could change her opinion about me—the way she saw me. But it didn't work out. Unfortunately or fortunately... honestly, I don't know.” She let out a chuckle, laced with awkwardness.

Rio's eyes remained locked on her as breathed slowly, listening to every word that left Agatha's mouth.

“She always said I had a black heart—unloveable, worthless—a sack of shit if you will. That the only person who could ever love me was someone with a heart to match mine—a black one. So, the painting... I don't really know how to talk about it. I—I never thought I'd talk about it to anyone.”

Then, she looked into Rio's eyes as if something in them encouraged her to keep talking, she resumed.

“I never even finished it. I was an addict at the time, a complete mess—whatever you want to call it, really. Half of the time I wasn't even aware I was painting it. So, ah... yeah. A few months after that, my mother committed suicide, leaving nothing behind but her will and a letter describing how I made her life a living hell.”

Agatha chuckled again, and Rio looked at her—an I am sorry resting on the tip of her tongue.

“Yeah. So, I completed the painting after her death. I felt guilty, yes, but after she was gone, I was free—like I was breathing for the first time. I don't know if that makes me sound like a horrible person.” An awkward laugh followed that as Agatha refilled their glasses. “So, you could say the first half of the painting was me being held captive in a nonexistent cage, and the other half... me being free, searching for who I really am.” Agatha's eyes locked onto Rio's again.

When Rio realized Agatha had finished speaking, she placed her hand over Agatha's. “I'm sorry,” she said, gently stroking Agatha's knuckle with her thumb.

Agatha looked down at their hands, then back into Rio's eyes.

“It's okay. It was a long time ago. Sorry for trauma–dumping and ruining the night.” Agatha laughed.

“No, you didn't ruin the night,” Rio said softly, continuing to brush Agatha's hand gently. “I want to hear everything and anything about you, Agatha.”

Agatha's eyes widened slightly. She remained silent for a few seconds before tilting her head to the side with a smile.

“Is it the painting that makes you feel guilty and sad when you look at it?” She asked, smirking with amusement.

“Did I really say guilty and sad?” 

“Yes, you did.” Agatha said, still smirking.

“Well, my choice of words was awful. But in my defense, I was drunk.” Rio smiled. “It makes me feel much more than that, everytime I look at it. At some point, I started avoiding Alice's office just so I wouldn't have to see it and get flooded with emotions.”

“Alice has it?”

“Yeah, she does.”

And Agatha hummed in response.

“But I like it so much,” Rio admitted as she absentmindedly rolled Agatha's thumb ring. It felt natural—until she realized what she was doing and quickly pulled her hand away.

“My turn,” Agatha said. She was silent for a few seconds, only searching Rio's eyes with hers.

She inhaled deeply. “How are you, Rio?”

Their eyes locked.

“How do you mean?”

“How are you, Rio?” Agatha repeated the same question, but this time, her tone was softer than Rio had ever heard. She wanted to tell Agatha to change the question, to ask something else. But she didn't. She couldn't.

“I don't know.” 

“You don't know?” Agatha leaned closer in her seat as she put both of her hands on the table.

“I honestly don't know.” Rio admitted sincerely.

“Okay.” Agatha smiled softly.

Rio was shocked. She had expected her to push for an answer, to dig deeper. But Agatha didn't. And somehow, that—exactly that—made Rio open her mouth again and speak.

“I mean... what would you do if your ex–girlfriend showed up at your house to tell you that she's pregnant and kind of want to raise the kid with you?”

Agatha looked at her, absolutely stunned. She raised her brow, “What?” she said, her tone was laced with disbelief.

“Yes, she did that. Yesterday.”

“Yesterday? Is that why you were at the club?”

“Yes.”

“God, I'm sorry, Rio.”

“Yeah, she's a bitch.”

“She sounds like one.”

“Yeah. I mean, she cheated on me with a dude and then made it seem like I was the monster somehow.”

“I'm sorry, Rio.” Agatha said, her tone had changed. It was sincere and concerned. 

“No, it's okay. Really.”

“No. You were already having a bad day, and I only made it worse.”

“How could you have known? You didn't know, Agatha. And also, you've apologized enough already.”

This time, Agatha took Rio's hand in hers and squeezed it gently—an unspoken I'm sorry.

They remained silent, looking at each other. Memorizing every feature. Savoring every detail. And saving second of their presences.

“I like your nose.” Rio said out of nowhere.

“You like what?” Agatha chuckled.

“Your nose. I like it.”

“Well... Thank you.” Agatha blushed.

“It's really beautiful. I want to touch it.”

“What?”

“May I touch it?”

“Rio...”

Rio looked at her with the best puppy–dog eyes she could muster.

“You—okay, you can touch it.” Agatha licked her lips as she leaned in slightly. Rio did the same as she grinned. Not caring where they were or who might be watching.

Their eyes met.

Rio lifted a finger up and touched Agatha's lips first. Agatha's breath hitched and her lips instinctively parted slightly.

“That's not my nose, Rio.” Agatha was breathless.

“I know.” Rio smiled. “But you wouldn't have let me touch them if I had said I wanted to.”

Her index finger trailed higher, sliding from the bridge of Agatha's nose down to the tip.

“I would,” Agatha mumured.

“What?” Rio said, her eyes flickering between Agatha's lips and her eyes. 

“I would've let you touch them if you had asked.” 

Rio fell silent, she hadn't expected that.

She just looked at Agatha's lips. Then back into her eyes, repeatedly.

And Agatha just looked at her as she let her do what she wanted.

Their evening came to an end as they stepped out of the restaurant. The night breeze embraced them both.

“Thank you for tonight,” Rio said.

“Thanks to you.”

They stood there for a while as if neither of them wanted to leave.

“Do you want to... um, come to my place?” Rio asked, fidgeting with an imaginary thread on her jacket. 

Agatha pulled her blazer tighter on her body and looked at Rio with gleaming eyes.

“Okay.”

They drove separately to Rio's place, arriving at the same time.

Rio unlocked the door, stepped inside and Agatha followed her.

The place was completely dark, so Rio hurried to turn the lights on. 

“Do you want something to drink?”

“Yes, anything would be fine.”

“Okay, make yourself comfortable.”

Agatha just walked to the couch and sat down, wandering around with her eyes.

Rio returned with two glasses of red wine and the bottle in her other hand.

“I like your garden,” Agatha said as she took a glass from Rio's hold and said a soft “Thank you.”

“Thank you.” Rio grinned as she sat beside Agatha, leaving a small gap between them.

They talked about work and other things, as if trying to distract themselves from the fact that they were sitting beside each other—denying the weight of the situation as if that would change the fact that it was heavy.

Then, Rio had just enough wine to summon the courage to ask.

“May I touch your lips now?”

Agatha smiled and nodded as she licked her lips.

Rio leaned in, only a few inches between them. She raised her index finger and traced Agatha's lower lip and Agatha's lips parted instantly. Her breath hitched and her pupils dilated, blown widely.

Rio brushed her bottom lip, then the upper one, noticing how Agatha was holding her breath because of how close they were.

“Can I kiss you now?” Rio whispered, still tracing her finger over Agatha's lips left and right.

“You better do.” Agatha sighed as she cupped Rio's face and pulled her closer. Their warm breaths mingled. The closeness made Rio's mouth water as heat spread through her body.

Rio's lips crashed against Agatha's and they both moaned at the first taste of each other—a taste Rio could already see herself becoming addicted to.

The kiss started slow and soft, but within seconds, it turned hungry, filled with lust and untamed fire. Agatha bit Rio's bottom lip, and Rio moaned in response and parted her lips slightly. Agatha didn't waste a moment, her tongue slipped into Rio's mouth and the kiss deepened. It was intense and hot, and Rio could feel the desire surging through her veins.

Agatha's hands left Rio's cheeks, settling firmly on her hips. She pulled Rio closer and closer, until Rio was practically sitting in her lap. They didn't break the kiss for a second; it only grew more feverish, more desperate. Agatha's fingers traced patterns over the fabric of Rio's clothes while Rio's hands clung to Agatha's shoulders. 

Only seconds later, when oxygen became a necessity, they pulled back slightly and broke the kiss. Their faces remained a heavy breath apart. They were breathless. Their chest rising and falling. Their breaths heavy. Their eyes blown widely and their skin flushed. Agatha cupped Rio's face again and pressed a kiss to her forehead.

“You're so beautiful. Do you know that?” Agatha mumured then she leaned in and pressed a soft kiss to Rio's forehead again.

Rio only smiled and blushed in response as she tried to catch her breath.

She settled back onto the couch and was already missing Agatha's mouth on hers. Agatha's hands on her body. 

“I'll be out of town for a few days,” Agatha said. “There's an art gallery I need to attend.” She paused, looking at Rio. “You can call me.”

“I will.”

Agatha leaned in again, kissing Rio softly before she brushed their noses together.

“I should go now.”

Rio didn't protest she just leaned forward and kissed Agatha in response.

They hugged at the door, holding on for a moment longer. And then Agatha left.

“Take care.” Rio whispered—long after Agatha was gone.

Chapter End Notes

Are we going fast or slow or what? Are we even going in the first place?

Chapter Six

Chapter Notes

Obviously, I listened to Isobel by Flower Face on repeat while writing this.

You’ll never learn to lie, say your French goodbye
Stay up in the blue glow, try to rearrange
All your insecurity and encyclopaedic rage
Do you still think you’re a killer,
O r that you could be if you tried?
Always thought that you could do it if you couldn’t see their eyes


Do you still wake up reaching for an empty space?
Do you start to miss your sadness when it goes away?
Do you wish your parents gave you someone else’s name?
Do you scratch another line out for the same mistakes?

The lyrics of the song hit her harder than any time  before. She had listened to this exact song several times, but it felt as if this was the first time she truly heard the lyrics and realized how much they describe her—how much they mirrored her.

Rio had never been a fan of sorrow, of living whilebeing embraced by misery and agony.

It wasn't her.

Rio Vidal was optimistic by nature, a transport of delight. Even in the hardest moments of her life—which were many—she always managed to remain the same version of herself, always with a smile on her face. But in the past couple of years, it was as if every bit of sadness she had once refused to embrace had caught up to he and made her vulnerable, emotionally and physically.

She certainly knew pain and sadness and had experienced them, hell, her whole life's foundation was built on tragedy, but she had always managed to control it—until now.

Are you right back where you started,
Or have you found another way?
Sugar rush, a stranger’s backyard, the devil’s holiday.

She was sitting in the garden, amidst the stillnes of the evening, just as always, with a bottle of vodka by her side. She was desperately trying to use the greenery to cleanse her thoughts—to clear calm restless head, to organize the chaos.

To breathe.

It was her birthday. The sky was painted with stars and sailing clouds. It was midnight, the cold breeze—and her thoughts—forced tears to form at the edges of her eyes. But she refused to let them go.

Rio didn't wish that she had never been born— not exactly—but it would have been nice to have good birthday memories. That day had always been a reminder of her misfortune. A reminder of how naïve she was for letting people in.

Once someone showed her the slightest bit of attention. Once someone showed that they cared. She always hurried to open the door and let them in.

She didn't celebrate this day, Rio hated her birth day and thought of it as reminder to how cursed she was.

Whenever she thought about it, what was there to celebrate anyway? Nothing deserved in her life deserved a celebration—especially not her existence.

The happiest Birthdays—and the only happy ones—were from her childhood. Whe she was surrounded by people who gave her unconditional love and care. She didn't care about the world back then, when she used to think about her next birthday during her current one.

Her teenage years were devoid of something called birthdays, not because she was a moody teenager, but simply because there was no one there to celebrate with.  She didn't realize back then that once she blew out the candle on her twelfth birthday, there wouldn't be any happy candles after that one. No more innocent, childish wishes.

During college, her friends always insisted on throwing parties for her, celebrating the undeserving. She appreciated it and all, but she always felt as if she was being forced into acknowledging it. Into accepting it.

By the following years, her birthday became the miserable reminder that it was now—something she couldn't bear to think about.

You watch yourself in fragments, amongst the leaves,
And you conclude that you never were much more t han a reflection in a pool

Her last birthday was a complete disaster—she was laying in bed, waiting her ex–girlfriend to come, who was late and completely wasted as always, not giving a fuck about Rio's existence.

It started as a reproach, turned into a loud conversation, developed into a heated argument, escalated into a fight, and ended with her ex's uncontrolled anger and violence issues, while using the victim complex as an armor.

Rio's birthday ended with her walking alone around the city with a scar on her elbow and tears hanging in her eyes, wishing to be released.

Do you still wake up wrapped around an empty space?
Do you only know the good days once they’ve slipped away?
Do you wish that he would call you by another name?
Do you pour another drink out for the same mistakes?

“Hell yes, I do.” Rio said, talking to the lyrics of the song as she reached for the bottle beside her and made a toast with the air.

Thinking back, she realized she was stupid. Wasn't she?

An idiot, a total loser, and somehow a bitch with attachment issues. It shouldn't have gone that far. She should have dumped that bitch two years ago, spat on her and walked away. She should have left the city and found a new place. She should have achieved her dreams. She should have lived—only she didn't. And that was why she always felt guilty—guilty because she ruined herself for nothing. Because she wasted time she could never get back.

Thinking about how things could have been different if she had done things differently. She wouldn't be a mess now if she had refused to get hurt for the sake of herself. She wouldn't be a fragile, depressed little thing if she hadn't put someone above herself—because not a single son of a bitch deserved to be at the top of her priorities.

Yet, she allowed it.

Rio looked up at the sky, it looked reae beautiful.

Oh to be a bird. To be a cloud. A star. Or even a bit of smoke rising up with no return.

She got inside, looked at the dim lit space and sighed—a long, low and a spent-out sigh.

Rio went upstairs and lay on her back, looking at the ceiling. She hought about texting Agatha—she thought about it since Agatha had stepped out of her house, but she didn't dare to do it.

Every time she reached for her phone and looked at Agatha's contact, something would strike her heart, making it pulse faster than ever.

The feeling was was sweet at first, but it grew to actually hurt her. The way her heart pounded the moment she looked at Agatha's name on her phone was overwhelming by all means.

It wasn't supposed to be like that, but it was as if she couldn't do anything about it. She was out-of-control.

Everything in her ached for the woman, longing to hear her voice. The delightful sensation she felt from hearing the Agatha's voice were something she had never experienced before—not once in her four decades of living. And it felt hazardous. Whenever Rio thought about it, it made zero sense in her head—the way she was drawn to the woman was scary. It held an unbearable amount of risk, with uncountable layers of emotions she couldn't bear nor handle.

As Rio closed her eyes, trying to sleep, a dark-haired woman appeared behind her closed eyelids.

Her face was vivid, as if she were standing right in front of Rio and Rio so desperately hung onto the image of the Agatha and shut her eyes even harder. She didn't want to open them, so the Agatha wouldn't leave.

God, it would have been so good if Agatha was here—if only Agatha was here to kiss her, to call her name, to tell her how delicious it tasted in her mouth and to tell her that everything was fine—that it would be fine because she was here beside her. But Agatha wasn't and Rio was delusional.

Her phone buzzed by her side her but Rio ignored it—only to open her eyes immediately at the second buzz.

As if Rio had summoned her, Agatha reached for her with a message. Rio's heart pounded harder in her chest, and heat traveled through her body once she saw the woman's name on the screen.

Hi, Rio.

Are you awake?

Rio looked at the messages. It maybe didn't mean much, but Agatha had reached for her first. And by the gods, it definitely meant something.

Yes, I am. 

Rio hit send and stared at the ceiling again. Probably Agatha couldn't sleep either, because it was already 4 am in where she was.

Can I call you?

God, this woman.

Call me, just call me. Let me hear your voice. Let me listen to you breathing for hours and hours. Let me be drowned in the sweet ocean of every word you speak, sank in the depth of every tone.

No, that was too much. Rio wouldn't say that. She only thought about it, and it ate her from the inside. It made her lose her sanity—or what was left of it, anyway.

Yes, of course.

And Agatha called. 

Rio cleared her throat before she swiped and answered.

“I've missed you.”

Was the first thing Agatha had said and it made Rio's heart stop for a heartbeat or two, only to come back again, beating faster, threating to escape her chest.

Rio remaind silent. Her grip on the phone was tightening and she was almost gluing the device to her ear.

Her eyes squeezed shut. She could hear Agatha breathing, and Rio searched everywhere for how to respond to something like... that. But nothing appeared in her head. Nothing could even work.

For god's sake, how are you supposed to respond to something like that?

“God, Rio...”

There it was—her name wrapped in a sigh, laced with dripping sweetness.

Rio's name had never sounded more beautiful.

The way Again called her name, it was almost unbelievable. She wanted her name to be called by Agatha again, and again, and again.

Rio was aware that she was silent—not a single word was coming out of her mouth—but, on the other hand? Her physical state was chaotic. Heat was radiating from her, she could feel an actual fireball resting in her stomach. A sheen of sweat appearing on her forehead. Her eyes were shut, and the only thing she could hear was Agatha's breathing. She could sense the way Agatha was waiting for her to speak. To say anything.

“Please, let me hear you voice.” Agatha said and Rio almost passed out from the heat that was only increasing with every word Agatha said.

The desperation in Agatha's tone was too much to handle and too good to reject.

“Do you know—do you know what you're doing to me?” Rio finally managed to speak. She probably gathered every bit of courage in her body to form the question and ask it. And of course, with the help of the alcohol in her system.

Was Agatha really unaware of what she was doing to Rio? Did she really couldn't hear how Rio's heart was pounding? How she was torturing Rio with doing the bare minimum? Or had she just decided to ignore that and just do whatever she wanted? 

“Do you know what you're doing to me?” Agatha repeated Rio's question, sounding even more desperate than before.

“Why didn't you call me? You said you would.” Agatha asked, her tone was laced with disappointment and something softer. Rio could sense it, and god, it did something to her. The way Agatha was talking straightforwardly with her. Transparent, saying everything with that intense confidence. Saying what Rio wasn't able of saying. She was even afraid of thinking about it let alone say it out loud. “Say something, Rio.”

“I don't know what to say. God, I wanted to call you, but I just....”

Agatha heavily sighed. “I've never heard a sweet voice like yours, Rio.” Agatha interrupted Rio's already failed attempt to explain why she hadn't called.

The way she ended almost every sentence with Rio's name did something to Rio. The way she said her name differently each time, but it also held the same similarity, the same taste, the same amount of heat. It made Rio's body ache.

“You can't sleep?” Agatha asked, interrupting Rio's train of thoughts.

“No,” Rio responded with a sigh.

“Something in your head?”

The way she asked it—a mixture of pure concern laced with amusement and something else—something out of reach.

“Plenty of things actually.” Rio responded sincerely.

Something was pushing her to talk because the safety that Agatha provided couldn't be an illusion. It was real and Rio could feel it everywhere, even in the air around her.

“Do you want to talk about them?” Agatha asked, then she sighed softly. And god, how Rio wanted her to sigh right on her neck. “You can talk about anything you want, Rio. And I'll listen to you. Or, I could talk until you fall asleep.... Just name it, and I'll do it.”

“Please, talk to me.”

It was a desperate plea. It was need and yearning.

And Agatha did as she promised—talking with that deep voice of hers, embracing Rio with every word. She tried to make small talks whenever Rio fell silent.

They talked about a few things. The conversation felt more intimate, more personal than the one they had shared before. Rio learned a few things about Agatha—things she would definitely think about on a daily basis.

Like how Agatha liked reading books, the way she had that nerdy hyperfixation on witchcraft, how she liked her coffee, her experience growing up in a religious household, how purple had become her favorite color, and how once she almost died because of a dare challenge.

The more Agatha talked, the wider Rio's smile grew, and the heat in her body increased. She was floating, lost in Agatha's words, in the way Agatha described things, showed interest in more than a way and spoke flawlessly with that demanding confidence. Agatha was a goddess of a woman, and Rio was very much aware of that fact. 

“When is your birthday?”

Agatha asked, and Rio felt her heart sink, thinking about whether she should say that her birthday was last month, or the next one—or even that her birthday was in a thirteenth month that obviously did not exist. It sounded foolish in her head, childish even.

What would happen if Agatha knew it was her birthday? She wouldn't care anyway. Why would she? They were still strangers to one another after all—a stranger Rio would kill for.

“It's... today.” Rio held her breath and squeezed her eyes shut. Damn it, woman.

“Happy birthday, Rio.” Agatha sighed. “Happy birthday you bewitching, captivating human being.”

Rio felt the way Agatha was breathing after saying every word. The way her voice sounded so close, in that slutry deep tone. And Rio was aware of how her body reacted to every word. The way she sighed, feeling her heart pounding, her stomach turning into a heat pool. The way the words hit every pulse point in Rio's body. It was insane even, the way she couldn't breathe once the words reached her ear.

“I wish I was there, with you right now.”

“I wish you were with me. I want you here with me, Agatha.” Her intention was to say that as a low murmur to herself, as a soundless thought in her head, but somehow she said it aloud, and she felt the way Agatha's breath hitched at her confession.

And somehow, the silence stretched between them. Not a single word was spoken, but it felt safe, as if you were sitting with someone you knew you could be yourself with—someone who would understand you with just a look, and in their case, with just an intake of breath or a tone of voice.

“What do you believe in, Rio?” Agatha's voice returned after moments of silence, and the question felt different in a way.

What did Rio believe in?

She took a deep breath before speaking, as if holding her thoughts inside. Afraid they would shatter and she'd be left with nothing.

“If you had asked me this a while ago, I would have been able to answer it, gladly,” a sigh. “I used to have faith in lots of things, you know? Because I had that kind of hope—the kind that made me save what I have now in order to have something later. And I lived with that for a long time. But lately, that faith shattered. I feel that I no longer have faith in anything, I no longer believe in something, and I can't even recall what I once believed in. It's as if everything was nothing but an illusion, and it disappeared once I regained my consciousness. But god, I don't even feel conscious.” Rio pressed her fingers into her eyes to release some tension. “Does that make any sense?”

“It actually makes all the sense in the world.”

And silence fell upon once again, until Rio spoke.

“And you, do you believe in anything?”

Agatha took a few moments to respond. And Rio was carefully listening to her breaths that became softer.

“I never really believed in anything. I always... doubted. Always had the sense that something didn't sit right. That things should make sense to me before I could acknowledge them, let alone believe in them. But lately... I'm starting to believe in something that doesn't really make sense. And whenever I try to put sense into it, it remains the same.”

“Yeah? And what is that?”

“I can't even name it, Rio.”

Rio rested her head on the pillow, phone still glued to her ear, listening to everything Agatha was saying. Every little thing.

“Did I bore you yet?” Agatha asked, and Rio closed her eyes.

“Never.” Rio breathed the word—it was a whisper that held so much weight. “When will you come back?” 

“Probably tomorrow.”

She wanted to tell her to hurry up, to come sooner so she could see her. But Rio wasn't in that position, to tell Agatha to come back and embrace her, to feel her presence.

Rio's eyes remained closed. She was so still, relaxed even. She heard Agatha calling her name and managed to mumble a few words. She was drifting between consciousness and unconsciousness when she heard a low, sweet laugh escape from Agatha—and she smiled.

“Sleep well,”

 

When was the last time had she really talked with someone for hours? Never—Rio had never done that before.

When was the last time she had falling asleep with a smile on her face? A long time ago, or maybe never. Debatable.

When she woke up later, she felt good. It had only been a few hours of sleep but they were peaceful. She hadn't woken up panicking in the middle of her sleep—which had become the norm lately. No, Rio had actually slept like a human being, for the first time in months. 

Her smile didn't fade the entire day. Even when someone spilled their coffee on her white shirt, she just looked at them and smiled.

Maybe things weren't that bad. Maybe she only needed someone to be truly present—even when they weren't. And that someone was Agatha.

Because even in her absence, Agatha was still there. In Rio's head all the time. She had glimpsed a bit of her in Alice's office today and smiled—fragments of her everywhere. Or maybe it was Rio who had started to see and sense the woman everywhere. 

Once she got in her car, her phone buzzed—Alice.

“Hey, are you still in campus?”

“I'm heading home. Why?”

“Wait, I'm coming.”

And within five minutes, Alice was there.

“Hey. Do you wanna go out? We're having a night out. It's just me, Jen, and Lilia—she's bringing a friend...”

“A friend? Agatha?”

“No, no, it's someone else. Another artist, I assume. She knows Agatha. Wanda Maximoff.”

“I don't know her.”

“Neither do I.”

A moment of silence and then it clicked in Rio's head.

“Alice...” Rio looked at her friend suspiciously with narrowed eyes.

“Is this one of those suprise parties you throw every two years? The ones I always tell you not to throw?”

Alice scratched her neck awkwardly. “No.”

“Alice Wu-Gulliver, you just scratched your neck, and I know that means you're about to lie.”

“Okay, yes!” 

“Jesus Christ.” Rio said, a shit–eating grin spreading across her face.

“See? if I told you, you wouldn't come.”

“I'll come though.”

“Seriously?”

“I know that sounds out of character, but yeah, seriously.” 

“God, I love happy Rio!”

“What do you mean?” Rio chuckled.

“I don't know what happened, but I fucking love seeing that smile back on your face. Dude, it suits you.”

“Yeah? I'm just optimistic by nature. You know that.”

And they both laughed, because it was a fact and they knew it. Maybe Rio doubted it, but Alice knew it by heart.

Alice hugged her warmly and wished her a happy birthday before they left.

Rio got ready to meet her friends. She grabbed her keys and stepped outside when her phone buzzed in her pocket.

How was your day?

And a smile spread across Rio's face—so wide it almost didn't fit into the world. It almost shone the darkness of the night.

She sat on the chair in her garden—the same chair where she had been eating herself alive the night before.

It was good.

She looked at the message and deleted it

Because honestly? Her day wasn't just good, it was the best she'd had in a while.

It was great. Thanks to you.

And she sent it, because she must show her gratitude to the woman. After all, she was the reason.

Well, actually thanks to you.

Are you doing something tonight?

She looked at the message for a while.

Yes, I'm going out with my friends.

Okay, have fun xx

A silly grin took over her face at that.

 

She went to the usual bar, and everybody was already there, waiting for her—the ones Alice had mentioned and two other women Rio knew but wasn't particularly close to. Her social bubble was incredibly small after all.

Once she approached, they cheered for her, showering her with smiles, happy birthdays, and hugs. A little overwhelming, but sweet nonetheless.

The red–haired woman who was sitting beside Lilia caught Rio's attention—that must be Wanda.

The woman reached out for a handshake, offering a soft smile that Rio found sweet.

The conversations flowed through the air—introductions, a little teasing here and there, warmth wrapping around them like a blanket. And Rio thought... maybe things weren't really that bad.

“So..” Wanda spoke as she looked at Rio.

Rio smiled as she swirled the ice in her glass, encouraging the woman to continue. But it seemed like Wanda didn't actually have something to say, so Rio spoke instead.

“So, you know Agatha?”

Apparently, Rio was a little too curious about how the two knew each other. And she knew something was there when Wanda's eyes widened slightly and also she didn't miss the way Lilia's head turned toward her at the mention of the name.

Wanda took a sip of her drink. “Yes, Agatha... I know her.” Wanda met Rio's gaze before adding “Some pages of history have been written between us.”

“Yeah? What kind of history?”

Wanda laughed awkwardly, and Rio noticed. How could she not? It was written all over the woman's face.

“Some professional pages... and intimate ones.”

There it was. That was what Rio wanted to read—the intimate pages.

“Do you know her?” Wanda asked.

Rio looked at her for a moment, then nodded as she took a sip of her drink.

“Mhm.” Wanda hummed as her gaze shifted.

Something was there. Definitely. But Rio couldn't quite place it. It was already inappropriate enough to ask, but she needed to dig deeper—maybe she'd find gold, or bones, who knew?

“So... you guys are exes?”

“Yeah.”

“Oh.”

That was enough. Exes. That was all what Rio needed to know. 

That was what fueled something else inside her.

The night came to an end. She had her fun. Thanked her friends, hugged them warmly and headed out. The cold breeze sobered her up a little. She wasn't really that drunk, or was she?

When Rio got home, she stepped out of the car and wobbled slightly as she walked to the door. That was when she noticed a black box sitting on the doorstep.

Rio arched a brow in confusion and bent down to pick it up. It looked luxurious, something she wouldn't have ordered or bought herself.

Opening it, she found a little note inside:

Happy birthday, Rio.

I hope you'll wear this when I finally take you out on a date.

A xx

Rio's heart rapidly pounded in her chest. She peeked into the box, then hurried inside.

Inside was a black dress and a perfume bottle. 

She ran her fingers over the fabric, feeling its softness carefully.

She picked up the perfume bottle and smelled it—once, twice. Then she sprayed it on her wrist and inhaled again.

It smelled like something Rio would wear, it smelled like her.

She looked at the label again. It was a perfume she recognized from somewhere, that was why it smelled like nostalgia and something else. 

Rio set the box on the table and just... stared at it.

She stared at the little note for so long that the letters started to blur.

Heat crept through her body, spreading with every second, she could feel it in every part of her body, traveling like a slow burn until it finally reached its destination, to her core.

That woman.

She took the dress out meticulously, almost afraid it would somehow disappear from her hands—or worse, transform into something else entirely.

When she finally put it on, she turned to the full–length mirror.

It was insane—the way the dress hugged her body so perfectly, accentuating every curve exhaustively.

The V-cut by the thigh... god it looked perfect.

Rio ran her hands over the fabric, feeling every inch of it against her skin.

Heat only increased when she thought about how Agatha had known her size after seeing her just a few times—enough to pick out something that fitted her flawlessly.

And then, her release tore through her, she came all over Agatha's fingers, shaking and falling apart in her arms, burying her face in the warmth of the crook of Agatha's neck as desire consumed her whole.

“Oh my... fuck, Agatha.” Rio gasped, barely able to form any words.

Agatha didn't stop, her fingers only slowed, riding out the aftershocks, letting Rio feel every second of it.

When she finally withdrew her fingers, Rio sat back, breathless.

Agatha met her gaze and without breaking the eye contact, she brought her fingers to her mouth and sucked them clean.

“That's my breakfast.” she said with a smirk before leaning in, capturing Rio's mouth once again.

Rio looked at her for a moment once Agatha pulled away, and smiled. This time, she pulled Agatha closer, her legs tightening around her waist and captured Agatha's lips in a deep heated kiss.

“God, that was...” She trailed off, words failing her. Instead, she leaned in again, letting the kiss say what she couldn't.

Once she had fully recovered, her feet found the ground, though their lips refused to part for long, so they met again.

“God, Rio, what are you doing to me?” Agatha murmured, pressing a soft kiss to Rio's head.

“What am I doing to you?” Rio teased, a smirk playing on her lips.
