“You're driving me crazy,” Agatha admitted, the words landing directly in Rio's ear, sending a shiver to run down her spine.

After a fair amount of kissing and sucking, Agatha pulled back and gave Rio's hips a gentle squeeze.

Rio's hands flew up to cling on Agatha's neck. Their bodies flush against each other.

“Can I?” Rio asked, looking directly into the oceanic depths of Agatha's eyes.

“What, angel?” Agatha murmured, their noses brushing.

“Touch you,” Rio said, blushing, her voice was barely above a whisper.

Agatha pressed her body closer, her hips flush against Rio's, and the contact pulled an involuntary, soft moan from Rio's throat.

“You can... but not now.” Agatha said as she tucked a strand of hair behind Rio's ear and her other hand moved slowly to cup Rio's ass cheek, their hips still pinned against each other.

“Can you wait for me, angel?” Agatha whispered, “Hmm?” She hummed in question as she looked into Rio's eyes, heat radiating from the proximity. 

“Yes. I can,” Rio said, closing her eyes, feeling Agatha's lingering touches on her body.

“Good girl,” Agatha praised, before capturing her lips once more.

And they ate the eggs and bacon after all.

Chapter Eight

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

How can I make it okay?
I just want you to be happy
How can I make it okay?
Nothing else is as important as that to me

Once Agatha had stepped out of Rio's place after kissing her goodbye, it was as if she had disappeared completely—without a trace, without a phone call, a text, or anything. Four days had passed, and there wasn't a single sign of her.

Agatha, who had came to Rio's house in the middle of the night straight from the airport.

Agatha, who seemed like she couldn't control herself around Rio.

Agatha, who had promised she'd come back.

And then, she just vanished into thin air. As if she had never been there in the first place.

The past four days had been a hell for Rio. Nothing occupied her mind but Agatha. Day and night, awake or asleep, nothing but Agatha. Her stupid, beautiful face and that goddamn breathtaking smile.

Was that it? Was that all she wanted? To fuck Rio senseless and make her weak? To crave herself into Rio's heart and then disappear, leaving only the imprint of her touch?

Rio had her fair share of women acting reckless for a while, then suddenly feeling guilty or whatever and disappearing. But Agatha wasn't like that, was she? She wasn't reckless. She didn't even hesitate. She knew exactly what she was doing from the moment she locked eyes with Rio across that room. She wasn't playing games, she wasn't having fun by making Rio squirm every time they were close.

Or was she?

The more Rio thought about it, the worse her headache became—the same headache that plagued her for three damned days.

She stared down at the papers on her desk, but none of it made any sense. She couldn't process a single thing. The only thing in her head was Agatha.

Goddamn Agatha and her gorgeous blue eyes. Her fascinating sharp nose. Her cheekbones and jaw, her full, delicious lips. Her slender, long fingers...

Rio squeezed her eyes shut the moment her mind started drifting to the wrong places. Thinking about the way Agatha's mouth tasted. The way her unapologeitc gaze pierced through Rio. The way she lifted her with ease, placing her exactly where she wanted. The way her fingers felt inside her...

Oh no. Not there. 

Rio had reached out first, sent messages, called—but no answer. Not a single one. She even considered asking Lilia, but she knew that was a bad idea. She wasn't in that place yet, hell, she didn't even know where the fuck her place was.

Rio was desperate. She just wanted to hear her voice. That voice could heal the wounds her absence had caused.

Rio was painfully aware of how hard she had fallen for Agatha, and god, it was torturous. And she couldn't do a damn thing about it. 

She was supposed to be past this—past the stupid games her heart wanted to play. Years ago, she had decided she would never fall into its traps again. She would dismiss it every time. If she couldn't control it, she could at least ignore it.

But here she was, sitting in her office chair, mind in disarray, heart pounding with fear—not just of what would happen next, but worse, of what wouldn't.

She let the pen slip from her fingers and tossed it onto the stack of papers in front of her. Leaning back, she covered her face with both hands, trying in vain to suppress the goddamn headache.

Nothing was working. And she was a fool. 

She couldn't help but feel like a teenage girl with a stupid crush, waiting for a message so she could grin at it like an idiot.

What was it with her luck? Something had to be wrong. Was Rio really the kind of person who scared people away? Who made them disappear? But god, Agatha wasn't just people, and Rio knew it. 

That was why she still had hope. That was why she knew Agatha would come back at some point. Maybe tomorrow, and she'd have an excuse, one Rio would accept without question.

Because if it was Agatha, she'd accept anything. Honestly, she was down so bad. Down on her knees for that woman. The woman she had only spent time with by chance. The woman she kept meeting in strange coincidences, without any planning. 

Every time they met, the world seemed to shrink. As if nothing else existed. No other places. No other people. Just them. And those damn unexplained coincidences.

Rio could feel her head pulsing everywhere, and she was aware that she looked like shit. She hadn't gotten much sleep lately—when did she ever get the rest her body needed anyway? 

She pushed the chair forward, trying to get back to the work in her hands—the work she couldn't even focus on, no matter how hard she tried.

Another day passed, and nothing from Agatha.

Maybe tomorrow?

And another.

Maybe tomorrow?

It had been a week.

There was no tomorrow.

Rio had spent every maybe tomorrow she had in her pockets, none were left.

And yet, when she woke up this morning, she still found herself looking at the messages she had sent to Agatha over the past few days.

Hey gorgeous. Are you free tomorrow?

Hi, Agatha. Are you alright?

Where are you? Is everything okay?

Did something happen to you?

God, Agatha, where are you? Please, can you just talk to me?

Again, Rio was desperate. 

And that woman, despite her absence, kept growing inside her. Kept taking up space. Kept living in her—even though Rio wasn't watering her memory. Even though no sunlight reached the depths Agatha had buried herself in.

So how? How did she keep growing and growing? And why did Rio still have so much hope that Agatha would return? To the point that hope inside her had already begun creating yet another maybe tomorrow.

So... maybe tomorrow.

Rio got up. It was Monday again. She had to face the world again, make small talks with people, even though every word left a nauseating sensation in her stomach—one she'd only purge at the end of the day when she'd vomit herself out.

It was strange how one couldn't control oneself. No matter the effort put into taming a wild heart. Something always came out of nowhere to shatter it. To leave open wounds that will eventually scar.

Agatha never had to speak to Rio in the first place. She shouldn't have. They weren't together, after all. They hadn't even gone on a proper date. 

And yet, the question lingered in Rio's mind.

Why? Why would someone go through all that effort just to walk away? Without a single word?

Did Agatha expect Rio to use her memory, her promises, to fill the space her absence had left?

Nonsense.

Rio wasn't great at communicating, that much she knew. But she still knew when to talk, what to say and why.

She had spent her whole life making sure she never did to others what had been done to her. She had put herself last just to avoid affecting people the way they had affected her. She knew the weight a word could hold. The pain an action could cause. And she never wanted to be the reason of any of it.

She washed her face. In the process, she glanced at her reflection, at the dark circles under her eyes. No amount of makeup would hide those properly.

She got dressed for the long day ahead, grabbed her things, and stepped out.

As the day came to an end, she gathered her stuff and headed outside. She was expecting a call from Alice, so when her phone vibrated in her pocket, she pulled it out and brought it to her ear without looking at it.

“Hey, Alice, I'm heading home—”

“Rio...”

The voice made Rio froze mid-step. People passed by her, unaware of what a single voice had just done to her.

She swallowed hard. Her breath turned unsteady. A panic attack was forming inside her.

She thought she'd be glad to hear that voice again, but now? Now she was terrified of what was coming.

Rio said nothing, not for a solid twenty seconds.

“First of all,” Agatha began, “I'm really sorry, Rio...”

“What do you want, Agatha?” Rio's question wasn't sharp. Wasn't edged. It was soft, barely above a whisper.

“Can I see you?”

“Why?” Rio asked, resuming her walk. “Why do you want to see me?” 

“I could explain... if you let me. And if you don't want to, I'd understand.”

“Explain what, Agatha?”

“God, Rio, please don't talk to me like that.”  Agatha's voice was hurt. It was obvious. And by the gods, how it pained Rio.

As if she could feel her insides bleeding from the stab Agatha's voice had caused.

“Like what?” Rio whispered. “I'm just asking, Agatha.”

Agatha was silent for a while, and that made Rio walk faster toward her car. She slid in and closed the door, then exhaled a breath she hadn't even realized she'd been holding.

“Can I see you? Please, just say yes or no. I'll answer any question you have.”

As Agatha said that, a tear ran down Rio's face, resting at the edge of her chin. She wiped it away with the back of her hand.

“Yeah, okay.”

“Okay?”

“Yeah.” Rio said as she started the engine. “Ah—I'm heading home now. Can you come to my place? If that's okay? I don't really have the urge to go out... if that's okay with you?” 

“Yes... Yes, of course. I'll be there.”

“Great. See you then.”

She ended the call and exhaled a deep shaky breath. Her eyes started producing the tears she despised. She couldn't cry, at least not here. 

But god, that voice. The weight behind Agatha's tone, something hidden, something carefully concealed, yet despite Agatha's efforts of hidding it, Rio heard it, and it hurt.

A knock on the window jolted her from her thoughts.

Alice.

She was holding her phone to her ear, pointing at it. Rio glanced at her own phone and saw Alice's name flashing on the screen. She lowered the window.

“Hey, why didn't you pick up?”

“I was calling someone.”

Alice studied her for a moment, and Rio felt exposed. Embarrassed.

“Are you alright?”

“Yes, I am. Just tired. Long day.” Rio forced the best smile she could muster.

“Okay... You still up for tonight, yeah?”

“About that... I don't think I'll be able to come. You guys go ahead without me, I have something to do.”

“What is it, Rio?”

“Nothing, really, Alice. I just have to meet someone, that's all.”

“And that ‘someone’ happens to be Agatha Harkness?”

Rio's eyes widened. Damn you Alice!

“No! Why would you say that?? Why would I meet Agatha?”

Rio tried to sound as defensive as possible.

“Rio, sweetheart...” Alice looked like she was about to say something else, but at the last second, she changed her mind. Instead, she smiled—that bright, knowing smile of hers.

“Nothing. Just take care, okay?”

“Okay. You too.”

Rio drove home and her mind was a mess.

What would she do once she saw Agatha? What would she say? What would Agatha say? What would they do?

So many whats, yet nothing was clear. She'd catch an idea, and the next second she'd dismiss it.

She had no idea how to handle situations like this one. And it was stupid—so, so stupid—to ask Agatha to come to her place, to be alone with her.

She should have suggested a restaurant. A goddamn bar. Somewhere crowded, somewhere where she could focus on anything other than Agatha.

But honestly... Would she even focus on anything else if Agatha was there? No. That was one of the impossible things in the world. Because even in her absence, Rio hadn't been able to focus on anything else.

Who was she kidding? No one but herself.

Rio arrived at the discomfort of her depressing house.

She hung up her coat, kicked off her shoes near the door, then headed straight to the liquor cabinet. A glass of wine would help her relax a little before Agatha's arrival.

She lay on the couch, a glass in hand, feeling her muscles loosen slightly as she let herself sink into the cushions. She stared at the ceiling for minutes. Voices in her head whispered. Suggested things. The clothes on her body felt uncomfortable, these jeans weren't made for lounging.

So she got up, took a sip of wine, and went upstairs to change into something more comfortable. When she came back, she sat in the same spot on the couch, waiting.

Waiting.

Minutes passed and there was no sign of Agatha.

They hadn't agreed on a specific time. Should she send a message? No.

She'd be here any minute. Or any hour.

Half an hour passed.

Rio hated waiting. No, she despised it. Especially waiting without knowing. 

She rose to her feet and poured herself another glass of wine. Agatha would get here whenever she wanted.

And Rio...

Had to pretend she wasn't waiting impatiently. Like lava wasn't running through her veins. Like she wasn’t on the verge of erupting.

As she finished the second glass and was about to pour a third, a knock on the door snapped her attention away. She looked up while setting the glass down on the table.

She tried not to hurry her steps, but the anticipation was agonizing.

Taking a deep breath, she placed her hand on the door handle and opened it. 

The first thing she saw was Agatha's blue eyes—then the darkness beneath them.

“Hi,” Agatha greeted, her voice was low.

“Hi. Come on in.”

Rio stepped aside, and Agatha walked in.

No warm embrace. No kiss. No anything.

Rio forced herself to stay calm, to suppress the burning inside her, the longing, the ache of seeing that beautiful face after a week, the pain of witnessing the exhaustion in those delicate features.

Agatha walked a few steps then she froze in her motion. Rio closed the door, then walked toward the couch. 

Agatha didn't follow.

“Come, sit.” Rio said, eyes fixed on Agatha's face, searching, but finding nothing.

“Rio... I'm sorry.” Agatha finally said, standing still in her place. “I know it's been a week, but I really was busy. With so much. I'm not trying to justify ghosting you. I just... I just want to let you know.” 

Rio remained standing near the couch, neither sitting nor moving.

“You could have said something. Sent a message. Anything.”  Her voice was soft. Her eyes were still on Agatha, who for some reason, refused to meet Rio's.

And Rio didn't like that. It made her heart tighten.

“No. I couldn't.” Agatha murmured.

“You couldn't call me? Respond to one of my messages?” Rio's tone rose slightly, she couldn't control it.

“No.”

“Why?”

Agatha still wasn't looking at Rio. She looked everywhere but at her eyes.

“Agatha, Look at me.” Rio stepped closer.

Agatha remained still. Frozen, not a single motion, as if something unseen held her in place. She was silent, like she wanted to speak but couldn't.

I wanted to call you, but I couldn't.” Agatha said, looking directly into Rio's eyes. “It's still not an excuse for disappearing for a week. And I'm sorry Rio, I really am.”

Rio felt panic building inside her with every word. What had kept Agatha so busy? What had made her look so tired?

She tried to stay calm, even as the panic clawed at her insides, threatening to drag her under. 

She swallowed hard, ignoring the ache twisting inside her as she cleared her throat. But her heart was pounding too fast and her stomach was burning.

“It's okay.” She heard herself, she knew how she sounded, but she tried not to focus on it. She tried not to focus on the pain growing inside her the longer she looked at Agatha.

God, if she were alone, she might have been able to deal with this.

But she wasn't.

Her head spun and the room tilted. She squeezed her eyes shut, and the next second she felt fingertips brushing against her cheekbone.

“Yes... yes, I am.” Rio said as she opened her eyes, forcing a faint, artificial smile onto her face.

The next second, the overwhelming weight crashed down on her. The pain of the past week caught up all at once. Her breathing turned unsteady, she couldn't get enough oxygen into her lungs, and the next thing she knew, she was on her knees, struggling to breathe.

“Rio, are you okay? Talk to me.”

Agatha dropped to the floor beside her, panic lacing her voice. But Rio couldn't respond, she couldn't even process what Agatha was saying. Her head spun like a goddamn wheel out of control. Her vision blurred, black spots floated in front of her eyes. The lack of oxygen was suffocating her.

She felt Agatha's hands on her shoulders. She heard her voice, thick with concern, but the words, she couldn't understand them.

“Rio, can you hear me? Baby, please say something.”

Her head hung low, staring at nothing. Before she could fall completely, Agatha pulled her close, holding Rio's weak body against her chest.

Trying to soothe her, to chase the panic away.

“Come on Rio, please just breathe with me. You'll be okay.”

This—

This was the first sentence Rio was able to make out, she was regaining some consciousness. Some control over her body.

“I'm here baby. I'm here. Just please breathe with me. Please.”

Rio forced herself to follow Agatha's voice. Slow, deep breaths, one then another. Pulling oxygen into her lungs, to reach her brain and regain some balance.

Agatha's hands never stopped moving, never left her. She kept stroking gently. Kept holding her, grounding her.

A few seconds passed, and Rio's vision returned to normal. Her hearing sharpened. She could hear Agatha's heartbeat, loud and rapid, pounding right against her ear. She could feel Agatha's warmth. Smell her scent. Hear her again.

“Can you please say something?” Agatha voice trembled, as if a sob was trapped in her throat.

It had to be uncomfortable for Agatha. Rio thought. Sitting on the floor, nearly lying on it, with Rio's body resting against hers.

“Keep breathing for me.”

Rio lifted her head, burying her face in Agatha's neck, breathing in her scent—violet and warmth and Agatha. Breathing—exhaling warm breaths against her neck, so Agatha could feel her, to make sure Rio was okay with every breath.

“Sorry about that.” This time, Rio managed a real smile.

“I'm sorry,” A kiss to her closed eyes. “I'm sorry,” Her nose. “I'm sorry,” Her left cheek. “I'm sorry.” The right one.

Wanting to tell her she didn't have to be sorry, but before she could speak, Agatha leaned in, whispering an “I'm sorry” near Rio's lips making her feel the warmth of it. Then Agatha kissed her. Tender. Sweet. Apologetic. Pouring everything into the kiss, every I'm sorry she couldn't say. Every I'm sorry Rio couldn't hear. The kiss lasted minutes. Maybe hours. Rio placed her palm in Agatha's and she pulled her up gently.

“I am now.”

“Good,” Agatha said, her thumbs moving up and down on Rio's hips. “Can you tell me what happened? Hmm? It's okay if you don't want to.”

“Yes, I'm really fine now.” Rio leaned closer and kissed the apple of Agatha's cheek. “Let's sit?”

She took Agatha's hand, and they sat on the couch.

“You look tired.”

“Yeah, the work never ends.” Rio tried to dismiss, but Agatha clearly wasn't satisfied with that response.

“You haven't been sleeping, have you?”

“I try to get just enough to get through the day.” Rio said with a smile. “You also look exhausted. Are you alright?”

“I am, don't worry.”

Minutes of silence settled between them. And it kept stretching.

They only kept looking at each other—neither knowing what they were searching for in the other's features, neither knowing how to voice the words resting on the tips of their tongues. 

“What were you doing in Paris?” Rio asked, trying not to put any pressure on the question. Because she knew something had happened there, even if she didn't know what it exactly was.

And her suspicion was confirmed by the shift in Agatha's expression.

Agatha opened her mouth, then shut it again, only looking at Rio with those tired blue eyes.

“Can we talk about this later?”

“Of course,” Rio said, tucking a strand of Agatha's dark hair behind her ear. “Whenever you want.” She looked into those enchanting blue lakes. “I'm gonna get us some water. Do you want anything else?”

“No, water is fine. Thank you.”

Rio got up to grab two bottles of water, then returned to find Agatha still sitting in the same place.

Rio was worried. This was the first time she had seen her like this—pale and exhausted. She wanted to know what was going on inside Agatha's head, to know what was wrong and try to stitch the wounds. But at the same time, she didn't want to push. She knew what it felt like to be forced into something.

But god, it hurt—watching those tired, beautiful features while being helpless to do anything.

She handed Agatha the bottle and sat beside her, closer than before.

“You should rest.” Rio said, watching as Agatha drank from the bottle.

Agatha removed it from her mouth and closed it, a smirk appearing as she wiped the corners of her mouth with her fingers.

What a sight...

But Rio forced the thought away, focusing instead on figuring out why Agatha was smirking. 

“You're the one who should rest.”

Rio narrowed her eyes. Then, her index finger moved slowly under Agatha's right eye.

“Your beautiful eyes are tired.”

Agatha chuckled. “You're adorable, you know that?”

Rio smiled as she kept moving her fingers gently.

“If you don't want to rest, then can I run a bath for you? Then we could eat,” Rio said, her gaze was drifting to those full lips before returning to Agatha's eyes. “Hmm? I won't take no for an answer.”

“Are you sure about that?”

“Sure about what? Running you a bath so you can relax a little, then finally getting the chance to eat with you? Yes, I'm sure about that, Agatha.”

Agatha seemed to hesitate, but Rio didn't let her. “Please don't overthink it.”

Agatha smiled—a smile that reached all the way up to her eyes, and it was one of the most beautiful things Rio had ever seen.

“Okay.”

“Yeah?”

“Yeah,” Agatha said, and that smile didn't leave her beautiful face.

Rio wanted to see it every day. To be reason behind it.

She got up to prepare the bath while Agatha stood in the doorway. Rio could feel Agatha's eyes on her—how could she not?

“Okay, so you have everything you need here. I'll put some clothes in the guest room, and if you need anything, just call me. I'll be in the room by the stairs.”

As soon as Rio finished speaking, Agatha leaned in, their faces mere inches apart. She rested a hand on the back of Rio's neck, then kissed her soothingly, tasting her with tenderness, pouring so much love and gratitude into that kiss. And Rio felt it all, it was consuming her in the best way.

Agatha pulled back slightly, “Thank you,” she whispered.

Rio only smiled and kissed Agatha's lips again briefly, then she stepped outside and closed the door behind her.

She grabbed one of her bands t-shirts, a pair of sweatpants and some decent shorts, leaving the decision to Agatha, along with a pair of new underwear. She placed them on the bed in the guest room and headed to the indoor garden.

She sat among her plants, letting the quiet settle around her.

Fifteen minutes passed, and a knock on the door made her smile.

“Come on in.”

Agatha stepped inside, and god—seeing Agatha in her t-shirt and shorts did something to her heart. Agatha's hair was tied up in a damp bun, and she looked relaxed, just as Rio had hoped. She stared at her for so long that she almost missed the amazed look on Agatha's face.

“Which one is the main one?” Agatha asked, her gaze sweeping over the white-colored room. Green plants stretched from the ceiling to the floor, vases overflowing with greenery, floor-to-ceiling windows letting in streams of sunlight. Two small windows in the ceiling allowed some plants to spill through, creating a dreamy, living view. In the center sat a velvet green couch with a small table in front of it, a stack of books beside a bottle of wine and two glasses.

Rio chuckled as she stood up.

“I don't know, really. Both spaces are dear to me, so I can't decide.”

Agatha smiled and kept wandering, her expression filled with wonder.

Her eyes landed on the guitar leaning against the couch, and Rio noticed where her eyes drifted.

“Do you play?” Agatha asked as she approached her.

“You could say that. I haven't played in a long time.” Rio admitted, a faint blush coloring her cheeks.

Agatha smiled as they sat down.

“Aren't you full of surprises? Can you play something?”

“If you want me to.”

“Of course I do.”

Rio laughed—Agatha was far too alluring.

“Okay, but give me a minute to remember something I can play.”

Agatha nodded, looking at Rio adoringly.

“The last time I actually played was when I was a freshman in college.” Rio said, setting the guitar on her lap and holding it close to her body with both hands. “I used to be in a band with my friends in high school,” She chuckled as she tested the strings. “Now... You know, I only play for my plants.”

She lifted her face to look at Agatha, and was completely flabbergasted by the way Agatha was looking at her. Her eyes were full of something Rio couldn't name or recognize, but she felt. It wrapped around her warmly. The way Agatha was smiling at her—completely dumbstruck.

“A band?” Agatha said. “Go on.”

Rio couldn't help but smile as warmth spread through her entire body. Agatha was paying attention to everything, looking at her as if she were something precious.

“Yeah, a band. In highschool—me, Alice and two other lesbians.” 

Agatha laughed and the sound warmed Rio from the inside out. It was one of the sweetest sounds she had ever heard.

“What was the band's name? Lesbians in High School?” Agatha teased, laughter still visible in her words.

“Close. It was The Scissors.” 

“No way!”

“Yeah, and if the school had known what it meant at the time, they wouldn't have let us play. But we were safe.”

And what she saw was a fucking haunting nightmare.

“You've got to be kidding me!”

“Hey, Rio.”

Rio's jaw clenched.

“How the fuck did you get in here?”

“Well, I know where you keep the spare key.” Jane stood up from the chair and started walking toward Rio.

“Get the fuck out, Jane.”

“Why don't you answer any of my calls? I feel like a dog barking just to get your attention, Rio.”

“I said, get the fuck out.” Rio's voice came through clenched teeth.

Jane laughed. That fucking annoying laugh of hers.

So Rio grabbed her wrist forcefully.

“This is the last time I'll say this. Get the fuck out.”

“Oof. Bold.”

“Okay, you heard her. Get out.” 

The words came from behind Rio. She turned her head slightly, glancing at Agatha—because that was the first thing she had said in minutes.

Rio's grip loosened at the distraction, so Jane yanked her wrist free.

Then Jane's gaze flicked to Agatha.

“And... who are you?” She asked, pointing a finger at Agatha.

Agatha was calm, her hands buried in her pants pockets, looking straight at Rio's ex-girlfriend's face with that smirk on her face.

“Lower that finger down, unless you want it broken.” Agatha's voice was smooth, steady.

She took a small step closer to Rio, removing one hand from her pocket and resting it on Rio's back—a silent reassurance.

Jane cackled. But she did lower her finger.

“Good for you, Rio. You got yourself a bodyguard.”

“Exactly.” Agatha's smirk deepened. “Now get lost.”

Jane looked at them both, then walked past Agatha—bumping her shoulder on the way out. As she reached the door and opened it, she spoke again, “I'll see you,” and left, leaving the door open behind her.

Rio stood in her place, annoyed and frustrated. The warmth of Agatha's hand resting on her back helped her steady her breaths.

After a minute, without looking at Agatha, she walked toward the chair, feeling embarrassment creeping in.

That? That was humiliating. Her toxic, creepy ex breaking into her house like that. Not being able to handle it herself. And letting Agatha to deal with it instead. It was all too much to process. She had come back to her house to do one thing and now she was dealing with something else entirely.

“I could have dealt with her on my own, you know?” Rio finally said, still not looking at Agatha—only staring at the nearest object, which was beginning to blur. 

“I know,” Agatha replied, her voice was soft and knowing. “Sorry if I crossed a line.”

“What line?” Rio finally looked up, but Agatha's features blurred together. She couldn't recognize them, not after seconds. “No, no. I'm sorry you had to see that.” Rio ran a furious hand through her hair, her irritation growing inside her.

The way Jane had spoken to her in front of Agatha... What must Agatha think of her now? Someone who couldn't even handle their own ex? Great!

“Rio...”

“No, Agatha. Please... Can we not talk about this? Just—just forget it,” Rio said as she got up. Her voice sounded so small. So broken. “Let's find your phone, yeah?”

Agatha only nodded, saying nothing more.

She grabbed her phone from the table in the living room, checked it, then tossed it into her pocket.

“I should get going now. You should rest, Rio.”

“But—”

“Don't,” Agatha said softly, extending her hand to touch Rio's face, but stopping short. Mid-air.

Rio frowned at that. Instead of questioning it, she reached for Agatha's hand and held it.

“I'll call you later,” Agatha added as she squeezed Rio's hand. Their eyes locked and Rio was painfully aware of the goddamn tears hanging on the edges, threatening to fall. 

She only looked at Agatha.

But she didn't.

She just stood there, looking into those blue eyes, not uttering a goddamn word.

After a really long minute. Agatha leaned in and pressed a kiss to her cheek.

“I'll call you,” She whispered. Then, this time, she did touch Rio's face—cupping it with one hand.“Take care.” 

And then, she left.

The touch lingered on Rio's skin, just like everything else. Agatha's scent still filled her senses. She could still feel her presence somehow.

But it wasn't the only one. She could feel her ex's presence too, the second Rio looked at the chair in the dining room. Jane's voice rang in her head, sharp and irritating. Triggering a dull ache behind her eyes.

With a heavy sigh, Rio threw herself onto the couch. Collapsing on it.

Here she was again. The same situation she had found herself in dozens of times. Helpless.

She needed to do something about it. Because she was done. Done being dragged into her ex's sick games.

And the first thing?

She should change the goddamn lock. So that creepy bitch wouldn't be creeping around anymore.

Chapter End Notes

I know this is short and weirdly written, but bear with me.

Chapter Ten

Perhaps Rio wasn't who she thought she was. The thoughts she had about herself—about how she acted—perhaps were only that: thoughts. Ideas that lived inside her head but never materialized into action. They were just... thoughts. In her head. Things she believed she was acting upon.

One might proclaim certain ideas, thoughts and principles, but actually following them? That was a whole different story. Because proclaiming them was one thing, but living them, making the effort to embody them every day? That was something else entirely.

Or at least, that was what Rio was thinking as she stared at her phone, the screen flashing with Agatha's name for the second time in ten minutes.

She didn't pick up. She couldn't.

She couldn't find it in herself to respond, to prepare herself to talk to Agatha, to hear the woman's voice after what happened this morning. Not even the alcohol in her system helped or encouraged her to pick up.

It perhaps seemed silly. Answering a call was one of the easiest and simplest things in today's world. But was it? Not when considering who was on the other end of the line. Not when it was Agatha's voice she would be hearing. Not when there were a dozen of other things tangled together in her mind. 

No. Answering a call wasn't simple. It wasn't easy. In fact, it was one of the most overwhelming things ever.

She watched as the screen dimmed and Agatha's name disappeared. At that moment, there were no options left. Even if she wanted to answer or decline, she couldn't. She had her chance—twice—and she missed them both.

She could have made a choice, but she didn't. She just sat there, staring, instead of doing anything. She didn't know what she wanted, and she hadn't made anything clear to the other party.

She was lost, confused, and in her confusion, she was dragging everyone else into the chaotic chaos her life had become.

Part of her turmoil came from her uncertainty about everything. Especially about Agatha.

She knew almost nothing about the woman—just a few threads, not enough to weave into anything. They were just... threads. And though Rio had tried to tie their ends together, hoping to grasp onto something, she hadn't caught anything.

And she blamed herself for that. Because it wasn't as if she had asked for more. She had just sat there, willing to take whatever Agatha was ready to offer, which, as it turned out, wasn't much.

She had so many questions, but they remained locked up in her head. She couldn't bring herself to set them free. Somehow, they made more sense that way. Or at least, that was what she convinced herself with.

For nearly thirteen minutes, Rio sat on that couch, doing absolutely nothing—just overthinking her entire life.

Her legs were spread apart, her back hunched forward, fingers were absently cracking as she stared at the phone laying on the table beside a half-empty bottle of vodka.

She wished for something, some divine force to intervene, to unlock the situation she trapped herself in. She needed something, anything, to give her the key to break free.

Then, after five more minutes—an eternity in Rio's mind—her phone vibrated again.

Agatha.

Rio grabbed the phone quickly and just... stared at it.

Her hesitation was eating her alive, and it was ridiculous—especially considering that Agatha had been wrist-deep inside her only nine hours ago.

“Fuck it,” Rio muttered to herself in drunkness. She cleared her throat and swiped to answer.

As she did, she was met with silence. No breath, no sound from the other end. Just dead silence.

So she forced herself to speak.

“Hey.” Her voice came out almost a whisper, softer than what she intended.

After fifteen seconds that Rio counted on her left hand's fingers, five after five, Agatha finally spoke.

“Hey there. Are you alright, Rio?”

Agatha's voice was laced with concern. Real concern, something Rio could both hear and feel.

Rio's fingers stilled as she absentmindedly counted another five seconds. She stared ahead, not looking at anything in particular—more lost in thought than focused on what was in front of her.

She wasn't fine. Not really. And she wanted Agatha to know. But why?

Why did she want Agatha to know?

Rio knew she was a bad liar—possibly the worst—but that never stopped her from lying every time someone asked whether she was okay or not. Yet, at that moment, even those bad lies refused to form. She couldn't bring herself to throw them at Agatha, whether she believed them or not. As if, with Agatha, she wanted to be nothing but honest. Transparent.

“I don't know.”

“That's okay. It's okay.” Agatha said, and Rio's heart clenched tightly in her chest. “What are you doing now?” Agatha asked.

Rio's heart spiked—so hard it was terrifying to feel. She pressed a palm to her chest, rubbing it as her breaths turned unsteady. She leaned forward, grapped the bottle of alcohol with her hand, and chugged until the burn scorched her throat and stomach. Then, she set the nearly empty bottle on the floor beside her foot and wiped her mouth with the back of her hand.

“Rio? Are you there?”

“I am.” Rio said as she leaned back into the couch. Her chest was heaving, her breaths uneven.

“Why are you talking to me?” she asked as she closed her eyes.

“What do you mean?” Agatha asked, her voice held uncertainty.

“I mean... why are you talking to me?” Rio repeated. “You could be doing literally anything else with your time.” Rio chuckled. “Instead of trying to figure out what the fuck is wrong with me. Because, I can assure you, I don't even know what the fuck is wrong with me.”

“Rio, are you... God, are you drunk?”

“Am I drunk? Am I? Yes, Agatha. I am. That? I can answer gladly.”

“Okay, look—”

“You could like... have whoever you want. Seriously. Have you seen yourself? Absolutely fucking drop-dead gorgeous.” Rio interrupted.

“Rio—”

“You know when I knew I was out of your league? When I saw that redhead, Wanda...” Rio paused for a moment. “Whatever  the fuck her last name was.”

“What? When did you see Wanda? How do you even know her?”

Rio chuckled, stretching her arm to reach the bottle again without shifting her posture.

“Believe it or not...” A sip. “She was at my birthday... The funny thing is—or it's not really funny, anyway, I never saw a painting of her while I was looking at your artwork. I was totally convinced that your type was dark–haired losers until I saw her.”

“Okay, Rio. Honey, slow down.”

“Look, I'm just saying...” Rio tightened her grip on the neck of the bottle. “You shouldn't be wasting your time with me.”

“Why and how did you come to this conclusion, Rio?” Agatha sighed. “Look, it's not what you think it is. You're getting it wrong—”

“Am I?” 

Agatha heavily sighed again but she kept speaking, pushing past Rio's constant interruptions.

“Yes, you are. You're reading it wrong. You're overthinking it. I'm interested in... Look, I'll have this conversation with you when you're sober. I want to hear what you're feeling and thinking while you're sober, Rio. Not like this. Not over a phone call I didn't even think you'd answer.”

“Well, I can't do life sober.”

“We'll see about that.”

“What about that blonde? At the club. Who is she? I saw her, you know. She's a model.”

“Yes, she is,” Agatha sighed, sounding helpless.“What about her?”

“I don't know. Is she... with you now?”

“No, she's not. Rio...”

“Do you sleep with her?”

“Rio—”

“Do you?”

“Please, baby... Rio, just listen to me.”

“No, you answer me.”

They both fell silent.

For a few, long minutes silence stretched between them. And it kept stretching.

“...Okay, I got my answer.” 

Rio pressed the phone harder against her ear, almost hurting skull, and before Agatha could respond, she hung up.

The phone hit the couch as she threw it aside, stretching her arms out, though her grip on the now empty bottle remained tight.

Where had that come from? All that jealousy. All that possessiveness?

Rio wasn't the jealous type. Not at all. She hadn't even realized she was jealous of both women until now. Until she said it out loud—until the alcohol forced it to the surface.

Those weren't the questions Rio wanted to ask. Not the information she wanted to know. And definitely not the side of Agatha she was interested in knowing first. But the damage was done.

If she hadn't scared Agatha away before, she sure had now.

Rio stood up, went upstairs and headed to her room. She paused in the doorway, staring at the dimly lit space. Then, she stepped inside and turned the light on. Her eyes swept over the room until they landed on the silver ring she found earlier—Agatha's.

She had spotted it on the floor near the bed while cleaning up or... pretended to do so.

She had stared at it for a solid ten minutes before placing it on the nightstand. It was the one Agatha wore on her thumb. The same one she had forgotten to take off—the one Rio had felt, cold against her skin when Agatha fucked her in on the kitchen island a week ago.

She studied her reflection, though nothing was really clear. She had been thinking about cutting her hair for a long time. A really long time.

Tonight was the night.

But it wasn't just about cutting her hair. There was something else. A hidden agenda buried somewhere.

That hairdresser with her short hair, muscular body and cool band t-shirts. Someone who reminded Rio of her youth. The twenty-or thirty-something lesbian who had been flirting with Rio for nearly two years—whether they accidentally met on the street, the salon, the nearby bar, or even the supermarket. 

Rio wanted a haircut. And that woman worked there—if she still worked there.

Was she a bad person for thinking this way?

Hell. Who the fuck gives a fuck?

She was drunk. Not a single clear thought floated through her mind. Nothing seemed right or wrong. Everything felt possible.

She looked at herself for a few more seconds, then grapped a pack of cigarettes, slipped one between her lips before shoving the pack into her pocket and her wallet went into the other pocket.

Downstairs, she lit the cigarette in the kitchen and put the lighter in her pocket as well. Pulled on her trainers and grapped the new door keys before stepping outside.

Before the door fully closed behind her, she hesitated. Stepping back inside, she grapped her phone from the couch, then walked out again.

She walked—more like dragged herself—to the salon. Her mind was a chaos. Nothing was clear. Her vision was blurred, and she stumbled into a few people along the way. But somehow, she made it. 

The ten-minute walk and the night air sobered her. Just a little.

Once inside, the strak white lighting attacked her eyes, almost burning them.

She had no appointment so she prepared to wait. But before she could even sit down, that woman approached her. 

Miriam, if Rio remembered correctly.

“Nice seeing you here.” Miriam said with a smile, and Rio straightened up.

“Need a haircut or did you come here to see me?”

Rio managed a laugh that didn't sound too drunk. Or maybe it was obvious. “Maybe both?”

“Oh, careful there. I might believe you.”

“Then believe me.” Rio whispered, a smirk forming on her lips.

Miriam raised an eyebrow. “Did you finally recieve my signals, then?” She motioned for Rio to take a seat. “Come here.”

Once Rio sat, she looked at their reflection in the mirror. Focusing mostly on herself, not the woman standing behind her.

“I recieved them a while ago.”

Miriam chuckled at that. 

She picked up a comb and started running it through Rio's dark hair. Rio's eyes remained locked on the mirror, her vision growing blurrier with every passing second.

“How do you want it?”

“Just cut it short.”

“How short are we thinking?”

Rio weakly lifted her hand up and pointed at her shoulder. Not able to form something as simple as shoulder-length.

“Okay.” Miriam slid her fingers through Rio's dark hair, stroking it gently before leaning in—her mouth was close to Rio's ear, “My shift ends in fifteen minutes, which means by the time I'm done with your hair—” 

Rio turned her head to look at the woman. “Great.”

They locked eyes for a few seconds before Rio turned back to her reflection.

“Okay, let's wash your hair then.”

“Do it without the washing. Just cut it.”

And Miriam did as she was told.

She cut Rio's hair, and by the time she was done she asked if Rio liked it. Rio managed a feigned, toothy smile and mumbled a few words—lies. Because she wasn't really aware of what was happening around her. She didn't even know if her hair had been cut or if it was still the same. She'd probably like it or regret it in the morning.

When Rio stood up from the chair, her legs almost gave out beneath her, but Miriam caught her by the forearm.

“You okay?”

“Totally. Just a little dizzy.”

“Alright, I'll go grab my jacket.”

While waiting, Rio paid at the counter, leaving a decent tip.

Then Miriam returned. They stepped outside into the busy, noisy street, packed with people and layered with sounds that made Rio's headache worsen by the second.

“My apartment's a few blocks away, or do you—”

“No. Your place.”

And they walked, silent. Not a single word was exchanged.

“What made you change your mind?” The woman asked.

“You were hitting on me while I had a girlfriend, Miriam.” Rio said.

Saying the word girlfriend while referring to Jane made her sick.

“Oh?” Miriam chuckled. “So you're single now?”

“Where's your apartment? We've been walking for an hour.” 

“It's been five minutes.”

“Yeah? Feels like an hour to me.”

“We're almost there.” She chuckled.

What was she doing? Why was she doing this? Who actually does this? Was she trying to forget something or someone? Agatha? Jane? Was fucking another woman really the only solution? Was she really that stupid?

“The place is kind of a mess.” Miriam said with a chuckle.

And Rio remained silent. It wasn't like she could actually tell if a place was messy or not. Everything looked the same to her at that moment.

“Do you want something to drink?”

“No, just...”

Rio took a few steps forward, closing the space between them. Then she kissed her.

It was rough—too rough. She almost bit the woman's lip hard enough to make her bleed. Almost.

Miriam tasted like whisky and tobacco. And she also tasted like—blood?

Rio pulled back.

“Fuck. I'm sorry.” Rio said.

“You're the one who's bleeding.”

Rio touched her lips with her fingers then looked at them. Two fingertips, smeared with her dark blood.

She wiped her mouth with the back of her hand and leaned in again, crashing her lips against Miriam's, not caring about the blood.

“Let me take the lead, yeah? Where's the bedroom?” Rio asked, breathless. And Miriam only pointed with her hand, still catching her breath.

She pulled Miriam's pants and boxers off in one swift motion.

Then she fucked her. Three fingers and a mouth.

Rio barely registered the sounds Miriam made, how she called her name, what she said—if she said anything at all.

“Jesus christ, that was...” She chuckled. “Holy fuck, Rio.” Her smile was evident in her voice.

For the first time, Rio really looked at the woman's features, and panic began clawing at her chest. Her heartbeat turned erratic and her breaths shortened.

The woman lying beneath her propped herself up on her arms, still smiling.

“Is it my turn now?”

Rio blinked. Then blinked again. What was she doing here?

But she took her shirt off anyway, exposing her chest—she hadn't worn a bra. She barely put the goddamn shirt on her body.

Then she climbed onto the bed. As Miriam sat up, Rio leaned in and whispered in her ear, “Make it quick.” Then she stripped off the rest of her clothes.

Rio's heart clenched tighter the moment Miriam's fingers made contact with her skin. 

I shouldn't be doing this. It was the only thought looping in Rio's head.

She felt like she was cheating on someone, crossing a line she shouldn't. Then her mind drifted to Agatha.

Fuck! Agatha!

She shouldn't have said all that shit. Mentioning Wanda and that other woman. Acting like Agatha owed her something. She didn't. And what Rio was doing right now—it wasn't any better. If she thought that was bad, somehow, then she was just as bad, if not worse.

She barely registered the moment Miriam's fingers entered her—foreign, unfamiliar to her body. But she did feel the tears slipping down her eyes.

Miriam seemed to notice.

“Fuck, I'm sorry. Did I hurt you?” 

Rio lifted her head, eyes unfocused.

“No, no, it's not you. Fuck, I need to go.” Rio pulled Miriam's fingers out by herself and immediately stood, her movements frantic. “I'm so fucking sorry. You don't deserve this, but I really need to go.” She threw on her clothes in a hurry, not bothering to button a single button. Then she left, shutting the door behind her.

The moment she stepped onto the street and the night air hit her face, the tears came—furious, relentless, hot.

She buttoned half of her shirt with shaky hands, then pulled a cigarette out from her pocket, lit it, and inhaled deeply as she walked, heading home. 

Where was the fucking home?

Two streets away, a black car rolled up beside her, moving slowly.

Rio glanced at it, then she kept walking.

The window lowered.

“Rio...”

She froze mid-step. That voice.

Then she moved with hurried steps, desperate to escape. She couldn't face her. Not like this. Probably never. She couldn't look into Agatha's gorgeous blue eyes. she couldn't look at her—

“Rio, please, just listen to me. Come on!”

Rio didn't answer. Didn't look. But her heart pounded violently in her chest.

The car stopped abruptly. Then the door slammed open. Rio flinched as Agatha got out, slamming it shut behind her. She grabbed Rio's wrist, not tightly, just enough to pull her closer. Close enough to rest a hand on her hip.

“Look at me,” Agatha pleaded. “Please, Rio. Just look at me.”

Rio kept her gaze on Agatha's shoes, unable to meet her eyes.

Agatha sighed, releasing her wrist only to tilt Rio's face up by the chin.

The moment she saw the tears, her thumbs brushed them away.“I'm here, okay?” Agatha murmured. “I'm here, Rio.”

That was it. That was all it took for the dam to break.

Rio sobbed. Tears blurred everything. Her heart was pounding. Her breaths were being caught in her throat. Her chest was heavily rising and falling down.

“I fucked this up, didn't I?”

“No. No, you didn't.”

Agatha pulled her into a hug, resting Rio's head against her chest, holding her securely.

“I'm sorry.” Rio gasped between sobs.

“Shhh. It's okay.”

Minutes passed.

When Rio finally pulled back, she looked down at the tear stains on Agatha's light gray jacket before she hesitantly lifted her gaze up.

Agatha's blue eyes, framed with her glasses, held nothing but concern.

“I'm really sorry, Agatha.”

The moment she said it, fresh tears threatened to spill.

But Agatha cupped her face with both hands in an attempt to steady her.

“I heard you the first time, Rio. And it's okay. We'll talk about this later. But not now, okay?”

Rio only nodded.

Agatha extended her hand. Asking for Rio's hold. “Now come with me?” 

And Rio did, she held Agatha's hand in hers.

“I like your hair,” Agatha said as she tucked a strand behind Rio's ear.

Rio didn't immediately understand what Agatha meant until she reached up to touch her hair with the other hand—only to find it much shorter than it had been earlier. A stunned expression took over her face.

They got into the car. Agatha leaned in to fasten Rio's seatbelt and Rio inhaled deeply, taking in Agatha's heavenly scent, filling her lungs and senses with it.

Before Agatha could pull away, Rio pressed a kiss to her cheek.

Agatha leaned back into her seat, offering Rio a soft smile.

God, her lips looked beautiful. She looked beautiful.

That white tank top under her jacket. Her pale skin. Her exposed cleavage. And fuck—glasses? Agatha was wearing glasses.

It hit Rio then—she hadn't quite registered the object minutes ago, but at that moment? Fuck. Rio felt hot. Agatha was hot. She was.

“You're wearing glasses.” Rio whispered.

Agatha glanced at her after starting the engine.

“Yes. I do, when I'm driving at night,” she said with a smile.

“They make you look even hotter.”

Agatha laughed. “You're adorable, you know that?”

Rio smiled, remembering when Agatha had said the same exact words, at Lilia's house. “Yes, I know.” Rio said, then she shut her eyes as her eyelids grew heavy and her eyes started to burn.

The safety wrapping her wasn't foreign anymore; it was something she always felt with Agatha. 

She didn't know how many minutes had passed when she opened her eyes again and looked around. She was shocked to see Agatha still driving. They should have been at home by now.

“Where are we?”

Agatha glanced at her, smiling softly. “Hey there. I'm taking you to my place.”

“So, are you kidnapping me?”

Agatha chuckled. “No, I'm not. I can drive us back if you want.”

Rio shook her head. “No. Take me with you.”

And she closed her eyes again.

Rio felt it when the car stopped. Felt it when Agatha got out and shut the door behind her.

Then, stillness. For a few seconds, or maybe minutes. The next thing she felt was strong arms lifting her with ease.

Agatha closed the car door with her foot and headed inside. Apparently, she had unlocked the door when the everything stilled a few minutes ago.

Rio buried her face in Agatha's neck. The sensation was too good to be ignored. To not take advantage of.

“I can walk, you know,” she mumbled.

Agatha chuckled.

“I know, baby. Just rest now.”

And Rio felt it—the steady rhythm of Agatha climbing the stairs, carrying her as if she weighed nothing. 

She didn't open her eyes once, too caught up in the warmth, the breathtaking scent, and exhaustion.

Agatha placed her gently on the bed, then she moved to take off Rio's shoes and socks. She held her hip with one hand and tugged at Rio's shoulder with the other.

Rio let out a sleepy “hmm?”

“Can I take your clothes off?” Agatha whispered.

Rio nodded. “Yes.” she whispered.

Agatha's hands roamed over the fabric before she slipped Rio's shirt off. She hadn't expected to be met with bare tanned skin. Agatha looked for a second but her gaze didn't linger. She moved forward, unbuttoning and removing Rio's jeans.

A minute or two passed. Then Agatha returned, dressing Rio in one of her oversized t-shirts. 

Rio was awake—not entirely. Her eyes remained closed, too heavy to open. She was hoverir between consciousness and unconsciousness, but she still felt every movement. Every soft brush and careful touch.

Then Agatha pulled the soft duvet over her body.

Stillness again. No sound at all.

Minutes passed before Rio felt Agatha climb into bed beside her. Without hesitation, she rolled to the side, pressing her body against Agatha's and resting her head on her chest.

Agatha kissed her head. Once. Twice. Then she pulled Rio even closer.

Rio couldn't understand what Agatha murmured before pressing another kiss to her hair as the sound of Agatha's heartbeat lulled her to sleep.

Chapter Eleven

Chapter Notes

I know I'm turning this into some typical lesbian drama, but I won't justify or explain anything Rio or Agatha did. That is just who they are, at least in my head. They're messy. They don't communicate in a healthy way. They're not straightforward. They won't just say what they actually want to say. Because yeah, people need to get used to each other before doing that, but they'll figure it out eventually though.

I know we're going up and down but this is going to have a happy ending.

Falling.
Falling.

She keeps on falling.
Into nothingness.

Trapped in a cycle, isn't she? Unable to distinguish between its ending and starting point.
Perhaps it ended a while ago, and she didn't know, and now she's repeating it all over again.

Falling and falling again.

Rio's heart raced, cold sweat dripping over her body. A ringing sound filled her ears, making her dizzier, creating a nauseating sensation in her stomach, the urge to vomit her soul out.

The sound grew louder and louder, weakening her, making it impossible to comprehend a single thing.

Her breaths were heavy and uneven, as if someone was choking her. She opened her eyes in fear and pain because not a single part of her body was functioning, as if she had lost all control over herself. Her eyes were open but everything was black—nothing but darkness surrounding her. She blinked, then blinked again but to no avail. She was completely frozen, unable to move a finger. Her body shut down, and she was laying somewhere. Was she? Maybe she was floating, or drowning. 

“Hey, hey. Follow my voice, yeah? Just breathe. Try to breathe. I've got you.”

She heard the voice. Tried to make sense of the words passing through the ringing. Some of them blended with it, almost making her ears bleed.

She couldn't quite grasp whose voice it was. Who was holding her? Who's cold touch she could feel little of on her numb body?

“It's okay. You're okay.”

The ringing gradually grew quieter, and her vision started to clear. There was a source of light on her side, blurry and almost too bright, but far better than the baleful darkness that had overwhelmed her eyesight moments ago.

As if someone had removed the weight from her chest, she could inhale properly again. The moment she breathed in, a scent filled her half-working senses and her entire body, Agatha's. That thought was the only clear one in her mind, and it warmed her. Knowing that her head had been resting on Agatha's chest almost the entire time. Knowing that Agatha's arm was supporting her, securing her at the waist. Knowing that the touches she'd felt seconds ago weren't cold, but warm and soothing—warming her chilled skin.

“You're doing really well. Just keep breathing.”

And she did. Rio tried to breathe as Agatha's voice counted softly. With each number, her voice held certainty and reassurance.

Agatha's fingers began stroking her hair gently while holding Rio—as if she was the most precious thing in the world.

The moment Rio regained control over her body and could move her muscles, she lifted her arms higher, reaching for Agatha's middle, holding her tightly as she pressed her head into Agatha's chest. She needed to feel her. To ensure that Agatha was really there and that whatever had gone wrong could be fixed.

“There you go.” 

Agatha's hand, once on her waist, moved higher, drawing invisible, soothing patterns on Rio's back above the fabric. Her other hand continued to stroke her hair gently.

Rio inhaled deeply through her nose, the air was flavored with Agatha, making Rio more awake and aware of everything around her. She pulled back slightly as she exhaled, and was met with Agatha's gleaming eyes, the light beside her was making them glimmer, as if actual stars were in there—making her beautiful eyes even more mesmerizing.

Looking into Agatha's eyes felt like gazing at the blue ocean on a starry night. A night you knew would stick with you forever.

Agatha locked eyes with Rio as she extended her hand to reach for the glass of water on thr nightstand, not breaking the eye contact. Then she held it up for Rio to drink.

Rio hadn't had a panic attack in her sleep for a long time. She thought she had gotten rid of them by doing absolutely nothing. But thinking about it, it was actually that she hadn't slept enough lately to have one. She always woke up before it could even happen. 

The thought of having it now, of all times, made her feel an uneasy sensation growing inside her. Because why?

Before she could overthink the entire situation, Agatha's thumb brushed Rio's lips slightly, as they kept looking at each other while she cupped Rio's cheek. Rio moved her hand and rested it above Agatha's as she whispered.

“I'm sorry.” Her whisper broke the stillness of the night for a brief second.

“Don't apologize.” Agatha's voice was warm and deep as she continued brushing Rio's soft lips, touching them tenderly, which caused Rio's lips to part instinctively.

“How are you feeling?”

“I'm... good now.” Rio answered, still whispering, her eyes remained fixed on Agatha's.

“Do you want to talk about it?” Agatha said as her fingers moved to hold the back of Rio's neck, brushing the little hairs there as Rio's hand dropped slightly to rest on Agatha's wrist.

“Can we do that later?” Rio said, her other hand held Agatha's hip tighter.

“Whenever you want.” Agatha took Rio's hand and pressed a kiss to the back of it.

“Let's get back to sleep?” Agatha suggested and Rio nodded in response.

For minutes, they just kept looking at each other's faces, without moving an inch to actually lie back down. They felt the tender touches as each of their hands rested in different places, soothing the skin beneath.

Then they finally lay down. Bodies pressed against each other. Arms secured around each other's middles. As they tried to be as close as possible, leaving no space between them. Their legs tangled together under the covers as if they were puzzle pieces, fitting perfectly in place.

Their senses were filled with each other's scents. They found peace in the close proximity between them. It felt like home, as if this was the only natural and right thing to do—a place where Rio felt she belonged. In Agatha's presence. In being held by her like this. Almost feeling her running with her blood, in her veins. 

Rio managed to close her eyes, but sleep didn't find its way to her. Minutes passed. Then more minutes, but she couldn't fall asleep. Despite the headache that felt like a time bomb ticking in her skull. Despite how her eyes burned. Despite the peace Agatha's embrace, her steady breaths and heartbeats provided, she couldn't. She felt exhausted, and the only thing she could do was bury her face deeper into Agatha's neck. Feeling the warmth of her skin.

“Don't hold your breath.” Agatha said as her hold around Rio's middle tightened. Rio's heart jumped; she thought Agatha had fallen back asleep because of how quiet she was.

Rio let out a breath she hadn't realized she was holding against Agatha's skin.

“That's better,” Agatha whispered as her fingers moved higher, running through Rio's hair. 

“What's the happiest memory from your childhood?” Rio asked out of nowhere, as her fingers began to wander on Agatha's t-shirt.

Agatha chuckled softly, and Rio smiled at the sound. She lifted her head slightly to be able to look at Agatha. 

“Well, I have a favorite one.” Agatha said after a few seconds as she resumed stroking Rio's hair. “I was seven. My family's house used to be near the woods, and I was allowed to go in there for an hour every weekend. The rule was not to go too deep—there was a mark I wasn't supposed to cross. My mother tied a blue ribbon on one of the trees. But I actually broke that rule every time.” Agatha chuckled, and so did Rio.

“So, one day, I was there singing to our mother nature, pretending to have an audience. I always dreamed of having an audience to watch me. To watch whatever I was doing—even doing the simplest things. So yeah, I was singing, almost certain no one was there. And a woman walked toward me and I froze in my place. Almost had a heart attack, really. I'm easy to get scared. So, then I recognized her—she was our neighbor. So she approached me and asked how I knew this song and she said that I had a lovely voice with the biggest smile on her face, a basket filled with mushrooms in her hand. I told her my mother sang it and she was so happy when I told her that. She told me her mother used to sing the same exact song to her. Then... I sang the same song all the way back home, I'm sure I gave her a headache but she didn't seem to mind in the slightest. She was my only audience. So... This memory is the first thing I think of when I hear the words childhood and happiness together.” Agatha took a breath, kept it in her lungs for a while, then she exhaled deeply. “That woman... she changed my life in a way.”

Rio lifted her head to look directly into Agatha's eyes. The expression she found there was indescribable. Softness and peacefulness.

“You wanted to be a singer?”

“No, not really. I probably did when I was a kid, back when I had a hundred dream jobs,” Agatha said as she gazed at Rio's face with tenderness and care and her hand continued delicately running through Rio's short hair, offering warmth and reassurance.

“What's yours?”

Rio smiled as she started replaying the memory she had in mind when she asked the question in her head. It was a little blurry, so she tried to enhance the images without mixing them.

“My father and I were fishing. I mostly used to sit and watch him, but that time, I decided to try it myself, and I caught my first fish ever. It wasn't big, but I was really happy with it. The moment I felt the rod move in my hands as the fish pulled, I lost my control over it. So... The fish pulled too hard, and I kept pulling forward until I lost my balance and fell into the water. My father hurried to pull me up, but I was only laughing. I ran toward the rod and looked at the fish, at that time... it felt like my biggest victory. I held it in my hands all the way home, just... staring at it. When we got back, I remember lifting it up for my mother to see. I was smiling and soaking wet. I didn't even realize I was shivering until my mother wrapped me in a blanket.” Rio lowered her gaze to Agatha's lips for a brief second before returning to her eyes. “She cooked it for dinner, and it really was the most delicious thing I've ever tasted.”

Agatha smiled in return—a bright smile that could illuminate and warm the whole world, but Rio's heart took it all, felt it all inside her.

“I'm trying to picture a younger you. Did you have short hair?”

Rio slightly shook her head, still smiling. “It was long. I inherited my mother's hair.”

Their eyes stayed locked. Their smiles didn't fade; they only grew wider. The silence was comforting, the air was thick with serenity.

Then the urge surged. The urge to kiss Agatha.

Rio's heart pounded as she leaned in, their lips almost touching. A mixture of emotions rushed through her body, dozens of memories flashing in her mind—the highs and lows of yesterday. Vivid and clear, every sound and image. She wasn't even sure if what she did had been real. It felt unreal.

Her heart raced, her thoughts and feelings were colliding. Instead of placing a hand on her chest to calm herself, she crashed her lips into Agatha's. Took her lips softly at first but then it heated. The kiss was everything. It was an apology. An explanation. A promise. But it was also hurt, guilt, and shame.

Rio pulled her even closer, deepening the kiss, exploring the depths of Agatha's mouth with her tongue. It was intense, and each passing second made her skin burn hotter. Her stomach clenched every time she sucked on Agatha's tongue.

Rio looked at her while trying to catch her own breath.

“Hmm?” She hummed in response.

“We need to talk.” Agatha whispered. Her eyes stayed locked on Rio's, her hands were moving up and down her hips. Their faces were too close.

Rio looked at her.

Yes, they needed to talk. She wandered why had Agatha even let her kiss her in the first place?

Rio nodded, then she lowered herself, sitting back against the headboard. Agatha propped herself up on her elbows, looking at Rio beside her.

There wasn't much light to observe, but she could make out details here and there. The windows were covered with Russian Velvet curtains, allowing little to no moonlight to seep into the room

Despite the room's spaciousness, it wasn't filled with much. An antique Victorian vanity stood against the wall, feeling somewhat out of place. A few boxes sat stacked in the corner.

A dim light flickered from what Rio assumed was the walk-in wardrobe.

She wandered the room for quite some time, feeling Agatha's eyes on her. Finally, Rio turned and met her gaze. A second later, Agatha sat beside her, taking Rio's hand in hers and looking at it. 

“Are you hungry?”

“No.”

“Do you want something?”

“Some coffee would be really great. And I really need to go to the bathroom.”

“Okay, come on then,” Agatha said, pressing a kiss to the back of Rio's hand.

“What?” Agatha asked.

“Nothing.” Rio's smile turned into a wide smirk.

At that, Rio burst into laughter. “I really tried to give you the least weird t-shirt I had.”

A half-opened door caught her attention. She walked past it, then instinctively took a few steps back. Standing in the doorway, Rio peered inside, only able to see what the angle of the door allowed. Agatha's studio.

She stepped inside without pushing the door open any further.

Her eyes scanned the finished paintings—faces she didn't recognize, abstracts she couldn't analyze properly with her headache. Empty canvases filled most of the space, alongside boxes overflowing with supplies.

As she turned to leave, her gaze landed on a painting she knew all too well.

Hers.

It leaned against the white wall, her features were captured in oil paint, every detail was perfectly placed, as if she were looking into a mirror. Rio stepped closer. Looking closer. Her neck and collarbone were exposed, her skin tone matched precisely, and her dark hair cascaded down her back. She hadn't notice those details the first time she saw the painting—because they hadn't been there before. The rest of the painting remained unfinished, or perhaps it was meant to be that way.

Her fingers traced over the brushstrokes of her face as she stared in quiet awe.

Rio's mouth ran dry.

She recognized the pose immediately. 

Yesterday morning, when Agatha had asked her to lift her leg.

She swallowed hard, her eyes lingered on the careful attention given to the curves of her body in the sketch. Oh. God.

Was that something she wasn't supposed to see? Too late. She had seen it, and now she felt like she might actually faint.

She set her mug down, staring at the steam raising up. She hoped Agatha would speak—ask something, say something, anything to break the tension. But she knew Agatha was waiting.

Waiting for her to be ready to talk.

She did?

Oh. Yes, she actually did say that.

At first, Rio thought he was a girl—but looking closer, she realized he was a little boy. His brown hair was pulled back in a ponytail, a few strands were falling behind his ear. He was gazing off to the side. Rio couldn't quite tell what he was looking at.

She turned around to glance at Agatha who was organizing boxes, then Rio looked back to the boy in the painting.

He looked like Agatha—not in the shape, but in a way Rio couldn't quite place. But that boy looked like her. 

She was about to move away and stare at something else when she felt Agatha standing beside her. Rio heard the deep breath Agatha exhaled before she spoke

“This is Nicholas. My baby boy.” Agatha extended her hand to brush the boy's cheek with her knuckles as if he were really there. But Agatha was only wishing to stroke his soft skin. To feel him by her side.
