“He... we were on our way to a basketball game, his favorite team. He was sitting beside me, singing his favorite song when a drunk driver crashed into us on a one-way road. It happened in the blink of an eye. And my baby... he died immediately.” Agatha's eyes remained fixed on Nicky's portrait. “I try to paint him every now and then... because... God, I'm really afraid of forgetting his face. His innocent  features.”

Rio heard the way Agatha sniffled, chocking back tears. So she placed a gentle hand on her shoulder.

Rio felt the way her heart sank. Hearing this broke her. Agatha's grief was woven in every word she spoke—every sob she tried to swallow. And it was heartbreaking to witness. And it made it even more sorrowful was the fact that Agatha was feeling it. She felt it not just witnessed it.

Agatha turned to the side and looke at Rio. Her eyes were glassy, her nose tinged with pink—but no tears fell. As if she was fighting to hold them back.

“I'm so sorry about your loss Agatha.” Their eyes met. “I won't tell you that it's okay or that it will pass. Or that it will... get easier with time. Because it won't. You'll probably never figure out how to deal with something like that. Because once it happens, you feel lost. Like you're running through a maze with no exit in sight.”

Rio took Agatha's hand and enclosed it between both of hers, her gaze dropping to their hands as she continued, “You know... when people leave, their seats remain empty. And nothing in the world can fill them. We shouldn't even try to fill them. They're not meant to be filled. They should stay that way, as remainders—as memories to the beauty of remembering who once sat there. The people we still love so dearly... but who... had to leave.” Rio lifted her gaze up at Agatha—who was staring down at their hands while listening to Rio.

“I know it's heavy. It doesn't get lighter over time. It never does. But I guess... in a way, we just get used to the weight. We become capable of holding it on our shoulders. It becomes something... familiar—not necessarily easy, or good in any way. Just... known.”

“Yeah. Guess you're right.” Was the only response Agatha offered. Her eyes stayed locked on Rio's hands wrapped around hers. 

After a few seconds, she looked up and met Rio's gaze. She smiled—a soft smile that didn't reach her eyes. It was wounded, Rio could recognize that kind of smile. Rio knew it.

“I'll stay here, I've got a lot to do. Make yourself at home.”

“Can I stay here? If that's okay?”

“Of course.” Agatha leaned in and stole a soft kiss from Rio's lips before she lifted one of Rio's hands and kissed the back of it as their eyes met.

They stayed at the studio for about an hour. They didn't talk much, just little comments here and there.

But their eyes met constantly.

Rio would glance at Agatha only to find her already looking. And every time, her heart clenched in her chest.

She wandered around the studio, feeling as if she were in an art gallery. Each piece was beautiful in its own way—different, yet all sharing something in common. Agatha's touches.

She kept returning to that portrait. The one that filled her with many emotions at once. Every time she looked at it, she noticed something new—little details, nearly invisible. But they were there. Scattered all over her figure and around it.

When they finally left the studio, Rio changed back into her previous clothes from the night before—the black button-up shirt and black jeans. This time, she buttoned everything expect the top two ones. She grabbed her phone, checked it, then slipped it into her pocket with the rest of her things

Agatha made tea for them both as Rio stared at her with a big smile while she sat down, then they headed to the living room. 

“You've got a lot of interesting films in here. Queer and witchy stuff.” Rio pointed out with a chuckle. “Fascination 1979? That's some heavy stuff.”

“You've seen it?” Agatha asked from her spot on the couch.

Rio turned around, holding the copy of the film in her hand. “Yeah, a few years ago.” She continued looking through the collection. “I like this one,” she added, holding up The City of The Dead 1960 to show it to Agatha.

Agatha smiled. “One of my favourites.” She took a sip of her green tea, then she continued, “Looks like I'm not the only one interested in witchcraft,” she said with a smirk.

Rio chuckled. “I watch everything, really—so long as it interests me.”

She closed the glass cabinet door, slid her hands into her pockets and walked toward Agatha.

“Will you go on a date with me?” Rio asked as she stood in front of the wooden coffee table, her eyes looking at Agatha—who was already watching her with dark, gleaming eyes.

It was about time, Rio thought. She wanted to go on a date with Agatha—a real one. 

Agatha smirked as she set her cup down, her gaze never leaving Rio's.

“Yes, Rio. I'd love to.” The smirk didn't fade, it only deepened and grew more intense, making Rio's heart tighten in her chest. Whatever Agatha was thinking, Rio wanted to know.

“What's that look?”

“What look?”

“That look, Agatha.”

Agatha laughed. “It's nothing.”

Rio narrowed her eyes. “It's wicked.”

“Okay.” Agatha laughed again, softer this time. It was so sweet and sparked a heated flutter in Rio's stomach.

“I'll pick the right place for us,” Agatha stood up to face Rio. “You just have to wear that dress for me. I want  to see it again on you.” Her hand reached out to Rio's jaw—only the small table was between them.

Rio felt her heart plummet to her stomach, right alongside all the heat pooling there.

“Yeah?” Agatha tilted Rio's face up by the chin and stared into her eyes. She licked her lips as her pupils dilated.

Rio was certain their lips were about to crash, but Agatha's next words made her eyes widen even more.

“I was planning to give you your reward. The one I promised before you fell asleep, remember? But now I can't, unfortunately. We should go on an official date first. Don't you think?”

“That's not fair.” Rio pleaded.

“Oh, I know.” Agatha chuckled.

She walked around the table, her fingers were still hooked on Rio's chin, and then she kissed her—hot and deep. A soft moan slipped from Rio's lips.

“That's all you get. For now.” Agatha announced as she brushed Rio's lips with her thumb.

“You're being mean.” Rio whispered. Her voice was low. Her eyes keot darting between Agatha's dilated pupils and her tempting mouth.

Agatha only laughed, a breathy, wicked sound. Then she leaned even closer. “Let's get you home,” she murmured softly while brushing her lips along Rio's earlobe. Her words burned against Rio's skin. “Though... I don't know why you insist on going home.”

Rio closed her eyes. The teasing was overwhelming—but, oh god, how it made her shiver.

The way it made her feel the blood racing through her vines. The way it made her heart pound. The heated waves that pooled down between her thighs. Agatha's warm breath. Her words against her skin. The wicked promises lying beneath. 

It all made her feel alive. 

“I can get a cab. I don't want to trouble you,” Rio breathlessly suggested.

So Agatha clicked her tongue then she leaned in and gently bit Rio's earlobe before. “You're not troubling me, honey. And it's not about the car—it's about you leaving my sight.”

Her words scorched Rio's skin and made her knees slightly tremble.

“God... Fuck, Agatha... are you going to do something?” Rio helplessly asked—her voice was low and trembling. Pleading.

Agatha pulled back to look at her smirking sinisterly.

“Sorry about that. I'm just going to get my jacket.” She turned around and walked away. Her hips swayed with lethal precision. If it lasted any longer, Rio thought, it could've killed her.

She collapsed onto the couch with a heavy sigh.

When Agatha returned, wearing a black jacket and those goddamn glasses, Rio melted. She just stared at Agatha, who smirked—fully aware of the effect she had on Rio—poor Rio—but Rio didn't give her the satisfaction. She kept all the inappropriate comments to herself and settled on just looking hungerily at her. Trying so desperately to dismiss the fact that she wanted to be fed so badly.

They arrived at Rio's house.

It was around four in the morning. The sky was still cloaked in darkness, only the streetlights illuminating the roads.

Rio unfastned her seatbelt and looked to her side. To Agatha. “Thank you,” she said sincerely as her hand reached for the door. 

But Agatha's soft grip on her wrist stopped her. Rio turned—and Agatha leaned in to kiss her, pouring every drop of tenderness into it. It was sweet and gentle.

When they pulled back, Agatha stroked Rio's cheek with her thumb.

“Take care of yourself, Rio. And please call me.”

“I will. You take care too,” Rio replied, then she got out.

She waved her goodbye and her eyes kept following Agatha's car until it disappeared into the fog.

Then, from her back pocket, she pulled out the pack of cigarettes and a lighter.

She lit one and smoked it to the butt as the cold morning breeze tousled her hair.

Chapter Thirteen

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Rio put her stuff on the desk. She was breathless and her face was flushed red, trying to ignore the way the students looked at her with different expressions on their faces. Aside from being fifteen minutes late, she looked like she had just ran a marathon—thanks to Agatha of course 

Earlier, while she was dressing for the day ahead, her phone buzzed on her bed. She hurried to check on it, and her face lit up upon seeing a message from Agatha.

Have a good day xx.

Rio smiled foolishly. She just knew her day was going to be good.

When she arrived at her office and was about to leave to start her class, her phone buzzed in her pocket. She pulled it out and a message from Agatha was waiting for her.

Are you at work?

Rio replied, and the moment she wrote “Yes, I am.” and sent it, Agatha followed up with a photo. A photo that made Rio weak in the knees.

“Oh fuck me!” Rio muttered to herself as she dropped her stuff on the couch and sat down.

Agatha's chest and pale skin were right in front of her eyes to devour. The photo was cropped so that Agatha's face and nipples were out of frame, but that didn't stop Rio from drooling over her exposed skin—over the fading hickey marks Rio had left the other day. She thought about sucking on them all over again.

The way Agatha’s throat begged for attention, her damn collarbones, her wild dark hair cascading down behind her back…

Or maybe fuck professionalism, because she had never been in a situation like this before to know what the hell to do. Maybe she should have thrown her thoughts and hesitation to the wall and just fucked herself while looking at that goddamn photo.

I would've told you to not touch yourself, but I know you wouldn't (;

That was the message Rio saw in the notification bar.

The heat inside her only increased and she was so goddamn helpless. She stayed like that, sitting and staring without doing anything, hoping things would calm down eventually. Spoiler: they didn't. Because her fantasies were stronger than her will.

So yeah, being breathless and flushed red early in the morning had a reason. She wouldn't be panting in a classroom out of nowhere. Would she now?

The two-hour lecture was kind of a hell. Torment.

Her mind kept drifting back to that photo. She paused mid-speech constantly, but somehow, that didn't stop her from being the good teacher that she was and delivering the material as intended. Despite her negligence over the past five months, Rio was pretty damn good at her job. Her reputation was built on being someone who filled the gaps, honed the daggers, and remained the knowledgeable prof with the strong voice. Which were the things that made her gain her respect—and also were the things her personal life lacked.

As she locked her office and was about to leave, trying to escape as fast as possible, she stopped mid-step as she remembered that she owed Alice a visit—one that she decided would be as fast as possible. So Rio turned on her heel and headed to Alice's office down the hallway.

She knocked the Rio's knock—two fast taps with the middle phalanges of her index and middle fingers, followed by a third one. 

“Come on in,” came Alice's sharp voice.

Rio pushed the door open. She glanced at Alice, then her eyes drifted up to look at Agatha's painting hanging above the maroon couch. It made her smile this time. Not overwhelmed.

“Hey, you wanted to talk to me about something?” Rio asked as she took a seat and crossed her legs.

Alice looked at her, peering over her glasses.

“Last time I checked, people say how are you to their friends and they wait for an invention to sit down.”

Rio poked the inside of her cheek with the tip of her tongue as she shoot Alice a go on, lay it all look.

“You fucking bitch,” Alice said as she placed the papers she'd been holding on the desk.

“Woah, hold on!” Rio said with half a chuckle. 

“Yeah? Cause I thought you were fucking dead!”

“Don't be dramatic! Oh my god, I just took the day off!”

“You just took the day off, didn't you? Seriously? Every week I think you're fucking dead Rio! You don't see anyone. You don't talk to anyone and literally no one knows anything about you or where you are. So excuse me for thinking that you were dead after calling you dozens of fucking times in the span of twenty-four hours until you finally picked up late at night not even knowing what the fucking time it was!” 

“Okay, okay. Fair enough,” Rio said with a smile, throwing her hands in the air, gladly offering her defeat. “But I told you I was asleep didn't I? And here I am, alive and breathing.”

“Yeah, I can see that.” 

“Yeah? Then how are you, Alice?”

“None of your business, Vidal.”

“What a hypocrite.”

Alice laughed, clearly cooling off. “I'm fine. Great, even.”

“Great. How's Jen?”

“She's fine. But god, I haven't seen her in a week. I'm kind of on the edge of sanity.”

“Where is she? Also, you're already insane, so I won't worry about that.”

“She's in Greece, doing some work. Also, shut the fuck up, will you?” Alice said as she got up and sat beside Rio.

“Ah, so you're suffering suffering?”

“Yes, Rio.”

“Well, you wanted to talk with me about something. What is it?”

“Oh, yeah, I want the photo albums you have. Technically, all of them.” Alice continued speaking as Rio shot her a death stare. “I won't ruin them I promise! I just want to do something and I'll return them.”

“Alright, but I swear if you—”

“I won't!” 

“Good. That's all?”

“No... I, uh, I saw Jane here yesterday.”

Rio's expressions changed immediately upon hearing that name. Because holy fucking shit.

“What? That fucking bitch...”

“Yeah. And the Irony of it all, she literally asked me if I knew where you were.”

“What did you tell her?”

“Well, I obviously pretended she doesn't exist. Like hello?” 

Rio went silent for a few minutes. Jane had always been creepy, but she’d never dared come to Rio's work or ask her friends anything. Clearly Rio had underestimated her. Once a creep, always a creep.

“Has she been approaching you?” Alice asked as she watched Rio zoning out.

“No,” Rio dismissed immediately. And Alice didn't push any further. Either she sounded too convincing or too dismissive, one of them did the job.

They drove to Rio's house separately, as Rio's head was bouncing from one thing to another during the ride—but the main event was Agatha's photo. She couldn't get it out of her head, and every time it crossed her mind, a renewed heat would pool between her legs and settle in her stomach. As much as it felt unpleasant and she wanted to hurry up and get rid of it, it also gave her a strange sense of being alive in a way. Of being present in the moment. Of being able to feel something oh so delicious.

Because she couldn't even recall when was the last time a goddamn photo made her feel that way. When was the last time she got that much pleasure from burning from the inside, and down between her thighs.

Once they arrived, Rio opened the door and stepped inside with Alice following behind—who's phone was glued to her ear and a bright smile was lighting up her face.

“I'm with Rio now, I'll call you later,” Alice said as Rio handed her a cold beer from the fridge.

“I love you too, babe. Take care.”

Rio smiled at her as she took the first sip from the bottle, eyes gleaming with a shit-eating grin.

“What?” Alice asked, tossing her phone into her pocket. The smile stayed on her face, pushing her cheeks all the way up.

“I gotta go see my dentist, ‘cause you guys are sickly sweet.”

“That sounded cheesy as fuck, Rio.” Alice said with a chuckle.

Rio only grinned as she took another sip. There were only a few things that truly made her happy—seeing Alice like that was definitely one of them.

“Anyway, have you changed anything here? It looks different.”

“Yeah, I took the Christmas tree to the basement.”

“You haven't had a Christmas tree in three years.”

“Yeah? Guess nothing changed then.”

“Asshole.”

Rio went to the living room to grab the few photo albums she kept there. Then she headed to her bedroom, where a few smaller ones sat in a box alongside some stuff from her high school and early college years—such as a little ceramic dragonfly, a worn-out journal, a golden cup that -She gives A head!- written under it (a silly birthday gift from Alice that Rio loved way too much), and a lyric notebook plastered with punk bands stickers on its cover and scribbled THE SCISSORS in bold letters across the front.

Then she headed down to the basement, where Alice was digging like it was a thrift shop.

“You still keep all those energy drink cans?”

“I'm a collector, Alice.” Rio said with a laugh, like she didn't believe it herself.

“Why do you even keep the albums down here ?”

“Nostalgia is a beast, darling,”

“Guess I should keep them with me then.”

“Yeah? What would you do with my parents' photos?” Rio said with a chuckle, but the look on Alice’s face was one of someone who caught off guard and left speechless. So Alice kept looking through the boxes until she found the ones she'd been looking for.

One of the albums was black, its cover decorated with polaroid photos of their old band members—their shirts were lifted up and their tongues stuck out of their mouths, on their chests were glued handmade stickers which were badly drawn boobs and their signatures were scrawled beneath each one.

Alice let out a weird sound that should’ve been a laugh and it made Rio laugh in response.

“God, we were fucking wild!” Alice let out a chuckle, as the look in her eyes screamed nostalgia.

“Don't you miss these two?” She asked, referring to Ella and Chris. 

“Not really.” Rio said as she set her beer down and leaned closer to take a better look. 

“I mean high school them, not when they turned out to be bitches,” Alice clarified.

“Yeah… well, kinda. I don't really think about them.”

“Me neither. Anyway, I can't wait to show these to Jen.”

“Put a shirt on me first.”

“You should’ve put it on yourself, perv.”

They looked through more photos and talked for a few more minutes, mostly Rio throwing in rotten mom jokes or dirty one-liners whenever she had the chance. Typical Rio behavior.

Alice told her to stop disappearing. Told her to call or text because it won't kill her. Then they hugged goodbye.

Maybe Alice didn't know it because Rio didn't show it that much—but her presence always brought joy to Rio. The way their relationship only seemed to bond, no matter how much distance got between them. No matter how distant Rio got. Because Alice was truly the only person Rio ever called a friend. For almost three decades, they’d understood each other. Been there during all the highs and the lows. Protecting each other’s backs.

So maybe Rio didn't express it much, but she was thankful for Alice. For being in her life and for staying in it despite everything.

Rio threw herself on the couch and lay there as the second bottle of beer found its way into her hand. She took her phone out, and the second she unlocked it, she was met with Agatha’s photo.

“God, Agatha…” She whispered in a low, breathy murmur. She set the bottle down and in the next second her thumb and index fingers zoomed in. She took the photo with her eyes. Quite literally. 

Rio licked her lips, once then twice, before swallowing hard when she scrolled down to see the message Agatha had sent earlier.

I would've told you to not touch yourself, but I know you wouldn't (; 

Rio knew Agatha could be really daring in such contexts, that much was obvious, and it thrilled Rio. But for some reason, she didn't think she'd go there—there in the sense of asking if she was at work so she could send a photo of herself and make sure that Rio couldn't do a thing with that goddamn winky face because Agatha knew exactly what she was doing and how much effect she had on Rio.

Rio’s hand drifted down to the button of her pants. She opened it and pulled the zipper down. The first moan that escaped her lips was one of awe, a reaction to how fucking soaked she was.

She started touching herself while staring at that photo with hunger in her eyes. She shut her eyes, and her mind began to drift to kissing that throat. To kissing and sucking that pale, captivating skin. To leave her marks all over it again. To feel Agatha’s fingers instead of her own…

She threw the phone to the side to lie beside her on the couch as she felt her orgasm building, ready to tear through her and flood her body with pleasure. 

Just as she was on the verge of receiving the reward she so desperately wanted and deserved, her phone buzzed beside her, making her snap her eyes open immediately. Irritated. Her hand stilled but remained in place. She cursed under her breath, grabbed her phone and looked at the name on the screen.

Her mouth went dry.

Agatha. And it wasn't just a call, Agatha was video calling.

Rio sat up immediately. She blinked at the screen, then hurried to her feet. She drank some water in an attempt to steady her breathing and calm herself down. After a moment, she sat back down, took off her blazer, closed the first two buttons of her shirt, then unbuttoned them again with a bonus one. She tucked a few strands of hair behind her ear. When she grabbed her phone and was about to swipe to answer, it fell silent between her hands. The screen was filled once more with Agatha’s photo.

“Goddamn it,” She muttered.

She considered calling back, and the moment the thought gained momentum, Agatha’s message came through:

Sorry about that.

Then another one.

Would you believe me if I told you my phone fell down and decided to call you on its own? 

Rio laughed, because yeah, that was believable. It happened to her once when she was mid-watching Angels in America in the bath, and her phone fell down and called the group chat she was in. Alice had answered in the same exact second. Thank god it was Alice and not someone else.

Yes, I'd believe it. But was that the only reason?

Rio waited a few minutes for Agatha’s response while finishing the last of her beer. But Agatha didn't reply. So, Rio just got up, changed her clothes, and crashed into bed—resuming what had been interrupted.

“This piece was inspired by my own journey of excavation. My own grave digging to see if the mothers were truly dead.” Agatha responded to the reporter’s question. “... I can say that it's layered, and... it needs its own excavation.” She said with a soft, honest smile before she answered another question and the video ended.

Excavation of the Dying Mothers (2005).

The painting Agatha was talking about.

Four female figures sat around a wide table. They shared the same clothes and hair—but their faces lacked features. They seemed like they were arguing or discussing something. The way each one held a cross in her hand and pointed it at the other suggested they weren’t having a casual conversation.

The dominant colors were dark browns and blacks, with deep, shadowy hues filling most of the canvas. Muted greens and grays were visible in the depiction of the figures' bodies and the table they sat at. Pale yellows and whites were used for the faint, eerie light that emanated from shattered candles—illuminating the old women's blurry faces—making them look even more haunting. The Chiaroscuro effect heightened the focus on the faceless figures. Making them the clear focal point of the scene.

The painting was… allusive. Evocative. Haunting.

Rio found the four-minute-long YouTube video as she struggled to fall asleep. Agatha was sitting, and that painting hung on a dark wall behind her.

The video looked much older than 11 years ago—the publishing date. It looked older, like the mid-2000s or so.

Lying on her side, phone almost glued to her eyes, Rio watched that video five times or maybe more. Who was really counting? 

Every time the screen faded to darkness, she would go back to the beginning and rewatch it all over again. She paused several times to look at Agatha. To just… stare at her features and listen to her voice. And each time Rio gazed at her, something stirred inside her.

Why hadn’t Agatha responded yet? It had been seven hours, and Rio’s mind was beginning to drift.

So, with sleep eluding her and Agatha not responding, Rio got to her feet and headed downstairs. She grabbed the bottle of vodka and shuffled her I'll break my spine: the playlist playlist.

I Want Your (Hands on Me) by Sinéad O'Connor started playing, making Rio tap her foot to the first beat and sway her body immediately. 

By the time I Think I'm Paranoid by Garbage came on, a cigarette found its way between her lips. Each puff of smoke was followed by a gulp of alcohol.

She kept dancing and drinking as the music kept playing in the background. Mixed rhythms, mixed lyrics.

Inertia Creeps by Massive Attack, Kool Thing by Sonic Youth, Hall of Ice by Lebanon Hanover, We Hunger by Siouxsie and the Banshees, Dancing With Myself by Billy Idol and other songs she knew by heart. The vodka bottle lost more than half of its content, and the third cigarette rested unlit between her lips.

And that was how Rio's night went. It ended with her sleeping on the couch in the dimly lit space as the music faded from her ears. 

Electric blue eyes
Where did you come from?

Electric blue eyes
Who sent you?

Electric blue eyes
Always be near me

Electric blue eyes
I need you

She crashed out, completely wasted.

When Rio woke up, she felt out of place. Unaware of anything except the headache that was about to explode her head off. She spent half an hour sitting on the couch, trying to make sense of whatever the fuck had happened hours ago. She looked around the space. Two bottles of vodka lay on the floor—one of them drained and dead, and the other was standing still. Her t-shirt was discarded on the floor—when did that happen?

She scanned the room with her burning eyes, as the hammering in her head became even more relentless.

She lifted her gaze to the side and found her phone lying on the edge of the coffee table. It was 3 pm, thank god it was Saturday.

A message from Alice and two from Agatha.

Her heart beat harder and quicker. She closed her eyes briefly and tried to make sense of the situation. 

She had a date with Agatha today. A real fucking date with the woman who had been living in her head. They had discussed it on the drive home and agreed on Saturday night.

She was the one who brought it up and asked, yet, she felt an anxious rush flood through her, making her overwhelmed.

A date. Huh.

The last date she'd decided on go on had mentally and emotionally imprisoned her for four fucking years. It had abused her in different ways, and it crippled her.

Yeah, it was sweet at first, for about nine months, but things started getting haunting and weird afterward. She couldn't blame the date itself though. She was the one to blame. She was the one who chose to go on a date with a fucking psychopath. Maybe she didn't know at first, but she stayed for years even after she knew.

Five months ago, she broke up with Jane. And now, here she was.

So going on a date was a big deal. A really big deal.

Maybe things would go wrong, what would happen next?

If there was something Rio didn't want to fuck up, with all the honesty and the sincerity in the world, it was this. The thing she had with Agatha. The undefined relationship. The strange connection. She didn't want to fuck this up.

She read Alice’s message:

Do you plan on isolating yourself today or do you want to go out?

isolating myself is always the right option, Alice, dear. But i actually have plans today, so maybe tomorrow?

Then her heart pounded in her chest as she clicked on Agatha’s chat.

Hey, sorry, something urgent came up and I was busy. But to answer your question, no, it wasn't the only reason, I wanted to call you. 

Agatha had sent this message hours ago when Rio was busy drinking and fighting her demons.

Good morning. You're still up for tonight, yeah? I'll pick you up at 7:30, if that's okay with you.

Rio stared at the screen, a soft smile finding its way to her lips. But the way her heart was still pounding made her anxious, why was it beating so loudly over a text?

She typed Good morning three times in a row and it made her frustrated, until she finally managed writing the Good afternoon

Good afternoon. Yeah that's okay with me. Looking forward for tonight.

With the few hours she had, Rio managed to tidy up the place, eat something to silence her empty stomach, take a shower, and stare into nothingness.

With meals cooked from hands she had begun to worship, meals that tasted better than any time before because they were shared with the person that made Rio’s heart race in her chest.

With smiling mid-lectures as she remembered her. With dates that started outdoors with the delicious warm smell of a cinnamon roll surrounding them, and ended indoors, with hot heavy breaths and the smell of pleasure filling the atmosphere.

It was a week filled with everything Rio hadn’t even dared to dream of, because these things were so out of reach that she forgot they even existed. Then, with a flick of her fingers, Agatha was there, handing them to Rio with a smile, asking her not to dream but to take because she deserved.

And Rio found herself wondering, since when waking up started to be a thing she looked forward to? And she would look to her side and see the answer lying there, an answer shaped as a woman, as an ethereal being. 

Since Agatha.

Just like after a storm the night before, Rio opened the windows to look at the ruins the sky caused, only to be met with the sun shining and illuminating the world. Apologizing and trying to fix something it wasn't the one who broke.

Look at me, just look at me.
I pine for you even when you're within my reach.

When she got back to her home that day, the discomfort of it was nowhere to be sensed. Because Rio’s haven was filled with Agatha now. Her touches lingered everywhere. Glimpses of her changed the place down from its foundation.

Her scent filled the air. That purple clay mug she made herself and gave to Rio set on the coffee table. Separating with someone. Separating with her loved ones. She experienced that, too many times to be counted. And it never ended well for her.

Whether the separation was on good terms or the complete opposite of that.

Whether it was lying in a tent and the distance was only a few steps, or continents away.

It never ended well, and that was why her heart was pounding and Rio's entire body and mind were plagued with paranoia mixed with panic and traumatic memories.

Chapter Seventeen

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Somebody good shouldn't feel so bad
Well, I must've done something to deserve to feel this sad

Was it jealousy or her fear of being cheated on again?

The fear of someone finding out that she was unworthy. Undeserving. And below it all. The fear of repeating it all again. The fear of seeing someone leaving. Walking out against her will. And she'd be sitting, like always, expected to move on.

She couldn't even distinguish that. The lines blurred, and so did her ability to be coherent. To know.

None of it was real.

It was just in her head.

Everything she was thinking about right now was nothing but her rotting mind’s way to get her. To push her sanity to the edge.

And Rio? She knew that.

But did she?

Did she know, as she lay on her front. Naked, drunk, her head was thudding, floating with no destination to reach.

Still feeling like she was getting away from everything.

Feeling herself as nothing but plaguing thoughts glued together.

Lying on Agatha’s side of the bed. Letting the sheets consume her body whole. Burying her face in the pillow and inhaling Agatha’s lingering scent.

Blurry images befogged her.

Agatha on that beige hotel room couch. She was lying one second, and the next, she would be sitting straight. Visualization Agatha being touched by a woman. A woman that wasn't her. A woman that didn't have a face Rio could even recognize. It was a mix of every painting Agatha’s hands had crafted. Every face Rio saw in them. And they were haunting.

The faces blended and blurred together. The features moved constantly, just like how the fingers constantly brushed Agatha’s skin.

The images were a melting wax dripping down onto Rio’s head, scorching and merciless.

Her head was ticking like a time bomb. Feeling like her skull might just explode at any moment. And there wasn't any right wire to cut. They were all black and would explode, whether they were cut or not.

She wanted to get up and just bang her head into a wall and make it all stop.

But she wasn't even able to move her body.

But she knew.

It was not real.

It couldn't be.

Agatha was talking with her two hours ago. She was there. Until she wasn't. 

Until Rio was staring at the screen and Agatha was nowhere to be seen. Only the picture of her. The thought of her was floating in Rio’s mind.

Agatha smiled at her, that beautiful smile of hers. The smile that illuminated what was around, even in the pitch darkness of the night.

They looked into each other’s eyes.

Their chests were heavy. Rising and falling constantly. Lungs rushing to be filled with air.

“I love your golden eyes, Rio.”

Rio felt her heart fall down into her stomach.

And suddenly, all the things she wanted to say minutes ago were pulled down into the void, and her head went blank. Swept completely.

She just sat there against the headboard, with her flushed face and heavy breaths. Staring at Agatha.

She Looked into her eyes, they were glinting, just like the stars in the sky above her head.

Despite the silence that hung between them, Rio’s head was anything but. Her ears were filled with the sound of her heart racing inside her chest. Knocking. Banging forcefully, as if it were begging to get out. Unable to handle all of this.

And as the minutes passed and the silence stretched, Rio felt herself getting filled with emotions as she kept staring into Agatha’s eyes through the screen.

Through the distance.

Emotions she didn't dare think about when she was sober and alone, let alone feel them. Say them out loud.

Neither of them uttered a single word. Just… staring.

Making her irises lighter, surrounding her dilated dark pupils. The bright afternoon sunlight reflected the flower shapes sewn into the curtain. Their shadows painted on Rio’s tanned skin.

A faint one stamped on the side of her jaw. Another resting lower on her pulse point. Two others scattered, one on her breast and a fading one lying lower.

Her collarbones were as sharp as her lethal jaw. The night breeze helped dry her wet hair, making a few of its dark locks curl into each other, into waves.

And she was staring at Rio, with her gleaming eyes.

As the sun reflected its light on Rio’s body, the moon reflected the sun’s light on Agatha’s.

“Did something happen, Rio?”

She exhaled, and just... stared.

She leaned in to grab the bottle of alcohol from beside her.

“Baby, can you put that down and talk to me? Tell me what's wrong?” Agatha said the moment the mouth of the bottle touched Rio’s lips. Her voice was still soft, almost pleading, and yet, it commanded.

But Rio didn't listen. She closed her eyes and gulped, twice, then she placed the bottle down. 

She wiped her lips with her thumb as she looked into Agatha’s eyes.

Did something happen?

How could she possibly know and talk about it with Agatha when she herself didn't know?

When she was struggling to hang on to one single thought in the middle of all this?

She looked at the door behind Agatha from a distance.

But Agatha didn't, she was just looking at Rio.

Rio couldn't hear properly, and even if she did, she wouldn't have understood.

Then a third knock.

And she heard Agatha’s name, called through a whine.

Another ex.

“I'm sorry baby. I'll just go and see what she wants, I'll be right back.”

Rio couldn't understand the language on its own, let alone when it was drunk French.

Feeling too many emotions at the same time and none of them was pleasant. They were all nauseating.

Or did she untie it?

From Agatha.

The annoying car horns beeping. The night wind hitting the speaker. And the sound of the drunken chuckles.

They all filled Rio’s ears.

It hurt.

It hurt.

Because it hurt.

It really did.

And almost all the lights were off.

The sound held nostalgia.

As if the clock itself held Rio’s childhood inside.

That same clock that was hanging on the wall of the living room she spent her best memories in. The same sound that ticked in her ears as she went back to the empty house to gather the stuff she considered as extremely important. The same old clock that she didn't know how its battery stayed alive for a long time. The clock she used to go down to the basement in her aunt’s house only to listen to its ticking because it was soothing. And it was one of the few things she took with her to the first apartment she had ever rented with Alice.

Back then, her future looked way different than the present now. The potential everyone saw in her faded as the years went by, and the ticking stayed as it is.

She will do better.

Chapter Eighteen

when a mother loses her child, the pain she'd feel would be double—worse than the pain she felt during labor. During giving birth, while witnessing her entrails being cut. She'd feel the pain mentally. Her head would bleed constantly. And the child would be swallowed by the head rather than pushed from the womb.

The little body ceased to exist, but the memories still exist. Haunting, horrifying, as sharp as a butcher’s knife, constantly cutting flesh. Constantly munching with bloody teeth.

But what does it feel like when a child loses the mother?

When a child loses the connection to the world?

When the soil is nowhere to be spotted and the plant is lying, petals torn, and the roots don't have a place to plant themselves in? Don't have the ability to grow?

Not feeling alive.

A child would feel like they had never lived, and yet, their body is still carrying the memories of a life that once had been lived. Memories that don't feel real at all, but they're there. Gnawing, feeding on the misery.

When a child loses their mother, they would feel like their coronary arteries are cut off, no blood reaching their heart. The heart won't be pounding. The body won't be functioning. But the brain would still be there, no blood reaching it, but still functioning on the misery of the memories. Squeezes the sorrow and quenches its thirst with it.

Then, would it matter to find the lost piece of the puzzle when there is no longer a board to place it on?

Would it matter to reach the water when you feel like a fish, thrown on the island, thrashing?

 

“The court finds the defendant not guilty.” 

The words landed on Rio’s ears.

“Court is adjourned.”

And the one single bang of the judge’s gavel banged in her head. Rang in her ears—then silence followed.

The entire place looked like a TV that just got turned on and the only thing Rio was able to hear was the static noise. Everyone around her looked like the tiny black dots, surrounding her and floating in front of her eyes.

The lawyer beside her embraced her little body with warm hands. Her aunt by her side leaned down to her level. Saying something Rio heard nothing of.

People cheered behind her, some of them were even crying—relatives and her parents' friends. 

But she wasn't able to hear all that. It was only the buzzing filling her ears.

They got out of the courtroom, people with poster signs showing their love and support to her and to her case. 

Calling her the little hero.

Their little hero.

Cameras flashed on her face once they stepped out of the court building. Microphones almost shoved down her face. Reporters asking questions she wasn't understanding or hearing. Only looking at their mouths moving. Assuming they were shouting.

She stood there beside her lawyer, the small black dots remained there, and the buzzing blended with the noise of the street.

The lawyer dismissed them all with a few words, updating them with the bare minimum.

“Rio, do you have a message to your parents?”

And she felt herself being pulled. Her eyes were opened widely, voices and sounds sharpened as they blended. Her heart was pounding in her chest.

The lawyer held Rio’s hand and they walked their way with hurried steps to the black car that was waiting for them.

Rio felt hollow when the car door got closed. No sound was inside the car but the noise was living in her head.

Her aunt sighed as she checked if Rio was alright.

But Rio wasn't alright.

How could she be?

Because what did all of this mean? 

Peoples’ words meant nothing. Their reassurance meant nothing. All of it meant nothing.

Rio wasn't supposed to be here in the first place. She wasn't supposed to witness all that. To live it. To go to a juvenile court. To testify it. To say it out loud. To admit it. To talk about something that didn't feel real. But it was real. Because no matter how hard she tried to pretend it was all an illusion, pictures would show up and fill her head.

As a punishment of survival. As a reminder of escaping. 

The blood. The murder. The guilt.

She wasn't supposed to lift this heavy weight on her shoulders. She wasn't ready to handle all of this.

At this time, a few months ago, she would be back from school, walking into the house that was full of warmth and love. The delicious smell of baking. Of watered plants.

She would go to the backyard and see her mother, sitting there in the middle, surrounded by the plants they grew together. See her painting a mesmerising view. Kiss her cheek softly. Embrace her and feel the peace and safety that could fit the whole world. She would be eating one of her favorite meals. Sit and talk with her parents about nothing and everything all at once. Talking about her day enthusiastically. Listen to her father talk about the new boat he was building. Feel her cheeks pushed up with a smile the whole time until they start to hurt.

She was supposed to feel alive at this time. 

But Rio wasn't. For long miserable months, she didn't feel like it. And it only kept getting worse.

She wasn't listening to the lawyer by her side speaking. Or her aunt talking about the family court, the custody and all. Something about child service meetings and arrangements this week. About how they would get along together.

But Rio couldn't comprehend anything. She just stared outside the window, looking at the life outside. Thinking about the one that got robbed from her.

“Okay, honey? You have an appointment with Doctor Sandra tomorrow. Your aunt will drop you off and I will be there.”

Rio snapped her head to the side. 

“I thought we weren’t going there anymore.” Her voice was so small. So innocent. And filled with pain.

“Yes, that was two weeks ago, dear,” the lawyer took Rio’s small hand. She wanted to yank her hand free, but she was more focused on what the lawyer was going to say next. “But now, the court required more sessions with Doctor Sandra. Just a few more.”

“Why do I have to go see her? Why can't I do the sessions with Aunt Teresa? She's a therapist.”

“Because, love, I can't be involved if I'm going to be your guardian. I told you that.” Her aunt said, turning her face to look at Rio with a soft smile and a sympathetic look on her face.

And Rio stared at her, the same way she did every time.

Her aunt looked so much like her mother. She sounded like her. But she wasn't her mother.

And Rii stared for a longer time after her aunt turned around.

Because the sound always rang in her ears and blended with her mother’s voice in her head.

Because the features always mixed in front of her eyes even if they weren’t there.

Her aunt and mother looked so much alike, almost like identical twins.

Except the eye color.

Her aunt’s were dark brown, but her mother’s were the greenest green she had ever seen. The only pair of eyes that embraced her with its softness.

The pair of eyes she couldn't stare at anymore to find the softness of the whole world living in their irises.

“I know. But why her?” Rio said after a few heartbeats of silence.

“You don't like her? Did something happen last time?” The lawyer asked and Rio looked at her. 

“It's… it's not that. She—she asks a lot and I don't like the stuff she gives me.” Rio turned her face back to the window.

And god how it hurts.

How it shutters a child.

To look to the side and see someone their age with their parents beside them. Unharmed and alive.

How it hurts to be jealous of someone else's happiness.

How it hurts to lose something you thought you'd keep forever.

How it hurts to know that you don't deserve.

It hurts like hell to be thirteen and yearning.

Yearning for something in a way you don't quite understand yet, but you know without that thing you feel hollow.

Silence filled the atmosphere between the three of them. Stretching loudly. Because even in silence, everyone's eyes were staring loudly at her.

And as Rio looked at the street, how she wished they would get into an accident and she'd be the only dead body after, rather than the only survivor.

Because there was no glory in surviving.

If survival meant this, Rio didn't want it.

“Alice will come later to spend the night.” Her aunt turned around briefly to look at her with a wide grin.

“You like Alice, don't you?”

“Yeah… she's cool. I like her.”

And silence stretched again, as her aunt stopped the car to buy her an ice cream. And she bought the vanilla flavored one.

Rio hated vanilla ice cream.

She tried eating it, but she couldn't.

Maybe she was picky. And that made her feel sad, not for herself, but for her aunt because she'd have to deal with her.

She felt guilty. Rio always did and always will do.

And the cone was melting on her hand when they arrived at her aunt’s house.

They got inside.

And there wasn't any delicious smell of freshly cooked pies or the smell of her favorite meals. 

The place was empty of her parents. This looked nothing like the haven she once lived in—and she was supposed to get used to it. 

This house was empty of home.

Her parents weren’t there so her home wasn't there. Rio wasn't able to feel home for months.

As her aunt walked around the house talking about something, Rio threw the ice cream cone and washed her hands in the kitchen sink.

When she turned around, the lawyer was looking at her, smiling a soft smile.

Rio’s face stayed as it was as she approached her again.

But once she lifted up her eyes, they landed on the painting hung in the hallway. The one her mother gifted to her aunt.

She was there during the process of it, she even helped her mother with it. It was one of her favorites.

But it started haunting her.

Other kids were afraid of the monsters under the beds. But thirteen-years-old Rio was afraid of the memories hanging on the walls. The ones living in her head.

“Do you need anything, Rio? Tell me,” the lawyer asked as she bent down to Rio’s level, putting a long strand of hair behind her ear.

She tried holding Rio’s hand, but Rio yanked her tiny hand immediately and clenched the necklace around her neck instead.

“I need my mother,” she said, her voice was barely above a whisper, but it echoed in the empty hallway.

It echoed and echoed and echoed in her ears on repeat.

It felt like it won't stop echoing. Won't stop reminding her. Ringing in her ear. The invisible sound vibrations made her ears bleed invisible blood, and yet she, felt it dripping from them.

Unforgiving and punishing.

Until the sound it faded.

“Oh, honey…”

“Why was I the one the universe picked? Why did it have to happen to me?” Her tears fell down her face.

Fast and scalding.

“I did nothing wrong, Miss Viv, why am I being punished?”

Her hold tightened on the piece of her mother she was able to save as the tears continued to fall down.

“No, honey, you survived. You're the little hero.”

“I’m not a hero! I’m selfish!”

“No. You're not. You're not selfish, you did what you were supposed to do.”

“Yes, I am. I’m selfish. I’m alive and they're not. They're not, Miss Viv. They're not with me.” She felt her little heart pounding in her chest. So loud, it was ringing in her ears. And it was too much to bear.

She begged for it to stop as her heart clenched tighter in her chest. Suffocating her. “I miss them.” A whisper followed by a gasp. “You ask me what I need. You say the law would do me justice, but… why justice taste so bitter? Why it can't bring them back to me?”

The lawyer tightened her hold and said something, but Rio felt her senses go mute. Unable to catch the outside. She wasn't aware of anything around her. She just felt her eyes burning, her nose sniffing, her heart pounding, her vision dark from how she was burying her face, and her head was a chaos—filled with pictures and thoughts and memories.

“My heart will... explode.” She gasped, unable to breathe. Rio felt herself being suffocated. Crushed down.

“Please make it stop.”

And she wept.

Rio loosened her hold after what she assumed were long minutes, feeling her legs unable to hold her weight.

She pulled back and wiped her eyes and nose with her sleeve, then looked up at the lawyer. She looked at her eyes long enough to start assuming that the lawyer was upset with her for doing such a thing. For weeping like a little baby.

Because Rio felt herself being a lot.

“I'm…” she swallowed her sob. “I'm sorry, Miss Viv.”

And Rio walked away to her room, despite the lawyer calling her name from behind and her aunt from the side. 

Rio made her way up the stairs as tears continued to fall down.

She didn't want to be their little hero; she wanted to be her parents’ little girl.

She didn't want justice; she wanted her mother’s embrace to soothe her, to calm her heart and lull her to sleep.

Thirteen-year-old Rio wanted to feel alive.

She wanted to breathe and not feel suffocated.

And for almost three decades, Rio yearned to be home.

“Shush.”

“I want you to behave for just a few hours.”

Because they were each other’s.

So... I'm sorry for the late update guys.

Standing in the in-between.

standing in the middle.

Chapter End Notes

I wish I could tell you guys how many times I wrote them say “I love you” in many chapters but every time I delete it when I remember that they haven't said it yet. But here we are!

Chapter Twenty

Chapter Notes

Okay, if we really think about it. This is a week later, the difference is, it's two weeks later. But we could pretend, with our free will of course, a little help of the illusion of time and a push from being sleep deprived, that this is a week later. So, enjoy this week's update. Love y'all!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio Vidal had never understood feelings in general. She'd never comprehended what they actually were .She was able to feel them, experience and express them—the bitter and the sweet ones—but never understood them. She could define each one of them accurately. Give a handful of synonyms to each emotion. Explain what they were biologically and psychologically, but the issue that she’d never found a solution to was how and why all of them burdened her at some point. One way or another. Everything overwhelmed her, no matter the amount of it or the intention behind it. She found it all overwhelming in a way she couldn't handle and had never known how to contain within limits. Everything slipped and ran out of her hand like a liquid. She knew it could adapt to the shape of its container, but the paradox was that she couldn't find the damn right container. Things always spilled and adapted a chaotic, unplanned shape. Not that she ever planned something and it actually went according to her plans anyway.

No matter what the feeling was, the terrifying process of experiencing it inside her body would always be the same. Whether, by definition, it was a positive or a negative one, it was all equivalently consuming.

She always felt it. The feeling would creep slowly inside her body, run in her veins and ride the waves of her blood. Starting in her heart—and it would clench in her chest. Thereupon to pump inside her lungs—when she'd suffocate and struggle to breathe. Then it would turn back to her heart, making it clench tighter for a good, nocuous mesure. Thus, the feelings would pump inside her whole body, nauseating and unbearable. Then eventually, like a combusting whack, it would reach her head, where it would analyze everything, throb and react. There, where lay everything that would make her miserable, simply for just feeling. Which—being miserable—was also a feeling. And it would remain like that, coursing with her blood circulation. Inside, where nothing could be visible and everything was fucking felt. Until, occasionally, it all would appear on her face and dragged out of her throat. She would sometimes weep uncontrollably, shout and scream loudly with rage and desperation. But most of the time, she kept it inside, eating her alive until she'd be alone and take it all on herself in different ways. By consuming alcohol to numb it all momentarily. Neglecting and lothating herself to let it rot. Letting her body struggle—physically and mentally—or the many other ways she adopted as methods of coping over the years. Ways of surviving in the face of simply, feeling.

Feelings were wicked. All of them. Whether they provided her a temporary happiness or a long-living sorrow and agony. The countless days and nights tormented her ashen body and forsaken soul. When she wished she would turn cold the next day. To be uncaring and distant even from herself. To just be living in this big melancholic world, just another number of a person, until the day for her would come. To be withdrawn slowly, then she'd be one with the void. Rio never cared about the world losing another person—losing her—because she never considered it losing in the first place. Many died every millisecond and doubles were born in the same exact damn millisecond. So it wasn't that big of a deal.

The only thing she wished, the only emotion she wanted and begged her body to feel, was the bliss of complete numbness. Something to match her long-lasting loneliness that she felt even in the middle of a teeming place. Amongst a crowd she didn't belong to. Because Rio never belonged.

The people who Rio was able to express her emotions to weren’t people she found by herself and decided to go toward. To just speak out her mind and express what she felt for them. They always—always—came to her. Whether she wanted them to come or not. The good and the dreadful ones. They always approached her first. She was never the one who started things first. She didn't come first even in contexts like these.

She always felt herself driven. Sailing with the flow in a boat with holes and no oars by her sides. There was no way to reach a destination where she could land and just simply walk with bare feet.

But all of it turned out just fine, or at least, that was what she repeated to herself over and over again. That everything went in its own way and led her so she could be here. To be what she was. Even if she didn't approve of where she stood or who she was as a person, she still took it. All the traumatic events she went through. All the disappointments she experienced, and the reckless, unreasonable things she did, they guided her to stand in the mark she was standing on. Which didn't mean anything and it wasn't much by all means, but it was fine. She accepted it with exhaustion, without making peace with it, because that was the only thing she was able to do.

But love.

Love? Unquestionably, that one was dangerous.

Because just like how immensely she felt everything, love took the same overwhelming pattern—only worse.

If she felt love toward someone or something? That meant being exposed fully. It meant being unguarded, unraveled. It meant her body and soul would react immediately, without giving her the chance to even hold the weight inside, to measure it and make sure of how heavy and overwhelming all of it was.

Rio loved so deeply. Deep enough to be hurt beyond healing. Her love was aching. The scarring kind. She loved with all of her senses, and the worst part? She attached easily. And she was all aware of it. But what would being aware do in front of being helpless?

Rio knew the chaotic and overwhelming side of loving. Nothing other than that. And that was her only view of it. All the movies she watched under the romance genre—which were many, because she always touched something through them, something untouchable—all the feelings they tried showing through rehearsed scripts and beautiful cinematography—she was aware those weren’t real. Not what love actually felt and looked like. Not what she experienced her entire life. Because all of it was written beforehand after all.

She knew love, that cursed feeling. Rio experienced it. Her body got infected with it more than once. It was more of a disease than a feeling. Love was ugly. It was painful. There were times she wished she hadn’t had the ability to love so she wouldn't have to suffer because of it. Wouldn't have to deal with the sorrowful aftermath of it.

Because she knew, if a thing went wrong, just a tiny little error in the enormous system, it would lead to a total collapse. It meant wreck and destruction. It meant suffering, and suffering was never good unless you were a tortured artist.

She loved three times. Three women in three different, cursed periods of her life. 

One of them was Alice, which was the only relationship Rio made peace with, because at the time she was young and way too oblivious of how fucked everything was. Including herself.

The other two? Disasters.

Nightmares she wanted nothing but to run away from. To just wake up and escape them.

One relationship that lasted nearly a year, but moving on? The process of getting rid of the feelings she had? They lasted longer. Way longer.

Then years later, Jane appeared. Fucking Jane.

A troubled woman Rio fell for because she was nothing but a pathetic, desperate fool. A woman that dragged her through every layer of hell.

The hate she had toward love feelings—she predominantly experienced with people. Other fellow human beings. Because plants and inanimate objects? The things she experienced solitude with? Those were the most appreciative and grateful. No matter how small and trivial they were. They never kissed goodbye, they kiss in their own ways and remain to give more than what they take.

And Rio just kept looking at the picture in that way most of her life. To the point she didn't remember anything that had existed before it, because she always seemed to see it that way. Her eyes always gazed forward.

And then Agatha arrived.

With ease and tenderness she turned the picture around. To its actual face. And revealed what it held. What it should always have been.

A scenery of something real, something that always existed and was there. Not out of this world, not fiction. Yet it was arresting in its conspicuous, exquisite reality.

Because apparently, Rio was only gazing at the back of a picture hanging on a plain wall. And she was too convinced that this was it, to the point she didn't question it any more. She just sat and stared forward. Trying so desperately to make sense of it even if it lacked any common sense. 

But that was what you do when you limit yourself, wasn't it? When you get exhausted and start trying to convince yourself with something nonsensical, that even you don't understand—just so you could sit down and stop thinking about it. Taking hold of the fallacious so you could rest. Then you realize that it only took a simple move. Just a shift to make it obvious for you. To make you really rest, body and soul.

And that was what Agatha did. With a tender shift, she showed Rio that everything could change to the way she wanted. That feelings shouldn't always be overwhelming. Life wasn't always mournful and unfair. Healing shouldn't cost more than being hurt. And that her existence meant something. Her journey wasn't nothing even if she took a path that made her struggle—a path that forced her to think less of herself. Agatha showed her that she deserved to take, to be loved, to be embraced. And if something happened, if that day came, she wouldn't just float away to the void. Rio would be lost. Not as a number, but as a goddamn human being.

And love.

Just by existing, Agatha made Rio realize that she could love. Could say the words out loud, express them and act upon them. She made her realize that her ability to love was something to be cherished and not chained down. Something to be proud of. Something human. Something Agatha was ready and willing to take inside her, no matter how deep it was.

There, maybe she found a container.

She was looking at them for a long time, crouching in front of a pot, trying just to know what caused her dear plants to turn like this. Unable to figure out if it was because of improper watering—because she was busy and forgot to do so in the past few days—or if they were diseased.

She closed her eyes briefly and exhaled a deep breath, because yes, Agatha’s voice did that much to her.

Rio looked up at her with a slight pout. Looking at Agatha’s wide, soft eyes and staring straight at the heartwarming gleam they held inside. An honest, soft smile that reached all the way up to her eyes. Because no matter how bad it was, looking at Agatha and that reassuring look in her eyes? “Oh? I didn't know about that.”

Chapter End Notes

Holy shit, it has been a hell of a week!
Four weeks to be precise. Actually... five weeks and a few days. But well anyway, who's counting? (me and you and a whole nation apparently.)

But really, in my defense, this chapter wasn't planned at all. It was supposed to be their trip to Paris but I got stuck mid writing and I couldn't write one of the simplest scenes ever, so I had to come up with something, and that's how this chapter was born. (come on twenty-one, say hi!)

Also I have another WIP that I'm currently working on, that if I'm not writing it, then I'm thinking about it.

Also, it's 45°C+ where I live, so if my head isn't melting then my fingers are, and vice versa.

Anyway, I thought about spillting this chapter into two when I realized how long it was, but I decided to keep it that way. It's good in its length and I really love this chapter because I literally poured myself and my time into writing it. (I only edited this once because I wanted to update, so I might edit a few things later. In the meantime, ignore the mistakes.)

So, enough yapping.
I hope you enjoyed reading this chapter the way I enjoyed writing it.

Your comments and kudos are always welcomed and appreciated, they make my days.

Afterword
